> You ... Researched the artifact
You grab the artifact and fire up google.


What do you want to know?
> You what is a Shabti?
Shabti or Ushabti (Egyptian language) is a funerary figurine which served as a dead man's deputy in order to do labor for him, mostly agricultural, in the afterlife. They existed between the Twenty-first dynasty of Egypt and the end of the First Intermediate Period.<|endoftext|>
<|startoftext|>You grab the artifact and fire up google.


What do you want to know?
> You why is Anubis depicted in the corner?
You find the following information about Anubis. However, you cannot find any examples of him being depicted on Shabti statues. That's a bit odd ...

Originally, in the Ogdoad system, he was god of the underworld, and his name is frequently thought to have reflected this, meaning something like putrefaction. He was said to have a wife, Anput, who was really just his female aspect, her name being his with an additional feminine suffix (the t), who was depicted exactly the same (though feminine). His father was originally said to be Ra, as he was the creator god, and thus his mother was said to be Hesat, Ra's wife, who later was identified as Hathor (who her identity was remarkably similar to). As lord of the underworld, Anubis was identified as the father of Kebechet, the goddess of the purification of bodily organs due to be placed in canopic jars, during mummification.

As ruler over the dead, he was given titles such as He who is set upon his mountain, in reference to his sitting atop desert cliffs to guard multiple necropolis, and Chontamenti (also spelt Khentimentiu, and Khentamenti), meaning Lord of the Westerners, in reference to Egyptian belief that the entrance to the underworld was towards the west, since that was the direction in which the sun set. As ruler, he was also said to have been victorious over the dark forces (described as nine bows), which also, naturally, lurk in the underworld, gaining him the title Jackal ruler of the bows.

As king of the underworld, he was also considered to be the one who weighed the heart of the dead against the feather of Maàt (the concept of truth), gaining him the title He who counts the hearts. One of the reasons that the ancient Egyptians took such care to preserve their dead with sweet-smelling herbs was that it became believed Anubis would check each person with his keen canine nose. Only if they smelled pure would he allow them to enter the Kingdom of the Dead.<|endoftext|>

> You enough Research ...
How time flies when you're researching. Before you know it, it's Sunday night, and time for bed.

As you and Alex get ready for bed, Alex complains that two of the fish died.<|endoftext|>
<|startoftext|>The bed is lovely. You are quite comfortable underneath your fluffy blanket, and sunlight has just begun to stream through the window. Perhaps there are birds twittering somewhere far away, but you don't pay much attention to anything. Everything is soft and warm, and soon you are nearly asleep again.


Then there is something against your lips. It is soft and warm too, and you smile. Your mouth is full of sweetness and the taste of great ripe blackberries. You picture them hanging on the bush, gleaming dark on a summer day. Now it is like wine, and now like honey.


The thing against your lips pushes a little harder, and the flavor grows stronger. The wine goes sour and the honey is sickly sweet. The berries seem to burst and spill their rotten juice. There are flies and maggots now, crawling and fluttering and devouring your tongue and face. You scream and they swarm down your throat. You open your eyes; the room has gone terribly dark, and everything is cold.


Sprawled across your body is a woman with purple lips, so purple they seem almost black. She studies you dispassionately for a moment as the insects crawl about your stomach and chew your organs. You cannot scream any more, you cannot even think. You only look at her beautiful face and those lips. You watch her spread a pair of vast silverly wings around you, until you are utterly alone. 


Then she bends forward and gives another kiss. 
> You continue...
You wake up gasping in a pool of sweat. It takes a few minutes before you realize it was a dream, the same dream that's come many times over the past year. Sometimes there will be a month in between the nightmares, sometimes only a few days, but they always come back, and they are always the same.


It's funny. The dreams look real, and indeed they even taste real, but after a couple hours you can never seem to remember exactly how those dark lips tasted or how the air grew hideously cold. You can't even remember what the woman's face looked like, only that she was very beautiful.


Today you'll have to force the images from your mind even faster. You can't afford to have these phantoms dancing around in your head during the examination, not after you've worked so hard just to have the chance at entering the College. It's been your dream for years, and who could blame you? The College is practically on your doorstep. Students come from across the country and some from the far corners of the world, but the great iron gates are barely ten minutes from your house. You passed them every day when you walked to school. Behind the gates you saw the students, laden with piles of old books, and the professors, some wizened old men, others .


Once you even caught a glimpse of the Chancellor himself, Dr. Fogg, stooping down to speak to a gardener. He wore a plain black suit, not much different from any merchant or gentleman, but his white beard grazed the grass as he peered through tiny spectacles at the flowers.


You head downstairs. Mrs. Littlethwaite, your family's cook, brings a plate of eggs, sausages, potatoes, and mushrooms, but you can only pick at the food. The sour dream taste is fading, but it doesn't leave much of an appetite behind. Still, you force down a cup of tea and manage some potatoes.


"Your father is in his study," Mrs. Littlethwaite calls from the kitchen. The order is left unsaid, but it still fills you with dread. You climb the narrow stairs and knock on his door. A moment later he calls you in.


He sits behind his desk, upon which sit a number of papers and a small brass balance. Augustus Latimer is tall and thick with a short beard. He motions you closer, still copying something from a huge ledger book. You stand silent as the minutes go by. You're not late, but every second makes you more and more nervous. All your notes are in a satchel upstairs- you'd like to be inside the examination room already, studying them one final time.
> You finally he sets down the ledger.
"He regards you for a moment and sighs. "Have you prepared as well as you can?"


"I've studied everything covered in the entrance exams, Father. Theology, natural philosophy, literature, the rudiments of daemonology, mathematics. And Latin and Greek, of course." You shift from one foot to another, hoping he won't comment.


He looks down at his paper and back to you. "Mathematics?"


"Yes sir. Arithmetic, geometry, algebra, and calculus."


"You never showed much interest in figures when I tried explaining the business."


You hold his gaze for as long as you can. "I'm afraid not, Father."


He only sighs again. "Very well. The College is certainly respectable, and the daemonologists do good service to the Church and the King, but I cannot say I approve of you joining them. Too many are disreputable, too many are foreigners, too many swindle superstitious old women. Too many are selfish and care only for increasing their own power. Too many care only for their work and do not think of the consequences of their magic." He pauses, and you are about to respond when he continues. "Your brother did quite well at Cambridge, you know. Dr. Burney is a friend of the family, and I am sure a letter would secure admission there. His brother is Bishop of Norwich, and I know many other churchmen besides. I'm sure we could find you a position, some well-endowed parsonage perhaps. Unless you're quite determined to continue on this course?"


The old argument, and on examination day too. At least it's helping you forget the dream. "I think my talents can best serve the nation this way, Father."


"Very well. You may go." His eyes linger for a moment on the portrait of you mother, and then he opens the ledger book and begins copying again. The scratching sound seems to follow you as you leave the study and climb to your room. You snatch your satchel and go back down the stairs. You're almost out the door when you see Mrs. Littlethwaite emerge into the entranceway. She's holding something.


"I thought you might get hungry during the exam. It's only a few scones, but it's better than nothing. Good luck dear." Her wrinkled face breaks into a smile, though she's crying a little too. You bend down to give her a quick hug, which makes her blush and sends her scurrying back to the kitchen.
> You to the Gates
It is overcast this morning, but the August sun still beats down and makes the whole city sweat. You pass traders, their carts full of apples and cheese and fish, beggars hunched over beside the street, and old men smoking outside a tavern. A priest, his face red above his starched white collar, yells at a group of schoolboys who nearly knocked him over chasing one another. Only a few months ago you were one of them, studying at St. Stephen's School in the south of Covingsford.


Soon you are at the Iron Gates of the College. They are only opened today, for examinations, and in June, when each graduating class departs, diplomas in hand, to war with the supernatural enemies of the kingdom and of all mankind. A bald man stands just inside, marking off names on a paper and wearing an annoyed scowl. He asks yours, and after you've told him, directs you down the path to Dodley Hall. 


The College is full of old stone buildings and neat lawns, and you follow the thin line of prospective students to a particularly large hall near the center of the grounds. The vast antechamber is packed. Most are around eighteen or so, around your age, but there are a handful of adults and even a plump and cheerful old man in a tattered coat. You catch a few snatches of whispered conversation, although everyone is too busy reviewing their notes to really talk. You do the same, letting your eyes wander across Cromwell's classification of lesser spirits, not really taking much in. There are a few hundred people here, and you wonder how many will gain admission. You can always try again next year, but there's a limit to your father's grudging tolerance for this ambition.


Nearly an hour passes in nervous anticipation before the bald man bangs a gong and the room goes entirely silent. Another man, standing behind a small podium, clears his throat. Everyone presses forward to hear while he smiles down indulgently, his red hair and moustache expertly coiled. "Welcome to the admissions examination for Covingsford College. I am Dr. Sidney Ffoukes, and you have already met my colleague Dr. Coghill." The bald man scowls. "In a moment, we will begin calling your names. When your name is called, please proceed to your assigned examination room. A member of the faculty will be waiting to evaluate your fitness for study at this institution. He will disclose his decision, which is final, upon completion of the examination. Good luck to you all."


The crowd waits expectantly for a moment. Coghill hands Ffoukes his list. "Mr. James Day." Day is short and thin, and he goes completely pale at his name. "Mr. Day, your examination will be in room 1." Ffoukes gives a little nod, and Day, trembling, walks down towards the door. The crowd gives him a wide berth, all eyes watching. He disappears through the door.


"Mr. Thomas Wesley" is called next, then "Mr. George Ryder" and "Mr. George Townsend." Then Mr. Patrick Warren, Mr. Phillippe Maréchal, and Mr. Ramsay Bennet. The names and faces fade into a blur as you try to focus on your notes.
> You hours drift by...
The room is much emptier now. Coghill and Ffoukes take turns calling names, and you watch a fat servant bring in bowls of stew and white bread for them to share. You remember Mrs. Littlethwaite's scones and pull them from your satchel. They are soft and crumbly and sweet, and they help keep you calm while you watch the others muttering Latin to themselves and pacing around the room.


"Do you have anything else to eat?" Startled, you turn to find another examinee staring at your satchel. His clothes are a little worn and he looks a bit older than you, though some of that might just be because his skin is drawn and sallow. His eyes have a strange, piercing glint, but then he smiles. "Us forgotten ones have to stick together, don't we?"


You hand him the rest of your last scone and introduce yourself. He eats it quickly and does the same. He is Peter Aubrey, from London, and he has been an orphan since his parents' deaths at sea some years ago. His uncle raised him, but he too died this past year. "But his friend, the learned Mr. Clark of Southwark, was quite kind to me. He knew Dr. Buckstone, one of the professors here, from Eton, and wrote him a letter asking the College to examine me."


You talk with Peter for the next hour, happy to have something to take your mind off what lies in the next corridor. When Ffoukes finally calls out your name, you barely feel nervous at all. Peter shakes your hand, and then you walk through the door and along the hall to room 11. You hadn't talked much about the exams themselves (better to avoid anything that might aggravate your nerves), but you hope he's well prepared. He certainly needs a place more than you do. 


You knock on the door and a weak voice calls you in. Banishing the image of your father and his study from your mind, you head inside to find a truly ancient man, his skin like old parchment. He squints at you. "Name?" he titters, his accent Scottish.


You answer, and as he writes it down you watch his hand trembling. You hope they'll be able to read it later- if you're admitted, that is.
> You he coughs and begins to speak.
"I am Dr. Thewliss, professor of Historical Studies and Daemonography." You bow and he continues. "The examination is straightforward. There are no tricks. Do not try to be clever. Answer the questions in good, plain language and you will do splendidly."


He glances down at his papers. "Explain Lagrange's Mean Value Theorem."


You rattle off the definition exactly as you memorized it. "Any part of a continuous smooth curve will certainly include a point at which the curve of the slope and that of the section will be precisely equal, sir."


"How did Hibbert explain the transmission of infectious diseases?"


You think for a moment. "Hibbert believed that diseases were spread solely through contaminated water, sir. He held that patients should be allowed only clean water and coarse bread to cure every kind of disease."


Dr. Thewliss scratches his nose. "And was this effective?"


"No, sir. Hibbert's patients recovered at the same rate as those of any other doctor. He himself contracted consumption and died from it."


And so it goes for a few dozen questions. You are able to give good answers to most questions and something to every he asks. You describe St. Augustine's views on free will and predestination, Shakespeare's tragedies, Quincy's tripartite theory of daemonic possession, the chemical composition of British soils, and so on. Dr. Thewliss remains dispassionate through most of your answers, though he gives a satisfied chuckle when you repeat, verbatim, 21 lines from Virgil in Latin. You fall into an easy rhythm. Question, answer, question, answer. Then Dr. Thewliss asks something you hadn't anticipated.


"Do you have experiential knowledge of any spirit, whether angelic, daemonic, or of indeterminate nature?"


You open your mouth to say no, and suddenly the taste of sour wine and sickly sweet berries fills it. You begin to gag and cough, your mind racing. All the awful dreams of the past year come back in an instant. Is it possible that they were more than simple nightmares brought on by an overactive imagination and evenings spent reading daemonological texts? The dreams are always the same, at least as far as you can remember.  Always the beautiful face and the delicate, silver wings. Always pleasurable at first, and then suddenly horrifying and foul.


But you're still alive, still healthy. What kind of daemon would haunt your dreams for months without doing any real harm? Besides, it's only a dream. Nothing has ever appeared to you while you're awake, not even to whisper in your ear or try to frighten you by knocking books off a desk. Dr. Thewliss isn't asking about imagined monsters. The College isn't interested in nightmares, only in real daemons and those who are serious about fighting them. Telling the old man about what you’ve dreamed will likely make him think you a fool, or worse, but you know you must be honest. They are probably nothing, but you can risk some embarrassment to be sure.
> You tell Dr. Thewliss
You take a deep breath. Surely he wouldn't ask unless he wanted to know if there was even the possibility that you'd encountered a daemon. Besides, if it really is more than a dream, maybe Dr. Thewliss or another professor can help. They'll certainly be able to do more than you can alone. "I'm not sure, sir. I've had recurring dreams, strange visions that seem as vivid as real life but then disappear when I wake up."


Dr. Thewliss looks at you with some concern. "What happens in these dreams? Have you seen a spirit? I take it from your reaction that they are not pleasant."


"Very pleasant at first, sir, but then horrible. It's a woman, or something like a woman at any rate. She has great silver wings, and she..." You stop, a little embarrassed.


"She what? Kisses you? That would be most common." You nod and he continues. "Her lips, describe them. Their appearance, their taste. Tell me everything you can remember."


Feeling a little foolish, you explain what you can recall. It's difficult, but you manage to get everything important across. Dark lips, the sweet tastes that turn foul, the sensation of insects. Dr. Thewliss nods at each word. "In the course of your studies, have you encountered the phrase concupiscent nocurnae?" You shake your head. "I'm not surprised, it is fairly technical. Perhaps you have heard the common name- a succubus?"


Your blood runs cold. Yes, you have heard of the dreaded succubus, the terror of men through the ages and in every country, savage or civilized. It is said they come at night and tempt men to unspeakable acts, that their kiss is death and that carnal acts with one brings on a living death far worse than the grave. "But it cannot be a succubus, sir!" you nearly shout. "I'm still alive."


Dr. Thewliss nods. "Quite observant and quite correct, Mr. Latimer. But you have only encountered the daemon, if it truly is one, in a dream. And dreams, though they may have great meaning, are still only dreams. No daemon can harm your body or soul when it appears in a dream, though it may of course corrupt your mind. Now, it may be that this is nothing but a simple nightmare. If not, thank God that the nocturnae has not appeared in the flesh." He sits back and rubs his wrinkled hands together. He looks lost in thought for a moment and then begins to read over your answers. It seems he considers the matter settled.


You, however, cannot let things end there. "But sir, what if it should come while I am awake? I will be lost!"


"Perhaps, Mr. Latimer. But I think you will be more prepared for that possibility soon than you are now." He straightens up and his voice, though still weak, takes on a quivering authority. "On behalf of the faculty, the governors, and the Crown, I am pleased to offer you admission to Covingsford College to study daemonology. Your formal matriculation, should you accept the offer, shall occur at the beginning of the fall term in September. Your answers were exemplary, and nothing you said gave me any reason to hesitate from offering you admission with great enthusiasm. Indeed, given the circumstances, it would be foolish not to admit you. If you truly have been visited by a daemon, it is certainly not by chance."


You look back at the tiny old man for a moment, not quite understanding what he means through the accent and official language. Then it all comes together in one great flash of light- you've done it. You will be a student at the College, and if a succubus really does appear you'll be able to fight it off. Thank God you decided to mention your dreams. Dr. Thewliss beams back down at you and adds, in a final squeak "Welcome!"


You shake the professor's hand and make your way out Dodley Hall's back door into the heart of the College grounds. The morning clouds have broken and the summer heat is fierce. You are full of energy. You want to run, to jump and sing and shout. But this is England, and you are a daemonologist-in-training now, so you content yourself with breathing in the sticky August air and wearing an enormous grin. A few other examinees are hanging around too, most just marveling at the stone buildings and the fact that their hard work and luck has paid off. 


A while later you notice Peter emerge from the examination hall, blinking in the light. He looks even paler and less healthy outside, but his smile is no smaller than yours. "You're in too?" he asks hopefully. You nod. "I had a feeling. Is there a good tavern or something around here? Greek makes me hungry, and Dr. Davies must have asked half his questions in the wretched language. I know it's his subject, but it doesn't make for a very balanced examination."


You are about to set off for the White Boar, a good inn near the marketplace, when Dr. Thewliss emerges from the hall. He sees you and totters over, waving his arms. You notice a few students laughing at the tiny old man. "Mr. Latimer, Mr. Latimer!" He takes a minute to reach you, and when he arrives he nods at Peter before addressing you again. "I fear I was too hasty in dismissing you. For your own safety and from an overabundance of caution, let me invite you back to my office. I may be able to give you some rudimentary protection. Just something to ensure your safety until term begins."


You arrange to meet Peter in the tavern a little later and follow Dr. Thewliss around the College grounds to his office.
> You cannot stop grinning at your good luck.
The professor winds around the College buildings and lawns before finally entering one near the center of the grounds. Like many of his colleagues, Dr. Thewliss lives and works in this ancient stone structure. His office is small but well-used. Books law strewn about the desk and tables in English, Latin, Greek, Hebrew, Arabic, and a number of other languages. He rummages through a chest for a few minutes before pulling out a small object.


"This," he explains, holding it up by the window and waving you closer, "is an ankh. First discovered by the Egyptians, clever fellows, it will give you a little protection from lesser daemons. It's iron too, which cannot hurt."


He hands you the amulet. It's shaped roughly like a cross, only it's topped with a looping ring. You are at a loss for words, so you bow.


Dr. Thewliss laughs, a high and reedy but not unpleasant sound. "There won't be any need for that. It's not such a handsome present, really. Any scrap of iron would do almost as well, nothing daemonic can abide the stuff. Now remember, it isn't very powerful. Just strong enough to spook the nocturnae and make it think again about chasing you, if it's really a nocturnae at all."


"Sir," you ask, "how else can I protect myself from a succubus?"


"You can't expect me to give away all the secrets of our profession today, not before you've even officially enrolled. Succubi are frightening, there's no denying that, but they usually aren't picky about their prey. Nine times out of ten, if you put up the least resistance, it'll leave and find someone easier to tempt. Mind you, it's not easy to find a man who'll put up resistance to a beautiful woman, not when she's as good at seduction as a nocturnae. That's why the ankh will be useful."


You thank Dr. Thewliss for the gift and his advice, but you can't help feeling a little less calm than he seems to be. The professor seems to be treating your dreams as quite real, much more so than you'd anticipated. And if succubi aren't picky, why has this one chosen to haunt your dreams for a year? There isn't anything in particular about you that would attract daemonic attention.


With a head full of questions and the ankh around your neck, you walk to the White Boar to find Peter already on his third pint. Soon you are drunk too, and as the hours go by you forget your concerns. All you remember  from the morning is that you passed the examination.
> You lose track of the time
"Lizzy works at her father's shop. He's Thomas Norrell, a bookseller, and she used to smuggle me out whatever I wanted to read and then return it before he'd notice. When I told her about the College examination she helped me a lot, brought me all sorts of things I needed and even introduced me to her father as 'an aspiring daemonologist.' He's not a bad fellow, but I suppose he didn't like my look, and that made Lizzy quite sad for a while. She's pretty, even when she's sad. Long blond hair, lovely blue eyes, plenty of other...assets." 


You burst out laughing at the gesture Peter makes on that last word. You've talked for a long time, with the ale flowing all throughout. Peter continues his story, and you listen as best you can, but soon you've fallen asleep right at the table, your head resting comfortably in the remains of a pork pie.


You awaken in the morning on a pile of flour sacks with a letter pinned to your shirt. Your head hurts a great deal, but it's better than the nightmares. The note is brief.


My dear Mr. Latimer,


I preemptively accept your most heartfelt thanks for carrying you to your luxurious accommodations. I shall have returned to London by the time you read these words, but I will be back in Covingsford in September for the beginning of term and will look for the man who cannot control his beer and has the charming smug knowledge of a native son of the town. In the meantime, I may be reached at the home of Mr. Geoffrey Clark of Great Suffolk Street, Southwark.


Your humble and most obedient servant,


Peter Aubrey


You fold the letter and put it in your pocket. The barmen gives you a smirk as you leave, and you realize there's still a bit of gravy dried on your face. You wipe it off as you walk back home. It's only then that you realize you never told your father the examination results. Even through the headache you feel nervous. You begin fingering the ankh mechanically, wondering if the iron will protect against his cold glare and disapproval.


"Brother?" calls a voice, interrupting your worrying. You turn and see Charles striding up the road, his cloak and coat flecked with mud from the road. "Has Father told you of the difficulties?" You shake your head. It's been weeks since you've seen him, but Charles is not interested in catching up. "Let me speak to him first, then. I'll get to the heart of the matter. it can hardly be as dire as his letter suggested, even if it's all true. Stability is the cornerstone of success in business, Father taught me that, and I won't forget it now."


You follow him home, and your brother explains what he knows of the family's troubles. It seems that a string of bad luck hit several of your father's ventures. Some mines have run empty, and the American rebels have burned and looted a great deal of British property across the colonies. You tell Charles that you were admitted to the College. "Well done," he says, and then goes back to explaining the financial woes.
> You he goes to the study as soon as you get home
You stand at the foot of the staircase, trying to catch something of their conversation but to no avail. Giving up, you decide that some water would be the best thing for your headache.


You find Mrs. Littlethwaite and one of the serving girls in the dining room. The latter is sweeping, but apparently it's not to the old woman's liking. "For heaven's sake girl, give me that broom! You've got to push the dirt, not send it flying. Like this." When she sees you she nearly drops the broom. "Oh dear, you don't look well at all. Come here and let's find you something to drink."


Tottering over, she tries to help you to a chair. "There there, you can always take the examination again next year."


Smiling, you correct her. "I won't need to, Mrs. Littlethwaite. I passed. This is just what comes of celebrating afterwards."


She gives you a little swat on the side. "You shouldn't play such jokes on an old woman! If your mother could see you now, how proud she'd be. Oh, I'm so proud I could burst and I'm only a cook!" Her eyes tear up, so you make her take the chair next to you. You stay there, telling her about the examination, Dr. Thewliss, and Peter, though of course you don't mention anything about your dreams.


Charles stays in the study until tea time. "Well, I was right that things aren't as hopeless as Father first thought. But between the Americans, the mines, and some other ill-fated investments, we don't have much capital on hand, much less than we ought. I'll return to London tomorrow, and he may come along. We should be able to find sterling enough to cover our debts until this black clouds breaks. We just need to keep our wits about us." He gulps down a quick cup of tea and adds "I told Father that you passed the examination, so there's no need for you to disturb him. Now, I need to walk and think."


Turning just before he reaches the door, you brother regards you for a moment. "It really would be best not to disturb our father today. As I said, he's calmed considerably now, but anything might set him off again. He's never been like this, not that I can remember, except perhaps...well, except when Mother died. Your birth. Good day, brother." And, with a stiff bow, Charles departs.


You certainly won't go to your father's study after a warning like that, not that there was much chance of it before. Charles comes back in the evening but goes straight upstairs. He leaves the next day before you wake up, and your father follows in the afternoon. "Make inquiries about tuition and fees," he instructs you coldly, leaving you at home with only the servants and your dreams. You squeeze the ankh, hoping it will at least take care of the latter problem.
> You things slowly quiet down...
Your father and brother remain in London for most of the next few weeks, but the latter sends a handful of brief letters that make it clear the family isn't going to fall into complete ruin. When he comes back near the beginning of September, he says the same thing in person.


Of course, changes must be made, and one of the serving girls is sent packing. Charles tells you they might send Simon away too, since your father does not often host guests and a family hardly needs a butler to manage things when they have only two other servants, but nothing has been decided yet.


Meanwhile, you've spent the intervening days exchanging letters with Peter and reading anything you could find on succubi. There isn't much in the books you've collected, and you can't access the College's library until the term starts. What you've found hasn't made you any less anxious, but at least the dreams have stayed away. Maybe the ankh is working, or maybe it really was just the stress of the entrance examination. In any case, it's the longest you've gone without a nightmare since they started.


You learned the College tuition is steep, but not terribly so, and informed your father of the cost by letter. He has not responded, and the few times he's been in Covingsford has barely said a word. There is something a little shameful, you cannot help but feel, in spending so much on your studies while the family is in somewhat dire straits, and despite all your anticipation, you nearly tell your father you've changed your mind. You always beat back these vague feelings of guilt, but you remain quite sure that your father feels the same way, though he has not shown it.


Some madness has caused you to use his study as your main reading room, perhaps because it is not quite as hot as your bedroom. Simon raised an eyebrow the first time he saw you enter, but, dour gentleman that he is, has not said a word. There is something reassuring about being able to glance up at your mother's face whenever you read some new and terrifying fact about succubi or daemons in general. You wonder if the portrait did as much good for your father when he got the wretched news about the family's fortunes.


With only one serving girl, Mrs. Littlethwaite has been working a good deal harder to keep the house impeccable. You tried telling her it was alright, that there was no need to dust rooms no one sleeps in, but she wouldn't hear it.


As luck would have it, your father returns the evening of September 1st. The first day of term is in the morning. His presence sends Mrs. Littlethwaite scurrying out of the dining room- you had taken to eating all your meals with her in his absence. He stares for a moment. "You are to begin tomorrow. Your letter did not contain the cost of accommodations at the College."


"I had thought I would lodge here, sir. There's no need to spend..."


"There is every need," he interrupts. "Propriety insists things be done in the established way, and in any case, the cost of a room in their dormitory will not break this family. I will not have it be said that my son had to live in his childhood bedroom because his father had lost all the family's wealth. You will make arrangements for a room after your matriculation tomorrow and send the cost by letter. There will be no need for you to return until Christmas." He turns and walks upstairs, and the familiar feeling of guilt returns.


A moment later Mrs. Littlethwaite creeps from the kitchen. "It seems I won't be seeing you for some time," you say.


She glances at the staircase and frowns, though she catches herself after a second. "I shan't be going anywhere, dear. Now, you go off and learn everything you can, and don't spend a minute thinking of me." You shake your head and she gives you a quick, tight hug.


You spend the next few hours packing everything you'll need. Clothes, books, it's all very ordinary. Very little to suggest you'll be learning to combat dark powers. When you're finished you try to sleep, but you lay awake, thinking of tomorrow, wondering what the future will bring, and arguing with yourself about what you ought to do. Time slides by and you aren't growing any more tired.
> You go for a walk
Covingsford is mostly deserted at this time of night. It's warm and the air is sticky. You set off in a different direction than usual, away from the College's Iron Gates and out of town. Soon you are walking through fields full of fat wheat, the moon big and bright above. In the distance there is a peasant's cottage, but for now you are quite alone.


Or perhaps not. Something makes a sound like wind behind you, but the thick air does not move. You turn but see nothing. A few minutes later it happens again, and when you look there is still nothing there. When you hear the noise a third time, you spin as fast as you can, and there she stands, her face just inches from your own.


It is the woman from your dreams. Her eyes are bright, brighter than any eyes you've seen before, but her lips are darker than the night. Her face is more beautiful in person than you could ever have imagined, a pale, unearthly beauty. Mindlessly you move slowly forward until your lips have almost touched hers and your arms are almost caressing her soft skin.


She takes a step back, and you regain a little of your senses. She is a succubus, there can be no doubt. There was something you were supposed to do if she ever really came, what was it? Something that would make her go away. 


The she speaks, and everything else disappears. Her voice is deep, sultry, and feminine, and you stumble closer even as she keeps backing up. Somewhere in the back of your mind you notice she isn't smiling, but you can't seem to care. "You're weaker than I expected, and what's that around your neck? Such a nasty thing for a nice boy like you to wear. Would you stop coming nearer, I'm trying to speak to you. I said stop." She says the last word with complete authority and you freeze, still staring into her eyes.


"That's better. Now I want you to think very hard, I know you're clever. I am going to give you a choice, and I'm sure you'll want to make the choice that will make me happy. You want me to be happy, don't you?" You nod stupidly. "Such a clever boy. You're going to the College in the morning, aren't ypu? Such a waste of your talents. I could teach you more, show you more. Let you feel much more." She grabs your hand in her own and places it on her chest, then pulls you close. 


Wrapping her body around yours, she whispers in your ear, careful never to touch her lips to your skin. "Come with me now, and I will make this night the first time you have truly lived."


You stand, her heat spreading into your body. You can feel her breath on your neck, and the only thing you can think is that she wants you, and you want her. You need her.
> You give in
"Yes. Yes. Yes," you gasp.


She looks at you for a second and then laughs. There is no humor or joy in the sound, but you don't notice that. Her vast wings extend and, holding you close, she takes off into the dark sky.


Time passes. You cannot tell how much, but eventually you land in a misty old church yard, the stones covered in black lichen. The moon is gone, and there are no stars above, but you don't notice that.


Bodies intertwined, you fall to the soft grass. The ground is littered with bones, and the gravestones have been defaced with foul symbols and curses in heathen tongues. You don't notice.


Instead, you spend several pleasurable minutes exploring the body of your new companion. She is so pale she seems to glow just slightly in the night, and that and the dim light of the mist are all to see by. You don't mind much, as your other senses have more than enough to occupy them. You don't even notice when she sinks her teeth into the gold chain you wear around your neck, snapping it effortlessly and letting the little ankh fall useless among the bones.


Eventually she pushes you away. Her eyes shine brighter than before and, if you cared to look, you might have seen the tears on her perfect, porcelain cheeks. "I thought you were something more," she says, her voice emotionless. "But I suppose this is reasonably diverting too." She presses her lips against yours, and then the agony begins. The insects and maggots crawling down your throat, sour wine and sickening rotten flavors compete to make you gag and choke. But you do not die.


She pulls her lips away and the horror recedes, but when she takes you inside her it comes back worse than before. You forget the taste of sweet berries and wine, you forget the feeling of the summer sun and the wind on your face. You forget your name. The pain is everywhere, and you are very cold.
> You centuries pass...
You are always cold, but as your body rots away the pain grows less and less. The sensation of maggots and rot no longer sickens you. Of course, it is debatable whether you truly exist to be sickened, but that is a matter for philosophers and theologians. All you truly know is that every so often She brings someone else to this place, someone warm, and that sometimes She sends you to terrorize some other warm people.


Perhaps someday your bones will finally disintegrate and you will be free. Daemonologists have discussed the question of whether a succubus's slave is freed once his mortal body is nothing but dust, or if he is burned completely by fire, or any number of other possibilities, but they have not come to any certain conclusions. There is hope, but only a very little.


You are less than dead.<|endoftext|>

> You resist
You feel something grazing your neck as she rubs against you. What is it? With all your strength you force yourself to glance down, away from her face and towards the ankh.


The ankh! It fills you with energy and clears your mind, and when you pull it from its chain the succubus hisses and draws back. She is still very beautiful, but you see for the first time how peculiarly inhuman she is. It is hard to describe, but her beauty is not of this world, not of your kind. Still, it takes all your focus to brandish the amulet before her. All at once Dr. Thewliss's ancient face appears in your mind, and you seize on it. Anything to distract from the spirit that stands before you, her eyes brighter than the moon.


Suddenly her face breaks into a smile and your heart nearly stops. "I knew I was not mistaken. You are strong as well as clever, and it pains me that I will not taste you, not tonight. That pitiful bit of iron could never keep me away, but I can tame my hunger for a while."


"Who are you? Why have you appeared to me?" you managed to say.


She cocks her head. "Patience, young one. Go to the College, listen to those professors about how vile and dangerous spirits are, and remember that this night I let you live." She purrs. "Let you live, but marked you as mine."


Leaning forward, her body bending deliciously, she pushes your arm away and plants a kiss upon your cheek before you can react. It burns and then grows cold. The succubus licks her lips and you nearly drop the ankh in spite of all that's happened. Meeting your gaze, she nods, unfurls her vast wings, and sets off into the night.


As she flies away, you hear the sultry voice. "Remember, you belong to me."
> You return to your bed
You walk slowly back to town. The night feels much colder and emptier, though you're sure the temperature hasn't dropped. The familiar surrounding help dull the fear which has taken hold, but it isn't enough to keep you from thinking about what just occured and about the future. There are so many questions, and you can't do anything except wait. Perhaps Dr. Thewliss or another professor might know why the succubus would leave you alive, why she would claim you as her own. Or maybe you'll have to wait until she reappears.


When you reach your room you light a candle and hold it to the mirror. On your cheek is a rose, blood red and shimmering with the flame. The skin is smooth, like some heathenish tattoo, and it feels perfectly normal. You think of your father will say when he sees it and laugh. A little of the terror fades away, and you climb into bed.


Your sleep is dreamless and you wake with the dawn. You dress quickly and swing the satchel with a few essentials onto your back. You'll send someone back in the afternoon for the trunk. Your father's study door is shut, but you can hear his quill scribbling away as you descend the stairs. Mrs. Littlethwaite must still be asleep in her room, you won't wake her. The house is always quiet, but in the early morning the silence is peaceful and pleasant, not the oppressive stillness of your father's disinterested stare.


In a few minutes you are at the College. The great, ceremonial Iron Gates are shut, and you head inside the grounds through the smaller wooden door a few yards down. Dr. Coghill, the bald man you remember from examination day, stands directing new students. His eyes linger for a moment on your cheek but he doesn't break his rhythm. "Proceed to Dodley Hall to formally enroll and register for your lectures. Lodgings in the dormitory may be procured in Cowper Hall. The matriculation ceremony will take place in the Chapel at 5 this evening. Proceed to Dodley Hall to formally enroll..."


You follow his instructions. The grounds are crowded with new students, professors, and clerks, and everyone appears to be in a great hurry. The hall is crowded, though not nearly as much as during the examination. A row of clerks sit in the antechamber and you join the line to speak to one. You see a few others pointing to your face and whispering, but you ignore it. Soon it is your turn, and you give the waiting clerk your name. He prints it on a contract and you sign. It's not very exciting, but that signature makes you an official student and, you suppose, a daemonologist-in-training.


He sends you to another room, and inside you find yet another clerk. "Name?" he asks, and you sign another contract, this one clarifying that your program of study will last three years and will result in the awarding of a Bachelor of Arts degree in Daemonological Studies. He also gives you the list of first year lectures. The curriculum is entirely standardized for new students- Hebrew, mathematics, introductions to practical metaphysics and the history of daemonology, and a Practicum. You ask who teaches the courses; Dr. Thewliss will take your history class, but the rest are all with professors you've never heard of.


Leaving Dodley Hall, you wander around the grounds for a while and end up in the library. Perhaps you can find something to explain what the succubus' mark means and if there's any way to remove it. You can hear shouting through the huge wooden doors, and when you open them you find two professors, one tall and strong and the other stooped over, though he is not old.


"And so I say again, damn you!" yells the stooped one. The door slams shut behind you, and they both stop the argument to stare.
> You bow and try to pass by
The strong one grabs your arm. "Where do you think you're going?" he barks.


You try to explain that you're a new student, but he isn't listening. "No room for your kind here, not if I have anything to say about it. What stupid spirit thought you'd be allowed to wander in unopposed? No matter, we'll soon get to the bottom of this." He pulls you aside, but the stooped professor grabs your other arm surpringly hard.


"You have no right to deny entrance to the library to a student, Bullock. No more than you have the right to steal my property!"


Bullock one lets go and roars "For the last time, fool, I took nothing! I will not permit you to shield this, this slave from my inquiries."


"Inquiries are well and good, Bullock, but even you will admit my expertise is more relevant here than yours." He turns to you. "Go down that corridor and wait in the study at the end. I will join you there in a minute, once I finish with him." You scramble to follow the stooped man's instructions. You hear he and Bullock continue to shout about theft, but the strong man does not stop you from going. You distinctly catch the phrase "stain on the honor of the entire daemonological profession."


The study is small and shabby, with old quills and bits of paper scattered about, but the stooped man joins you almost immediately. He takes a few deep breaths before beginning. "Bullock," he says apologetically, "is a wretched man and a damned thief, but he is the best mathematician in England. He could have expelled you in an instant, so it's luck for you I was there. He may be Vice-Chancellor, but he doesn't have my power and he knows it. Now tell me exactly why you wear a daemonic insignia and which spirit has so marked your face."


Seeing no alternative and hoping for answers, you tell him everything. The dreams, the ankh, the encounter last night. He swears several times but shakes your hand at the end of your story. "To resist a succubus, even with the aid of the ankh, shows no little power. You will do well in my practical metaphysics class." He introduces himself as Dr. Hopkins and then grins. "And it takes a special man to attract that kind of attention from a nocturnae. The ladies of Covingsford had better look out, eh?"


The professor is certainly flippant about everything. "Sir, am I in danger? What does the rose mean?"


"You aren't in any immediate danger, not from the rose at least. It's her insignia, her mark of ownership. Bullock was right that it can mean you've become her slave, but even a minute's conversation proves you aren't possessed or entranced. I'd guess it's meant as a warning to humans and other daemons to let you alone. She's taken a fancy to you for whatever reason and doesn't want anything to harm you. But it won't do anything on it's own, it's just a mark." He laughs. "Rather embarrassing though, for those of us who know the whole story. As for the succubus, I wouldn't worry too much. If you resisted her once, her aura should be easier to fight off in the future. If she wanted you dead or enslaved, she would have done so last night. Spirits, especially succubi, can be strange creatures. There's no telling why she's toying with you like this. Not much point in speculating."


That's rather easy for him to say. You bid the professor good-bye and wander out of the library. Perhaps you ought to research more, but for some reason you don't want any more information about the daemon that's chosen you right now.
> You time passes...
The rest of the day is a blur. With your mind fixed on the events of last night and the succubus, you are only dimly aware of booking lodgings in the dormitory. It is not particularly comfortable, but you will have your own small room, complete with a bed, a desk, and a bookshelf. You pay a clerk a few pennies to fetch your trunk from home, then eat a mediocre meal at another tavern.


The afternoon passes quickly. You meet many new students but none are very memorable. Most, like yourself, are the sons of merchants, a few of the lesser nobility. Everyone's eyes linger on your mark, but thankfully everyone is too nervous and far too English to ask any questions. The matriculation ceremony is long and dull, full of speeches on the honors and solemn responsibilities of students of the College. Glancing down the line of professors, you notice all those you have met before- little Dr. Thewliss, Chancellor Fogg with his long beard, Dr. Coghill and Dr. Ffoukes from your examinations, strong, scowling Dr. Bullock, and the stooped Dr. Hopkins. Hopkins meets your gaze just when you look at him and grins. The speaker, a professor you don't recognize, continues droning on about the sacred duties to the Church and Crown, and Hopkins rolls his eyes.


There are at least twenty more professors, ranging from ancient men even more shrivelled than Thewliss to an enormous, red-faced man who sits, his face expressionless, at the end of the row. Dr. Fogg takes the podium to administer the oath, and the entire class rises to their feet, perhaps two hundred students.


You repeat the words after the Chancellor, and even your anxiety over the succubus can't entirely keep your heart from swelling with pride. 


On my sacred honor, I swear solemn obedience to God, to His Majesty the King, and to the Professors and Governors of this College. I renounce the works of the Devil and of all his host, and I pledge to spend my life in unceasing study, prayer, and struggle against their pernicious war on the human race.


The ceremony finished, you follow the mass of students out of the hall and into the faint evening light. Groups disperse for various inns, and you join one headed for the White Boar. Everyone chatters excitedly about the classes, which begin tomorrow, and soon you hear someone running to catch up. It is Peter, who shakes your hand. "I looked for you all day," he says, "but without luck." His clothes are threadbare, and you realize they are the same he wore weeks ago to the examinations. His face is still sallow, but he is grinning. His eyes flicker to your cheek, and you shrug.


The Boar is full of students, and soon everyone is drunk and merry. The ale helps loosen your tongue, and you tell Peter about your dreams and, eventually, about the visit last night. He whistles. "It's a good thing you're here, I suppose. No better place to hide from a succubus. Still," he says leaning in close, "how did she..."


"Look?" you supply. "Quite lovely, to be honest, and she felt quite lovely too." You must be very drunk indeed to be speaking so brazenly, but what matters is that you no longer feel so scared of the future.
> You classes begin the next day
The first year schedule is almost entirely standardized. Only the Practicum, where you will learn the rudiments of actual combat with daemons, varies; different professors naturally have different approaches to the subject. Today you have Hebrew, history of daemonology with Dr. Thewliss, and mathematics with Dr. Bullock.


Hebrew is not terribly exciting. The professor, Dr. Faber, is a German, and his English is difficult to understand, let alone his Hebrew.


"Ve are here to study ze most ancient and sacred of ze many ancient and sacred tongues of ze vorld. Ze Hebrew language is complex and I haff no doubt zat many of you vill never master it. Nonezeless, it is my duty to instruct you in ze essentials. Now, ze Hebrew alphabet has 22 letters..."


The hour passes slowly. Faber assigns a great deal of reading for the next class, and the students file out groaning. He holds you back and points a bony finger at your cheek. "Zat is ze mark of a succubus, a nocturnae." You nod. "Zat is quite a mark. How is it zat someone so young vould haff such a mark?"


It seems that you will eventually have to tell everyone at the College. You give Faber an abbreviated version of the past few months. He seems satisfied, particularly with the ankh. "Dr. Thewliss is a good man and clever, much more experienced with zese sorts of things zan I. If he believes zat talisman vill protect you, zen he is right. But let me give you some advice, Latimer. You vere right not to trust ze succubus. If she returns, do not listen to her, no matter vat she says. Ze are tricky creatures, daemons and vomen both. A daemon in a voman's form, zat vould be ze trickiest creature of all, eh? So you must be strong. You are a young man, but you must resist ze urges." He looks at you with some pity. Suitable advised, you give an awkard bow and leave the room.


Dr. Thewliss sits in an enormous, plushy armchair at the front of the history of daemonology class. You notice Peter sitting near the window and take a seat beside him. Thewliss begins his lecture, still resting comfortably, without much preamble, launching directly into the earliest known appearances of daemons to the ancient Hebrews, Assyrians, and Chinese. It is not thrilling, but you manage to stay awake.


When the hour ends, you approach the chair. Peter hangs back too. "It seems your succubus has come in the flesh, Latimer," Thewliss chirps. "And you are still alive, and hardly worse for the experience. I congratulate you." You fill him in on the details, and he looks puzzled. "Quite strange. Daemons, especially the nocturnae, play these sorts of games from time to time, but only if their target is someone of particular importance or strength. Not to make any assumptions about you, my boy, but young men are hardly known for their resistance to temptation. It would seem unnecessary for her to take such steps, if your soul was all she was after."


"So you think she's trying to get my defenses down, to trick me somehow? She did leave me alive, and she said the ankh was no protection. Perhaps her motivations..." You trail off, not quite sure how to phrase the idea that's come into your head.


"Are not quite evil? No, unfortunately not. Daemons may be confusing, they may seem ambiguous, they may even seem friendly, but they are evil by nature and they always seek the damnation of mankind. It may be that she has some infernal plan, and she hopes to use you somehow to cause greater wickedness. I cannot say for sure. Still, the fact that you resisted her once is very good to hear. Keep the ankh, keep learning everything you can, and keep me informed."


You and Peter depart, and he tries to distract you with other conversation, but you mind is still on what Faber and Thewliss had to say. It is strange, but you don't feel as frightened as you did before, though both professors warned you about the succubus. They were not there, though, when she actually appeared, when she spared your life. You remember Dr. Hopkins' words "If she wanted you dead or enslaved, she would have done so." The more you think, the more likely that seems. But is her plan to cause some greater evil, or is it something else entirely? You suppose you'll find out eventually.
> You mathematics is next
It is the only class you're dreading, and Dr. Bullock proves your fears right as soon as you walk through the door. "You!" he barks. "You will sit here, where I can keep an eye on you." He points to a desk directly in front of his podium. He glowers at you throughout the lecture, which is a spectacularly confusing introduction to the magical properties of certain trigonometric ratios and equations. Bullock may be a genius, but he must assume his students are too, since he speaks so quickly that you can barely catch the jargon.


The hour finally comes to an end, and after assigning a list of formulas to memorize and several chapters to read, you attempt to leave with everyone else. Bullock stalks to the door and grabs your arm. "Wait." Peter stares at him, his eyes shining with that strange metallic glare you remember from examination day, but you tell him to go.


It takes a moment for the room to clear. Bullock examines the rose on your cheek again and scowls. "I know they are wrong. Hopkins, Thewliss, whoever else you've managed to trick. I know you've fallen under some daemon's spell, and I want you to tell me what kind of spirit it is." You start to protest and he shouts you down. "Silence! Just because you are not a mindless slave does not mean your mind is free from daemonic influence." He takes a few deeps breaths and says, forcing his voice to stay calm, "I cannot help free you if you do not tell me what has happened."


He repeat your story for what feels like the hundredth time, and Bullock finally lets you finish. You do not, of course, mention your suspicion that the succubus might not be entirely evil. "Better than I expected but worse than I hoped. You are clearly enraptured with the nocturae, if not already in league with her. She will twist you around her little finger, use you for some infernal purpose, and then consume you. Pleasurable as that may be, it would mean the damnation of your immortal soul, and I am sworn to prevent that fate from befalling anyone, even impudent young wretches. I urge you, if she comes again, to tell me at once. I am Vice Chancellor, and it is my duty to defend the College from her enemies. If you do not, then I will likely have no choice but to destroy you along side your mistress." 


On that note, he turns and leaves the room, and you follow. You remember that Dr. Hopkins said Bullock had little real power against daemons, no matter how brilliant of a mathematician he might be. Even if you had any inclination to follow his command, what could be do against a succubus?


The next day you have your Practicum and practical metaphysics with Dr. Hopkins. The former class generated a lot of excitement among the new students, but when you arrive it seems no more interesting than the others. The professor, a clean-shaven, middle-aged man called Dr. Young, explains blandly that it will be some months before you will have learned enough to fight even the weakest daemons. Until then, the class will consist of theory.


"McConnell recommends silver against the rakshas of India for, as he says 'they differ not in essential properties from the more familiar malevolent daemons of Europe,' but Reynolds argues for a poultice of wormwood and lavender. Nicholson, of course, disagrees with both and holds that the prayer recorded in  Bede's Historia ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum is effective. Yaxley concurs in part, but adds that a a fox's tail, collected during a new moon, may add to the efficacy..."


You manage to keep mostly accurate notes, but you're pleased when the hour ends and you go to practical metaphysics. Even better, Dr. Young says nothing about your mark. In fact, you aren't sure he even noticed it.


Dr. Hopkins paces back and forth in front of his class. He nods when you and Peter enter. The lecture is fascinating, both because the subject is more interesting than mathematics or Hebrew and because Hopkins, unlike most of the others, seems to care whether his students fall asleep. He tells you that daemons are classified according to which of the deadly sins they make their chief weapon- pride, envy, and so on. He mentions succubi under lust and catches your eye. "Daemons of lust can, of course, make for an entertaining evening, but they rarely make good wives for Christian men. Not that I need to tell some members of our class."


The class chuckles and you join in. It is hard to be too worried, even about a daemon, when someone like Hopkins takes everything so genially. After class you mention your notion to him that the succubus might not be entirely evil. He shrugs. "Perhaps she is and perhaps she isn't. There is still so much we do not know about spirits, and I am more cautious than some of my colleagues in assuming them to be purely vile. I almost wish I was in your shoes, but alas, I am married, and to a good Christian woman." He laughs again.
> You that evening
You talk everything over with Peter in the tavern, where you learn he has found cheaper lodgings than in the dormitory. You are somewhat surprised to find that he agrees that the succubus might not be evil. Or, as he puts it, "she might be evil, but that does not mean that her designs are evil where you are concerned." Still, you come to no certain conclusions, and you only hope that she does not come again until you have learned more.


Of course, such a hope is tempting fate, and that night you are awoken by something like the wind rushing against your window. By the time you blink away your drowsiness, she stands beside the bed, her arm extended. She traces a finger up your leg and side and to your neck, which she caresses for a few moments in silence. You stare at her face, which wears a small smile, and at her body. A sliver of moonlight shines upon it, and you become aware of an ache deep within yourself as your eyes move across her soft curves.


She notices your gaze and her smile widens. You are dimly aware of her teeth, gleaming white and very sharp, and idly you wonder what they would feel like if you kissed her. Her voice cuts through the haze, deep and feminine. "There is an ankh around your neck. Look at it." You obey, of course, and your mind clears enough for you to squeeze the iron. Of course, now that you can think a little more, the fear rushes in.


"I already told you, that little thing would not protect you if I did not wish to spare your life. Pathetic, really, how little your professors care about your wellbeing. That's truly all they gave you, all the help they could spare, even after I claimed you as my own?"


Your voice is weak, but the more you talk the stronger it grows. "They seemed to think my willpower was enough to resist the temptation. I am not afraid," you lie. "I know you do not wish me dead, since I am still alive..."


As you speak, the succubus has been climbing onto your bed. She straddles your waist, just as in the dreams, and rubs her soft body against yours. Her eyes have a strange innocence, or perhaps that is only another tool of seduction. Either way, it is working, and you let out a soft groan. She bends towards you and whispers "Your will is strong, but you are very afraid."

His beard hangs down to his waist, and if were wearing robes instead of an ordinary black suit, he would be the precise image of a medieval wizard.

"Latimer and Aubrey, is it? You have both, it seems, violated one of the most important of the rules which govern this College. At issue is far more than a few punches. At issue is nothing less than the entire daemonological profession and, therefore, the safety of the realm. If we allow these kinds of fights when you are students, that might very easily cause grudges that last well into adulthood. That will not do. The daemonologists of Britain and, indeed, of the world must be united in brotherly affection against all dark forces. I will not permit factionalism or rivalries, let alone all-out brawling." The urge to laugh comes back when you think of Bullock and Hopkins, hardly models of brotherly affection, but again you beat it back and adopt a suitably contrite expression.


Fogg continues. "You two will, therefore, spend a little time working for this institution to instill more respect for our sacred duty. Dr. Coghill is moving into different lodgings and will, I believe, require some assistance. He usually finishes his meal around seven- help him carry his things, arrange his books, dust and scrub the place, and the like. Four or five nights should be sufficient." You nod. It won't be the most pleasant way to spend the next few evenings, but it could be far worse.


Keating was clearly hoping for expulsion, but he seems satisfied that you're both receiving punishment. Hopefully he'll be able to see the parchment with his new black eye.
> The evenings go by quickly...
And so do the weeks. Almost before you realize it, it's November. You watch the crowds of schoolboys and farmers burning Guy Fawkes as one old plowman regales them with the story of how the wicked man tried to blow up Parliament with the help of a terrible daemon. 


Speaking of daemons, you haven't has any more visits from Seria, at least not while you're awake. There have been dreams, however, at least half a dozen, and they aren't exactly like the ones you'd grown used to. She appears, pale and beautiful, dark lips and intoxicating scent, and kisses you, but she pulls you from the bed. Usually you just dance for a while to strange, otherworldly music, your hearts beating together, but once she pulled you close, so close you could feel every inch of her body, and then flew off into the night. The news from America is mostly bad, as General Burgoyne surrendered his entire army to the rebels. British victory is assured eventually, of course, but that eventuality is starting to look quite far away. Opinion on the war is divided among the College's students and professors, with more and more favoring a peace. Some even go as far as to support independence, though mostly because they're sure the Americans will come crawling back in a few years when the Indians or Spanish start invading.


The events in America cannot be doing your family's business interests any good, but you haven't heard a word from your father or brother. You have run into Mrs. Littlethwaite several times, first because of a real coincidence and then because you can tell she's rather lonely. She hints that your father has been even busier than usual and that it would be better not to bother him, not that you're very inclined to stop by the house in any event. Still, it's good to see the old woman every now and then, though the conversations always end with tears on her end and ineffectual attempts to comfort her on yours.


Your classes have become more interesting too. Dr. Bullock has moved from ordinary mathematics to more advanced, daemonological studies. The world has come a long way from the simple summoning circles and pentagrams of the Middle Ages, and he instructs you in the complex geometry and calculus needed to interpret these designs. No daemonologist would, of course, ever need to inscribe his own, but often they can give vital clues as to which kind of daemon has been summoned.


You have finally begun to work with real spirits in Dr. Young's Practicum, though the bulk of your time is still spent on theory. About once a week, though, he brings a tiny glass beaker to class, tighly sealed and full of what looks like fog. "A spirit's essence," he explains, "can be distilled and stored like any other fluid. The experience is not pleasant for the spirit in question, although it is doubtful that a mere mite like this is even aware it's happening." Then he carefully pours the essence into a complex silver container lined with little inscriptions.


The daemon transforms slowly back into its prefered form, in this case a red and orange creature not much bigger than an ant. It scurries around and around the container, but there is no way out. You take turns approaching and dropping various substances in- different herbs and minerals mostly. Once or twice Young tells you to use a certain prayer. The mite flees quickly from whatever you place inside, and sometimes the effect is strong enough to make it burst entirely. It was fascinating the first time, but you can't help wishing you could move on to something a little more advanced.
> You eventually you do.
Dr. Young brings a much larger beaker, still full of what looks like fog, but now the substance is a pale orange color. "This is an imp," he says in the same slightly bored tone he always uses. "It should be more of a challenge. Like all daemons more powerful than the mites, it will speak, though of course its persuasive abilities are rather limited."


The silver container is larger too, and it barely fits on the table at the front of the room. The daemon's preferred form is that of a roughly foot-high person, light orange and covered in a series of bumps and ridges. It is really quite hideous. It says something obscene to the first student to walk up who grimaces and dumps a few fistfuls of juniper incense. This seems to scald the imp, which screeches horribly.


You hang back from the table as the others cluster around, trying to decide what you're going to do. Young isn't the most expressive professor, but he does give some freedom in how you deal with each daemon. You suppose he considers this good practice in applying all the theory to the real world. With the mites, of course, this didn't matter much, since they had hardly any power, but the imp might be different.


Perusing from books from the library for something that might explain Seria's behavior or your new dreams, you came across an interesting prayer recorded by a German monk. He claimed to have found it in an old scroll of Cassiodorus, though part of you doubts the authenticity. Still, the Latin makes sense and fits with some of the other prayers you've read, and it's certainly a step beyond anything you've attempted. As far as you can tell, the prayer is to dispel dormant and lesser daemons. Apparently the monk used it to banish an imp which had become trapped in a grave in his cemetery, rattling bones and general frightening the novices. You're fairly sure it would impress even Young, who gives rare praise to students who manage to surprise him.


On the other hand, you could just drop in a simple wooden amulet. It's quite crude, not much more than a wood chip carved with a few Greek words, but you did make it yourself. It probably wouldn't do much damage to the imp, but Young would likely be pleased that it's your own work, if not overly impressed. There's also little chance of it failing to work altogether, which you can't say for the prayer.
> You prayer
By the time you make it up to the front, the imp is glowering and covered in more ugly welts. Small heaps of herbs and metal ingots lie littered around him. He has some foul language for you, mostly about the mark on your cheek, but you just clear your throat and begin the prayer.


"Haec dicit Dominus Deus exercituum quia locuti..." you chant softly. Young steps closer, clearly intrigued. 


The imp is not pleased. He continues swearing and waves his stubby arms, but he is powerless to hurt you. The prayer is long, but Young doesn't seem to mind that you're reading from your notes.


"Segetes tuas et panem tuum devorabit filios tuos..." It's working. The daemon is jumping up and down now and screaming incoherently. You feel the power surging through you like fire, but you just keep chanting. The imp wriggles like he is being boiled alive, and then his skin seems to melt right off his bones.


The prayer is nearly over, but you know you have to finish it to be sure the imp is really gone. His bones burn up into pale orange cinders and then begin to swirl as if caught in a storm. Then they vanish altogether, just as you say the last "saecula saeculorum." You have never felt so alive and full of energy. How different this is from the hours of study and memorization!


If you were not so focused on the prayer, you might have noticed Dr. Young shouting and waving his arms, trying to get you to stop, or you might have seen the other students backing away slowing as your own skin rippled like water. But it is only once you are done that you notice how your skin has blackened, how the fire inside keeps getting hotter and hotter. You try to sputter some words, and you just barely see Young chanting his own prayer, desperately trying to save you, but you cannot hear the words. Soon it is your flesh which melts from the bones and your bones that disintegrate to dust. They swirl for a moment and then vanish.
