It takes a long while to fall asleep, but eventually you do, and when morning comes you are quite refreshed. It takes a second to remember Seria's visit, and you spend more than a few pleasant minutes remembering how she looked and felt. Then you remember the conversation.


You know you cannot tell Hopkins, Thewliss, or any of the others. But there is one man who you must speak with, and about a subject he has never willingly discussed. Who would have thought that a midnight visit from a daemon would be less terrifying than talking to your father? You try to think of the right words, the right story as you dress and gather you things for the midyear examinations, but nothing sounds convincing, not even to you.


Hebrew is first. You meet up with Peter outside the classroom and have a sudden, vivid memory of your time waiting for the entrance exam to begin. So much has happened since August, and what was once just a figure in your dreams has become quite real. You wish you could tell Peter about Seria's visit, but that would likely be a very bad idea. Even if you hadn't promised not to, you doubt succubi enjoy being the subject of tales by young men.


The written portion is difficult, but not as bad as you had feared. You develop a bit of a headache by the time it's finished, however, and you bungle several sentences during the oral examination. Dr. Faber frowns, but, as he says, "zat vuz still better zan most of zese idlers." You remember his advice about not trusting succubi and feel a little guilty. None of them, though, knows what it's really like to be marked by Seria.


Mathematics is long and tedious, covering everything you've studied in the last few months and a few topics you're sure Bullock never mentioned. He stands at the front of the room throughout the entire exam, scowling when anyone coughs or sneezes. The two hours cannot pass fast enough, and you follow Peter outside into the cold winter afternoon, confident that you did not fail but nothing more. Seria's visit and her words occupied a large portion of your mind and left little space for cosecants and postulants. 


You say goodbye to Peter, his coat tattered and whipping in the chilly breeze. He is off to London and his love, and you begin the walk back to your house. There is no snow, but a thin layer of frost coats the cobbestones and crunches beneath your feet. The mixture of fear and curiosity is familiar by now, though it is curious that it's your father and not Seria causing it.


In a few minutes you are back. No one answers when you ring the brass knocker, so you let yourself in. It is scarcely warmer than outside, and you keep your coat on as you ascend the stairs.
> You climb to the study
The house seems quite empty. You guess that Mrs. Littlethwaite is out buying groceries, but it is curious that Simon is nowhere to be found. Long before you reach your father's study, the familiar scratching grates your ears. Distracted, you open the door without knocking and only realize your mistake too late. Your father glances up and frowns, but he must be too busy to get very angry at the intrusion.


"Why have you returned?" he says, eyes already back on the ledger.


"Because..." you fumble, realizing you never quite decided on a convincing story, and then suddenly it all comes out. "Because a succubus has marked me, and she's done it because of mother." He goes on writing, finishes the sentence, and then looks up again. Only now does he see the rose on your cheek.


"What is the meaning of this? What is this thing?" he thunders, rising to his feet. "This family is respectable, boy, and I will not have us brought into disrepute because you picked up some degenerate fashion from the daemonologists." It seems he was not listening.


Strangely enough, the fact that his eyes are fixed on Seria's mark gives you a kind of confidence. "It wasn't the daemonologists," you say. "It was a succubus. She said it's because of mother, though I don't know much more than that. I need to learn about her. What she was like, where she came from." You pause a moment. "Everything you never said."


Suddenly your father darts forward, and for a moment you think he is going to strike you. His great hand grabs your shoulder, and before you can fully process what's happened, he sinks to his knee. "Forgive me, Amelia," he cries, "forgive me for everything."


It is more emotion than you have witnessed from him in your entire life. Unsure, you hold his arm, and he keeps gripping you shoulder as if he were drowning. But he is not looking at you anymore, now he is gazing up at your mother's portrait. She smiles serenely down at both of you, looking for all the world like a perfectly ordinary woman.


Your father pulls his hand from your shoulder and begins unbuttoning his waistcoat. Alarmed, you try to stop him, but he swats you away. Soon it is off, and then comes the shirt. You feel as though you're in a bad dream. Business must be bad, must be worse than you had imagined. Your father has gone mad. He stands, unsteadily, and points a quivering hand at his side.


There, though it is surrounded by coarse black and gray hair, you see a small golden harp. It looks like a tiny tattoo, and with a shock you recognize it as akin to your own rose. He grabs your shoulder again and begins the tale, slowly at first, but once it has started it is like a great flood.


"Amelia was an angel," he begins, and when you don't understand he says it again. "I knew she was lovely, but I didn't realize her true nature until after the wedding." That was when she marked him. She was loving and kind, precisely as you would imagine an angel to be. He says he still does not know why she married him, and he talks for a while about what a miserable man he is and how he never deserved her. Your father talks for a long time about her laugh and the way she walked, and all the while he continues staring up at her portrait. He stops speaking, and you get the impression he is trying to find the words for the next part of his story.


"She could not have children. She told me that it might be very difficult, a while after the wedding, but I didn't care, not for a few years. I was sure we would have a boy soon. But when it didn't happen I...I...you must understand, I was in London a great deal, away from your mother, and I was weak, and there are many women in the city, and..." His voice trails off into sobbing. You, of course, have no words.


Eventually he recovers enough to whisper that Charles is only your half brother, his mother a Lambeth whore. "But she forgave me, that was the hardest thing. She wept and prayed, and then she forgave what I had done. The evil I had done, and to a woman so innocent, so kind! She cared for Charles like he was her own. Her prayers must have been answered, too, because a few years later you were born, and..."


He stops, and outside the study you can hear a sound like the rushing of the wind.
> The door slams open
Seria's eyes are like fire and her face is utterly terrifying. Without a word she strides into the study, grabs you by the throat, and throws you against the wall. You land with a crash and look up just in time to watch her slap your father, hard enough to send him careening into his own desk, which snaps under the weight and sends a flurry of books, papers, and the scale to the floor.


"You were her husband," she says coldly, and her voice makes you want to run and hide under what remains of the desk.


Your father stares up at Seria, his cut and bruised. "Amelia's husband," he croaks out.


Seria kicks him in the stomach and he collapses entirely. She turns to you. "Why did you tell him? Why did you disobey me?"


You stand slowly. "I needed to know about my mother. I needed to know why you chose me." You take a few unsteady steps towards the succubus, praying that you haven't gone mad and that you clothes have not damaged the pattern. Seria is breathing hard, fists clenched. You know that she is stronger by far than you, that one flick of those tiny wrists would probably mean your death.


"It was not your place to disobey me, you miserable, oh!" You cut off her words with a kiss. She resists for the smallest moment and then grabs your coat, pulling you close. You reach around to caress her and spend a few terrifying, intensely pleasurable minutes exploring her lips and body. You're fairly confident that, between last night and now, you know every inch, but you hope you get the chance to check again.


When you finally break apart, Seria's eyes are back to their usually dark beauty. She gazes at you, her lips still in a shocked little o, and then reaches out to touch the rose on your cheek. "You are mine," she murmurs, "but I am yours, all yours." She seems ready to make love right there, but you notice your father groaning on the floor. She licks her lips. "I suppose I can wait."


You pull him from the rubble and into the center of the room, and after a while he revives enough to cry. It is a startling sight, but by now you've seen so many that it hardly seems unusual. Seria gives him another kick, this one a little gentler. "Will you finish the story or shall I?"


He groans and whispers that it must be him. "You were born. Such a beautiful boy. Amelia was so happy. So happy for those first few days." He coughs, and then a spasm seems to go through his body. "And then...and then..." He breaks off into sobbing once more. Seria looks at him coldly. When he gives no sign of continuing, she turns to face you.
> You say "And then they murdered her."
You stare into her dark eyes. The words do not make sense. No one murdered your mother, she died from eclampsia right after you were born. If anyone killed her it was you, but you know that kind of talk is only foolishness. Seria stares back for a long time and then, in a low voice, adds "the daemonologists."


Your father gives a great cry, but you do not hear him. The daemonologists could not have killed your mother, they are sworn only to fight against evil spirits, against daemons, never against angels. It is impossible, absurd, unthinkable.


"No," you say, shaking a little, "it cannot be. Not the daemonologists I know."


Seria grabs your hand and holds it, tight. "The daemonologists who said I must be a monster but who gave you nothing but bits of metal to defend against me? Who fight among themselves and care more about prestige and little quarrels than with protecting the innocent? They care only for status, only for prestige and power, and your mother had plenty of power."


Her words are like knives, but as you gaze into her eyes they make terrible sense. You do not want to believe them, you want her to be quiet, but she continues. "They must have sensed her aura for a long time, living so close to the College, even if she tried to hide. But the birth was difficult, and so, when you were only a few days old and healthy, she ventured out into the countryside for a walk, perhaps to clear her thoughts, to enjoy the sunshine and the grass. I imagine she hated to stay cooped up indoors. That's where they caught her, and that's where they killed her, leaving you, just born and already all alone in the world, to fend for yourself."


Your father struggles to his knees and clutches at your leg. "She was killed, but you were not alone, my son. You had a father..." Seria catches him with another slap, and he falls to his back. You share in her surge of anger. You had no father, or as good as none. When did he care, when did he speak to you or tell you anything about your mother or your heritage? How can he try to claim innocence when he chose some whore over his own wife?


But your father will not stay down. "She was killed, my angel was murdered, but..." With a sudden roar, Seria slams her elbow into his neck. He gives a horrible gasp and lies still for a few seconds, but somehow rises again, looking nearly dead. You cannot listen to any more of his words. He would not give them until Seria came, why should he have the chance to say them now?
> You strike him down
He has no right to speak, not after everything he's done. You aim a quick kick to his head, and then another and another. Every unsaid word, every disdainful look you can remember is avenged with those kicks, and finally your father falls down and does not rise, his face barely recognizable.


Seria's eyes glitter like black pearls, and she grabs your shirt. She pulls you close, her voice deep and husky.  "Take me. Now."


You obey, and soon you both have shed your clothes. Bodies locked together, you feel her, hot all over, and it makes you forget everything you have learned these past minutes. Those darks lips are everywhere, and everywhere they touch burns with a cruel and insatiable fire. Your lusts burn together, and it seems nothing could ever quench them.


You last longer than the night before, and when you finish she purrs contentedly. Lazily playing with the strands of her hair, your eyes drift to your father. He has not moved. Seria glances at him too and states, quite matter-of-factly, "He is dead."


You nod. You had not intended to kill him, but now that it is done you do not feel guilty. He was an adulterer, and against your mother. He let you think her death was your fault, let you join the College, the ones who killed her. His sin probably drove her out of the house, drove her to her death. You can feel her eyes watching from her portrait and are filled with a sudden rage. Death is too good for the fat old bastard, and with a great roar you begin to pummel his lifeless body.


Seria lets you go for a minutes and then grabs your arm. "Enough. Save your hatred and wrath, we will need them both. This man disgraced your mother and mistreated you, but the ones who killed her live and breath. I doubt they even remember the deed." You nod, fully intent on marching straight to the College to slaughter every daemonologist you can find, but she keeps speaking. "No, young one, you are not strong enough, not yet. Your mother's blood gives you great power, but it will only bear fruit in time. If you strike now it will be in vain, and the wretches will add another of our family to their list of murders."


"Our family?"


She smiles. "Yes, cousin. Amelia was my aunt, my mother's sister. The divide between angels and daemons is not sharp. What does it matter that my mother chose the darkness and yours the light? Blood is what matters, and revenge against those who spilled it." Suddenly she bends forward and bites your ear, just enough to get a few drops of the stuff. It is barely visible on her lips, but you could hardly miss the way she licks it off.


"Return to the College. Continue with your studies until everything is ready. Rest assured, soon it will all be in place, and together we will avenge your mother. I will visit often, for I know I will not be able to resist tasting you again. You are mine, and I am yours." Seria gives you one last kiss, and then she is gone.
> You time passes...
Mrs. Littlethwaite returns a few hours after Seria's departure, wizened arms laden with food from the market. When she sees your father's body, you do not even have to lie. "Business was not going well, and I feared his debts had grown, feared he had gone to thugs and criminals. What is to become of us now?" she wails. You do your best to comfort her, a little shaken that his death would cause such a reaction, but you know you had no choice.


Charles returns a few days later to take possession of the house and full control of the Latimer business interests. If he is at all affected, he does not show it. His analysis is sober. "Father made a string of bad investments, and then some ill fortune compounded the problems. He was too stubborn to listen to my advice, and I suppose he thought he could handle his creditors. But what's done is done. With luck they'll catch the killers, and in time I will rebuild our family's reputation and wealth." You also learn that your father gave Simon his notice a week before, another casulty of his bad investments. Charles assures you that your tuition will still be paid. "We are not so desparate as that."


Christmas comes and goes, a somewhat solemn holiday. Charles returns to London most of the time, so you are left alone with Mrs. Littlethwaite. You speak of little things, but you no longer have any interest in discussing your studies at the College, and the sight of your father's body seems to have rattled her quite severely. You spend most of your time in your room reading, or walking alone around the town and countryside in the crisp air and snow. You've taken to picturing your mother's death, surrounded by a gang of daemonologists, probably the same professors you've trusted all this time. Sometimes you are not certain you'll be able to wait for Seria's plan,  the anger is too strong. Despite her promise, she does not return. You can be patient, however, since her absence means your revenge will come quicker.


Come January you return to your lodgings in the College dormitory. Classes are much more interesting, now that you've learned the theory and the basics, though Hebrew is still a dull slog. Peter is a day late, and when he returns he is thrilled to tell you that he and Lizzy are engaged. "It will have to be a long engagement," he admits, "but her father is no longer opposed. No more secret meetings, unless perhaps I need a strong distraction form my studies." You are pleased for your friend, the first real happiness you have felt in a while, aside from picturing the moment when you strike down your mother's killers.


Those fantasies have made it more and more difficult not to draw attention during your classes. You want to interrupt Faber and Thewliss and Hopkins and ask them why they cornered your mother, or at least why they sheltered her killers. You realize that most of them probably had nothing to do with the foul deed, but you have little doubt that they've done similar things in the past. The illusion is shattered, they are nothing but self-serving, greedy wretches. You've even begun to dislike your fellow students, all except Peter. How can they sit in class, day after day, and learn to fight daemons, when the ones they should be fighting are standing right in front of them?
> One day in your Practicum
Dr. Young is lecturing on the power of daemons over certain diseases and ailments. It is dull stuff, and with the hour almost gone it nearly lulls you to sleep, but your ears prick up when he mentions childbirth. "The common natural dangers can also be excacerbated by daemons, especially daemons of lust. Succubi, for instance, favor eclampsia, and they relish the chance to induce that terrible disease in a woman. Thompson reports the case of a particularly devilish daemon in Edinburgh who infected no less than 40 women. Saint Bonaventure describes something similar, and he advised a mixture of lily and hawthorne bark as an effectual remedy. Nicholson, whose biases against hawthorne are well-known, reccommends the creation of an amulet, made of brass and inscribed with the Magnificat. Georg Strutt, the great Prussian of our own day, disagrees, since he considers..."


Eclampsia. Your father always claimed your mother died from eclampsia. It was nearly the only thing he said about her, and now you've learned it can be caused by succubi. At least, you think bitterly, Young claims it can be caused by succubi. You wonder if your father knew that, if he chose that lie so that, one day, you might blame a daemon instead of the daemonologists.


The rage grows strong and hot inside you. You can see Young but you don't hear his words. He is middle-aged, just old enough, perhaps, to have been among your mother's killers. How dare he stand and talk about saving women from harm, how dare he be so calm and expressionless. You realize that this anger cannot be controlled. You need to do something, now, or you'll explode. Thankfully the class is ending. You only need to wait a minute more, and with all your strength you focus on the paper in front of you. You count the words and then the letters you've written there. The full heat of your rage dissapates, and soon Young dismisses the class. The other students file out slowly and you bring up the rear.


As you near the door, Dr. Young turns and nods. The anger changes, turns cold and and calculating. There is no one else in the room, he suspects nothing. Now is your chance to strike, to pay them back for what they did to your mother.
> You attack
You step closer and clench your hand into a fist. Young does not notice. Suddenly you get the urge to speak, to tell him that you've seen through the facade. "Sir," you ask, "I was wondering if angels ever cause these kinds of ailments."


Young shakes his head. "Of course not, Latimer. They are by nature good and pure, the very opposite of the daemons. They assist in childbirth to protect both mother and baby."


"As I thought. But then, why would a pack of daemonologists surround an angel and murder her?"


He looks at you, confused, and opens his mouth to respond, but it is too late. You land a punch right on his jaw, and he falls to the ground. He manages to splutter a few words, though you do not understand the language, and then you strangle him. He claws at your hands, but your grip is strong. Slowly you feel the life ebbing away. You think he is dead, and you want to dance in triumph.


"I knew it, I knew it all along!" you hear behind you. You turn to find Dr. Bullock, his face blazing with an awful light, but by the time you release Young his fist has already crashed into the side of your head. You stagger away. Bullock shouts something in Latin, and what feels like a tiny hurricane slams into your body. You black out for a moment and fall, and by sheer luck knock your skull against a chair at the worst angle. You just barely see Bullock running towards you, cursing that he won't get the chance to find out what daemon you serve, and then your vision fades forever.


"I...mother, I tried," you murmur with your last breath. Hopefully Seria's plan will still work without you, because you could only kill one of the murderers. Still, you die happy, knowing you did what you could to avenge your mother's death.<|endoftext|>

> You leave
You are quite tempted, but you know it isn't worth it. Much better to wait for Seria and get revenge on all of them at once. Besides, Young has a reputation for power, boring as he is. Who knows how he'd defend himself?


You follow the others out and meet up with Peter at the White Boar. After a few ales, some roast chicken, and conversation with your friend, you leave feeling quite happy. It's pleasant to have some distractions from the awful knowledge you gained over Christmas.


Weeks pass, and you are surprised and pleased to learn that your practical metaphysics class will now cover basic magic. Hopkins stresses the dangers of this sort of thing, but that doesn't do much to dampen the enthusiasm. "You'd better be sure your Latin pronounciation is good, or you'll end up looking worse than me," he cautions. Of all your professors, he is the hardest to hate. His good humor is infectious, and you remember that, unlike the others, he did not assume Seria must be evil.


Working real magic is complex, and it is only after a week of study that you get the chance to attempt it. You've used the occaisional prayer in your Practicum, of course, but this is different. Hopkins explains how, eventually, some of you will be able to use magic to make light and fire, to calm storms, and, most important, to defend against daemons. You chuckle a little at the last one, since you plan to use it against the daemonologists. The first task is simple, the prayer short. You are each given a small red candle and told to light it. Everyone chants the same words, but the results are quite different. For most, nothing at all happens. A few, including Peter, produce a bit of smoke, but yours bursts immediately into a plume of fire nearly a foot high, burning your fingers a little.


Hopkins is thrilled. "Marvelous work, my boy, marvelous!" You can't help but feel that the praise is over-generous, as you're sure your ability just comes from your mother's blood and not from any work on your part. Still, it's exciting. If you could do this on your first try, how powerful will you be when your angelic heritage is fully manifest?


Peter is a good sport and congratulates you, and you realize this is the first time you've really excelled. It's annoying that the next month will be spent on similar tasks, trifles like filling a cup with water or making a bell ring without touching it. Still, you can be patient, though you decide you'll head to the library to find some more books of magic. There's no reason you can't do a little advanced work now, just to see how far your power stretches.


It takes a while for you to find the right section in the cavernous building, but you are well-rewarded once you do. Spoiled for choice, you spend nearly an hour pulling books from the shelves at random, fascinated by everything you could try. You end up bringing half a dozen to your room, where they join the more mundane works on mathematics, Hebrew, and the like.


You flip through the pages until something catches your eye. It's a prayer to make inscriptions permanent, recorded by a monk named Clement in Britanny in the 13th century. Apparently he used it to keep his most prized manuscripts pristine, which makes you laugh a bit. You take a piece of charcoal and fix the design on your chest, making sure it is exactly as it should be. Then you begin the prayer. "Domine Deus..."
> You that night
Seria pays you a visit. She notices the magic immediately, though she seems happier that you had the power to do it than at the spell itself. "Your strength grows, young one, and it will grow stronger by far. It is intoxicating. Bind me, take me, ravish me!" Her voice changes to a moan and she tears away her thin robe. You are more than happy to obey, though you don't require any magic to throw her onto the bed, nor to ravish her. You get little sleep.


After a few hours Seria decides she's in the mood for conversation, though her hand is still working lazily below your blanket. "They are almost convinced. It will only be a little longer now, and then we can strike."


"They?" you ask.


"My allies, powerful spirits. Each has a grudge against one of the Covingsford daemonologists, not that they need much excuse. Now that your angelic blood has begun to awaken, they will be eager to begin. I can afford to come back to you, I need to come back, perhaps even every night."


Her words would have shocked you before, but you shed any real animosity towards daemons once you learned of the hypocrisy of the daemonologists. "Very well. I still do not know what use I will be. I have some power, I realize, but the professors must have more."


Seria laughs and gives you a kiss. "Your modesty is adorable, but I want you to know your true power. None of those professors will have even half your strength, not once your mother's blood shines forth. Even now you are stronger than many of them. They are learned about some things, perhaps- dead languages and moldy books, but we are speaking of raw power. Of strength. Of will. Of domination. Of hunger." She gives another moan and you decide that the time to talk is over. There is little doubt that you both have a great deal of hunger, and you do your best to satisfy it in the hours until dawn.


She departs just before sunrise, promising to return when it is dark. You say goodbye with one last squeeze and she laughs again. You laugh too and think about Peter and his Lizzy. Love comes, it seems, in different forms.


The day passes quickly, your mind quite unable to focus on Hebrew grammar and the like. As soon as your classes end you hurry back to your room to practice more magic, and soon you can make small objects levitate, shatter glass with a flick of your finger, and produce food from thin air. This last one only adds to your anger at the daemonologists- how can they let men starve when creating food is so simple?


Before you know it, Seria is back, and you spend this night in much the same way as you spend the previous one. If this is how your life will be, days spent gaining power and nights spent in ecstasy, you could not be more pleased.
> You time passes...
Life has never been so good. Each day you work greater and greater magic, though still in the confines of your room, and nearly every night Seria comes to reward you. You feel guilty about it, sometimes, having so much pleasure when your mother's killers still breathe, but you know that you must have patience. Your anger no longer burns quite so hot against the professors, perhaps because you release a lot of energy during the night. The other daemons are almost convinced, and you are almost strong enough to summon them.


This is, you learn, your essential role in Seria's plan, and so you've been studying the basics of summoning in secret. Each of the spirits was banished long ago by one of the professors, which explains their willingness to risk destruction for revenge. It takes someone with more power than the banisher to reverse that kind of magic, and she believes you are close. Thankfully, one of the spells you've come across lets you dimly sense another's strength, though it is not exact. Chancellor Fogg is the only daemonologist who could certainly best you. Dr. Hopkins is powerful too, as are a few professors you don't know well. The others are pitiable weak, substituting useless knowledge for their lack of natural strength.


Speaking of Hopkins, he and Peter are the only people that keep you from complete allegiance to Seria's plan. You don't care at all if innocent professors are slaughtered. They sheltered your mother's killers and probably did similar things themselves. You don't even mind if some students are killed, though Seria assures you that your allies have no interest in doing so unless the students try to resist their attack. You hope Peter will not, but you aren't sure how to warn him without raising his suspicions. Hopkins is the one professor whom you wish did not have to die. He has always been kind to you, and he doesn't seem to have the same attitude as the others, the attitude that you now find so hypocritical. If he has to die, so be it, but you'd like to find a way to spare him.


Thewliss is in a way the worst of them all. You find it hard to believe you once respected him and felt grateful when he gave you the ankh. His lectures are full of what you now recognize as sanctimonious nonsense. To hear him tell it, spirits have been oppressing mankind since the dawn of time, and daemonologists have defended them. You've done a little reading of your own and know now that the truth is very different. Your mother's murder is only one of many through the ages, innocents killed by overzealous daemonologists. Soon she will be avenged, and all the others too.


Still, the matter of Peter and Dr. Hopkins preys on your mind. There must be some way to explain what's happening, some way to get them to see reason. You need to act quickly, however, since Seria's been hinting that the attack will come quite soon. Last night she told you she won't be back for a few days. Apparently there's one more spirit to convince, a mighty raksha in Bengal who Bullock encountered during a brief job protecting the East India Company. This should give you a chance to warn them, but who should you speak to first?
> You peter
Hopkins is strong and experienced and might be able to fend for himself. In any case, you can always warn him after you speak with Peter. As you roam around the grounds, however, you cannot seem to find your friend anywhere.


He is not in your classes the next day, and when you stop by the White Boar, the innkeeper informs you he's gone back to London. "His love's sick," he says, polishing a glass. "Probably nothing serious, but these young pups hate to leave their ladies alone." You nod, knowing very well how hard it is when Seria leaves each morning.


You wonder how long Peter will stay in London. Perhaps he'll even miss the entire attack. You go about your business for the next couple days, planning to speak with Hopkins after practical metaphysics, but his comment during the lecture catches you off guard. He's discussing spells to keep your mind clear. "Now, these aren't just to give you dullards a bit of help during examinations. They're quite useful against daemons, since the smarter ones will always try to manipulate you. Most of you probably wouldn't even realize you're being manipulated, but spells like these will at least give you a chance at resisting their honeyed words."


Hopkins is a good man, and you still don't wish him any harm, but comments like that remind you that he isn't fundamentally different from the other professors. Daemons are the enemy, they want to manipulate and devour you, and the whole rest of it. He likely wouldn't be happy that you're trusting Seria, likely wouldn't understand that there's a difference between manipulation and love. He will have to take care of himself when the time comes, and you hope he does so effectively.


Two more days pass without Peter returning. Your magic is stronger than ever, as you learn during a walk in the countryside when you send a sudden bolt of lightening from the clear sky. You are thrilled, however, when Seria surprises you while you're asleep, waking you up in a very interesting way. You spend a while on pleasure and then turn to business, though you can't resist playing with her body a little while you talk.


"Everything is in place. We need to strike now," she says, her suddenly serious tone quite a change from her earlier moans. 


"Tonight?"


"Yes. Our allies are not as patient as you and I, and if you don't summon them now they may move on to easier prey."


You consider it. "The Chancellor is still stronger than me, though I'm probably a match for all the others."


"He won't be a problem. The other daemons might be able to kill him, and if not, the excitement of the battle should fully awaken your heritage. Then you will be unstoppable." She gives you a deep kiss, and you spend another couple minutes distracting yourselves from the work ahead.


Finally she pulls away and grabs a piece of charcoal. It is time. You take the charcoal and begin to draw the summoning circle. You think of Bullock and his expression if he knew how you were using the knowledge he taught you. You have to stifle a laugh when you realize he will know soon enough.
> The summoning
You have come across many different summoning procedures during your research, though you've decided to use a simple one originally created by the Cathars. Seria stands on the other side of the circle, ready to tell you the different names of each daemon you will call up. You have the incantation written somewhere among your notes, but you're confident you know it by heart.


"Quid sum miser tunc dicturus, quem patronum rogatorus, cum vix sit securus..." you intone. The charcoal lines begin to glow with dim blue light. "Ingemisco tamquam reus, culpa rubet vultus meus supplicanti parce..."


Seria's eyes are locked on your own, and you stare right back. You are hers, and she is yours. Together you will do what should have been done years ago. For the first time you let yourself think of the future, after the revenge has been won. You cannot imagine a better life than one spent with Seria by your side, and your angelic heritage should, once it fully awakens, make it a very long life indeed.


"Propet hoc lugebit terra et infirmabitur omnis qui daemoniat..." Seria has a hungry look on her pale face, and the circle's lines are now very bright. It is time to call the first spirit.


"Lignor," she murmurs, and you repeat the name. The air inside the circle ripples like water, and slowly something like pale green fog begins to swirl. You continue chanting as it coalesces, growing larger and larger, and then all at once the daemon is fully there. He is a minotaur, nearly seven feet tall with curling horns and broken teeth. He bows slowly and steps outside the circle.


"Propet hoc lugebit terra et infirmabitur omnis qui daemoniat..." you chant methodically once more. This time the daemon is Nephilaxet, who would look like a perfectly ordinary merchant if it were not for the two long, curving scars that stretch from each side of his mouth to his ears. Then he smiles wide, and you notice that his gums are bright red. He too bows and takes his place beside Seria and Lignor.


Then Jarobaal, who has the head of a great viper, Semkhapu the sphinx, and Spulliso, who has no face at all, only a terrible blankness, deathly white, where eyes and the rest should be. You soon lose track of the names and each one's particular monstrous appearance, though a few, like Yfrigge, who looks for all the world like a timid, frightened six year old girl, manage to stand out. Each one bows and joins the others, watching as you call forth more and more. Last of all is Anumun, the raksha with a grudge against Dr. Bullock. He is covered from head to foot with a tiger's fur and stripes, and when he bows, you see that his tail is a cobra.


Then it is done. Seria nods, and you mutter the final words of the summoning. Your eyes flicker from one daemon to the next. The room is quite full, and you guess that there are at least two dozen spirits inside. Each one is staring back, and it is with a jolt that you realize that you, not Seria, are their leader.
> You speak
Though you are not entirely sure where the words are coming from. "Tonight we will gain revenge on the daemonologists. All my life I hoped to be one of them. All my life was a lie. They murdered my mother, a powerful spirit, and they have wronged each of you too. Tonight we will make them pay for what they have done."


It is a simple enough speech, but it seems to inspire the daemons. "We will follow you, great spellcaster," Jarobaal says. It is disconcerting to hear good English come from a snake's head, but you just nod. The others give their assent too, and Seria comes to your side.


Her voice is forceful and her face wears a sneer as she speaks of the enemy. "They are asleep in their beds, so we will have little trouble with the first few. But then they will raise the alarm, and we will have a true battle on our hands." She squeezes your hand. "The students are not to be touched, though if they attack you may of course slaughter them. But it would be better to put the fear of daemons into their veins, to teach them never to oppose us."


Most of the daemons have particular targets in mind, the professors who banished them or stole their prey, but splitting up to take each one individually is too risky. Instead, Seria divides your army into three groups, who will work their way through the professors. She will fight by your side, of course, as will Nephilaxet, Semkhapu, Spulliso, Yfrigge, and a few others. Dr. Fogg is the final target, since you should grow in power as the battle progresses and your angelic blood fully awakens.


You whisper a quick spell, and your window vanishes without a sound. The daemons leap out at once and you follow, commanding the wind to soften your landing. You lead Seria and the others to Dr. Coghill's house, the same place you once spent your evenings cleaning. He has little power and should make a good first victim. Something to whet your appetite.


His door is protected by some carved glyphs, and you stop to examine them. Coghill is an expert in these sorts of enchanted inscriptions, and, weak or not, he likely put a good deal of thought into them. After a minute you're fairly confident you understand how they work, though your Hebrew isn't advanced enough to grasp the details. You know a few unbinding spells that could probably let you in, especially given your advantage over Coghill in raw power, but you've certainly never tried them against anything like this.


You musings are interrupted by a growl from Semkhapu. "I could easily smash this down." You glance at her huge paws and muscular body, and you have to admit she could be right.
> You magic
"No," answer, "Coghill is weak and stupid. This should only take a moment. Dilexerunt adferre ignominiam..."


The spell is short, and when you finish, the inscriptions have completely faded away. You wonder how long Coghill pored over his defenses and chuckle. The door is not even locked, and you walk right in, the daemons right behind.


Strangely, you seem to be right back where you just were. The door still stands directly in front, still without any inscriptions, but you're back outside. You open it and go through again, but once again the only place you get is where you've already been. This is curious magic, and you start scanning the front of the house for any other glyphs and tell the others to do the same.


You find it almost immediately, a tiny row of characters scratched into the side of the doorframe. These are in a script you've never seen before, and while you're puzzling over them you hear someone nearby give a great bellow.


Nephilaxet has taken a silver axe to the face, and you watch with growing anger as his skin melts off. The fool must have tripped another of Coghill's defenses. "No one move a muscle," you order, but it is too late. Spulliso leans against the house, and you see another inscription, this one scrawled by a window, glow blue for a moment. Then he lights up like a torch, and in a few seconds the smooth-faced daemon is reduced to a pile of cinders. 


"Stand still, damn you all," you shout. You know you can figure this out, you just need a little time to think. The man must have covered his home in wards, paranoid bastard. There could be hundreds of them, all alert to any magical activity. A general unbinding spell is your best chance, and you'll just have to hope your power is great enough to overcome them all at once.


You start the chant, but, as it turns out, the spell you've chosen is the trigger for another one of Coghill's wards. You feel something like a tickle along your legs, and when you look down you see that the withered grass beneath your feet has burst into life. You writhe away and try to think of some magic to escape, but the tendrils grow higher and higher. Your daemons, meanwhile, have fled, judging that the risk here is not worth the reward. Seria is the only one to stay, and she claws at the vines as they slowly engulf you.


"No!" she shouts, baring her teeth. "You are mine, and I am yours, and we will slaughter all our enemies!"


Her voice grows more and more muffled until at last you can hear nothing at all. Then the tendrils begin to squeeze tighter, and within a few minutes you are dead. Before the pressure becomes too great, your last thought is to hope that Seria escaped from this vile place. You picture her body, soft and perfect, and slip into death.<|endoftext|>

> You force
Strange as it might seem, the sphinx has a point. You still aren't entirely sure about these inscriptions, but daemonologists have a tendency to focus on the magical. You wouldn't be at all surprised if the door is unprotected against mere physical force. In fact, you doubt it's even locked.


You nod, and Semkhapu backs up to charge. Her body is power, and when she springs against the door it crumples without any trouble. There is a crash, of course, but it was probably too much to hope to catch Coghill asleep.


You lead the way up the stairs, remembering the hours spent cleaning them from the previous owners' grime. Coghill was something of a perfectionist, which no doubt served him well in inscribing those runes. His bedroom door has similar writing, which you deal with in the same way. The entire daemonic horde rushes in after Semkhapu, and you encircle Dr. Coghill, still wearing his dressing gown and nightcap. He is covered in dust and bits of debris from the door, but he recognizes you at once and grimaces.


He is standing in some kind of protective circle, its intricate lines weaving in and out like the Celtic pattern on your chest. You see tiny runes carved there too. Probably best not to attempt a direct attack, though in a way the circle is a blessing. He has no chance of escape, and it gives you plenty of time to destroy him. You begin chanting a simple spell, one that should smudge the pattern and let the daemons in to devour him. Meanwhile, Seria and the others explore every inch of the design for weaknesses and send spurts of fire and dark energy. Coghill is clever, however, and his circle is safe.


At least, it is until you complete the incantation. You finish, and he stares, wondering what exactly you meant to accomplish. Seria understands at once, though, and slips through the tiny break you've made in his otherwise perfect design.


Coghill gives a strangled yelp and tries to run, but she is quicker. She takes his hand in her own and he stops, gazing into her eyes. You watch his resistance melt away, and he bends down for her kiss.


His lips are only an inch form hers when you send a bolt of lightening to finish him off. Seria turns to you and laughs. She darts back to give you a quick kiss before the band of daemons sets off for their next target. "Don't tell me you were jealous of him?" she purrs, twisting her body away from yours. You reach out a hand and pull her back by her lovely neck. She lets out a little whimper.


"You are mine, and I am yours," you growl.
> You to Faber
Your Hebrew professor is the next to die, and you lead your army out of Coghill's house and through the grounds. A professor whose name you don't know tries to stop you, but he's rather foolish and must not notice the daemons right on your heels. Spulliso takes care of him, snapping his neck before he has any idea what's going on. "My fingernail," he says, sounding mildly annoyed. "My fingernail broke on that man's neck."


As luck would have it, you run into Faber, who must have detected the disturbances and all the spiritual auras. It seems you've lost the element of surprise, though that was bound to happen eventually. Slightly complicating things is the fact that he's with Dr. Young and two other professosr, one of whom is among the strongest at the College. You see that the man's face is bleeding, but it doesn't seem to be slowing him down. "Traitor and fiend!" Faber shouts, but then your daemons are on him and it's all he can do to say alive.


You watch with anger as Young throws a silver knife at Semkhapu, catching her on the leg. She howls in pain, but then the other professor begins yelling in Latin. You turn to face him and mutter a spell of your own. You can feel your aura fighting with his as you chant. He is strong, stronger than you thought. This will not be an easy fight.


Out of the corner of your eye you watch the battle, though you can only get quick glimpses before you need to turn back to your enemy. You see Faber finish off Semkhapu with some amulet, but when you glance back Faber's own throat has been opened by Nephilaxet, who laps at the blood hungrily. Meanwhile Dr. Young is a blur, casting short spells and throwing daggers and bundles of herbs. The man may not have much magical ability, but he is keeping your daemons occupied. The other professor is holding his own too, though he doesn't seem as capable as his companions.


Your enemy reaches into his pocket, still chanting, and pulls out a dagger of his own. He does not have Young's skill, though, and you easily dodge the blade. He is out of breath, which might mean that you are close, but then again you are too. Why won't your angelic blood awaken? Or has it already, and you are simply not as powerful as Seria had thought.


You glimpse her out of the corner of your eye, see Young attack her with a flurry of blows, his silver knife making a dozen cuts all along her arms and side. She fights back, but you notice that he's strew the ground with herbs. She can barely walk without terrible pain, and neither can the other daemons. Seria falls to the ground, and he raises the blade for the final blow.
> You save Seria
She cannot die. In the moment you forget about your mother and the plan, forget about everything except the woman you love. You redirect your chant to Young, guessing that he will have no defenses at all for your spell. You catch him completely by surprise and he drops the knife, howling with the pain you've inflicted.


Hoping that at least bought some time, you turn your attentions back to your main enemy. He is still chanting, and you keep up your own spell. The balance has gone against you, however, and now you're only just managing to stay alive. Glancing over, you see Yfrigge walk calmly up to Young, reach out her hand, and dig his heart straight out from his chest. The sight gives you a little hope, but your battle of wills is not going well.


He keeps chanting, and suddenly you feel your defenses snap. "So die all who side with daemons," the bloody professor says, and you burst into flame. The pain is immense and your screams horrible, but through it all you watch Seria fight through the the other professor and charge towards your enemy.


Her eyes burn even brighter than you, and she attacks with savage fury and no mercy. Her teeth, long and sharp, cut into his flesh, and she snaps his bones like twigs, quite literally tearing him apart. She cannot save you, but she can make the last moments of this man's life as close to hell as one can feel in this life.


When the deed is done she runs to you. You are nearly dead too, but when she kisses you the pain dies away. Surely this is the best way to die, with the lips of the woman you love on your own and your enemy's blood spilled in puddles around you. It is a shame you could not kill every daemonologist, but if Seria's expression is any indication, they have little time left.<|endoftext|>

> You focus on your opponent

You agree, but Seria has different plans. "You need to finish that one off. Your mother's blood still hasn't awakened, and until it does Fogg can likely destroy you. He may destroy us all, but we can at least keep him occupied until your full power comes. Go, my love, and do not come back until you can make me a present of this Chancellor's corpse."


You hate to leave her, but you know she is right. You following the fleeing professor as the others head towards the main battle. His aura might be broken, but it still leaves quite a noticeable trace, and you eventually corner him near the great iron Gates themselves. His face has stopped bleeding, and to his credit he turns to fight you once he knows you are there.


The second battle is much shorter than the first. His power is nearly gone, and you are prepared for any tricks. Within a few minutes he begins to shiver, then to shake, and a moment later he collapses. A quick Greek spell is all it takes to sever his head from his shoulders. You are pleased to defeat him, but it does not feel like anything new has happened. No surge of power, no second wind, no anything. It seems your angelic nature needs something more to awaken, though you don't know what it might be. You could head for the main battle and hope you run into someone else to kill, you suppose, but there's no telling if it would work.


Just then you hear someone running up the path from the other door. You don't bother to hide. Fogg is accounted for, and unless it's Hopkins you shouldn't have any trouble defeating him. Part of you hopes it is Dr. Hopkins, as you think that perhaps such a victory is the only way to unleash your potential.
> The figure emerges into the moonlight
He wears a tattered cloak, and even at night you can see how pale and gaunt his face is. It is Peter.


"What are you doing here?" you ask.


He stops, trying to catch his breath. "I arrived from London this evening and woke when I heard the explosions and screams. Half of Covingsford must be awake by now too, though I don't blame them for staying in their beds. What on Earth has happened?"


You look at your friend. He has a little silver knife, the kind you might use for practice in Dr. Young's class. You find you cannot lie. "Daemons are attacking the College, daemons I summoned." You see the shock on his face and continue. "I do not have time to explain everything, but the daemonologists are evil, more evil than the spirits they fight. They killed my mother, Peter, murdered her because she was an angel, and I won't let them escape justice."


He runs a hand through his hair. "Who killed your mother?" When you admit you don't know, he takes a step towards you. "I believe you, but this cannot be the best way to have justice. From the sound of it, the daemons are killing every professor here and a fair number of students too. Most of them probably had no part in your mother's death."


"They protected whoever did kill her. They broke bread with a murderer, and they're all guilty of a dozen crimes besides. Do you think everyone killed in America is a true rebel, Peter? No, but when you live and work with criminals, you have no cause for complaint if you get caught up in their punishment."


"Then this is vengeance and no justice."


You laugh. "You may call it what you will. It does not concern you, however, and I have no wish to see you dead. Go back to your bed. Go back to London and your Lizzy, and I swear no daemon will follow."


"It's her, isn't it? Your succubus. You must listen to me, as your friend- she cannot be trusted. For God's sake, she's a daemon!"


You throw the punch before Peter finishes the word. He stumbles back to his feet after a second, nose smashed. "Go," you say, turning around. You only make a few steps before he finishes a spell. A jolt of electricity arcs from his fingers into your back, and you swear. It seems you are not the only one who practiced advanced magic in secret, though you can tell your friend is no match for you.

You mutter another incantation and he is forced to the ground. He rises unsteadily and, seemingly empty of magical power, resorts to throwing a rock. You could boil him with the water vapor in the night sky above or tear him down the middle without a second thought, you're sure of it, and none of his brilliance will save him.


"You're her slave," he yells. "I'm your best friend, and you're going to kill me for her. You'd best get it over with, I wouldn't want her to get impatient with you."
> You kill him
The rage surges through you. You imagine this must be what it's like to struck by lightening, this feeling of sheer power and of life. You barely even notice Peter sprawled below you. Your mind is fixed on Seria's face and your mother's. What you do now, you do for them. None of the spells you can think of seems quite right, so you start scanning the ground. It only takes you a moment to find it.


Peter's knife is elegant, and you take a second to wipe the dirt away. Yes, this will do quite well. His eyes widen just a little when he realizes what is to come, then they harden. You can tell he's thinking, trying to find something that will dissuade or defeat you, but he cannot win, and he knows it. Finally he meets your gaze, eyes glinting in the moonlight. "Do it."


You bring the knife down. Peter does not bow his head, does not even flinch, though when the blade cuts his neck he cannot stop the shudder. You are methodical as you slit his throat, and you do not mind how much blood cascades out and onto your hands. It is sticky and very hot, steaming in the chilly air, and it adds to the fire in your blood. The memory of Seria, her lips wet with your blood, leaps into your mind. You need to find her. Together you will kill your enemies, just as you killed this false friend.


The heat travels up your hands and arms, and it fills your chest. Soon it is painful, but there is pleasure in the pain. Each heartbeat send a stab of agony through your entire body, and for a time the pain is so intense you think you will die. But this is not death, you realize joyfully. It is your second birth, your mother's gift. You are becoming what you were meant to be. You are becoming an angel.


You let a great cry echo into the night. Your back is burning, tearing, and then suddenly your wings break free, even larger than Seria's. The pain fades away, though the heat remains. You want to fight, or else to find Seria and make love. Your aura is strong, surely stronger than Fogg's. You glance down at Peter's corpse and feel nothing. Then, unbidden, a mirthless laugh escapes your lips. He was a true friend after all, for without him you might never have embraced your destiny.


You move your new wings a little, marveling because you can sense the smallest currents in the wind, and then leap into the air, springing nearly ten feet and then taking flight. You can see across the buildings and far into the distance, but your eyes go at once to the cluster of flames, flashes, and strange shimmering spells in the courtyard in front of the library. You only need to beat your wings twice and you are above them, gazing down as your daemons fight the last of the daemonologists.
> The battle rages below
Even from the sky, you can see that there are bodies strewn everywhere, many more than the number of professors. It seems that the students, or at least a good number of them, joined in the defense of the College. You feel no pity. Quickly you survey the enemies, pleased that your forces have already slaughtered most of your mother's murders. Dr. Thewliss and five or so students are clustered in one corner, Dr. Hopkins and two are in another, and in the center of it all, Chancellor Fogg stands alone.


Each battles several daemons, though you note with displeasure that their ranks have thinned, too. The minotaur Lignor and a few others face Thewliss' band while viper-headed Jarobaal and Yfrigge, still wearing the guise of a young girl, fight with Dr. Hopkins. The Chancellor has the most enemies- Anumun the raksha, four daemons you don't recognize, and Seria, her flaming eyes shining brighter than the stars above. Chanting in many languages mixes with howls and shouts of pains, while knives and bundles of herbs fly in all directions. The combatants' auras mix too, and it's hard to tell which battle needs your direct attention most.


Since Hopkins is the closest, you glide down to finish him off. The stooped man wields a silver saber, its blade flashing as it twirls. Jarobaal has a spear, and the two are locked in an intricate dance. You would never have imagined Hopkins would be so quick on his feet, but it does him no good. Swooping, you shout an incantation, and though he tries to yell a spell of his own, his power is no match for yours. Your fire devours him completely. You land, setting the grass aflame, while he shrieks in agony. Jarobaal finishes him with a blow to the gut, and you feel his life force ebbing away.


The two students are even less trouble. Yfrigge catches one by the leg and tears it off, then in short order does the same with his other limbs. He screams for death and she obliges, breaking his neck without a word. The other, you realize, is John Keating. He mutters something and sends a a rush of wind at you, but it barely rustles your wings. You remember the time you fled instead of fighting him. It seems tonight is your chance for vengeance here, too, and you dispatch him with a spell you found in an old Russian book. He sinks to his knees, his skin turning blue, and then one by one his fingers freeze and fall off, then his nose and ears. By the time the cold takes his life, his eyes are crusted over with frost.


Jarobaal and Yfrigge gaze in wonder at your true form. "My lord," the girl says, and Jarobaal joins her in a bow. Their deferrence is intoxicating, but you have not forgotten about the battle. You see that Dr. Thewliss now fights with one two students at his side against the minotaur, whose enormous axe cannot quite catch the tiny man, though he is not nearly as quick as he was before. Chancellor Fogg has defeated one of your daemons, but Anumun, Seria, and three others still press him close, and you can tell the old fool is faltering.


You order Jarobaal and Yfrigge to finish off Dr. Thewliss while you head for Fogg. His long beard is smoldering, though you can't tell if it's from a daemon's attack or the sheer power he's wielding. You do not fear the man, and you are eager to test yourself and to destroy him. Seria sees you coming, and her smile is ravishing, those dark lips so beautiful beneath the moon. You stride to her side and pull her close for a kiss. She rubs against you and purrs. "You have changed, my love! No one can stand against you now."


Your hands roam over her body, Fogg quite forgotten. "But I am yours, always yours, and you are always mine."


You hear a cry. Lignor has finally caught Thewliss, the old wretch split in half by his huge blade. The students break, fleeing in different directions, and the minotaur and his daemons give chase. You and Seria watch with pleasure as your allies run the first one down and break his skull, but your joy turns to anger when Fogg, his beard now nearly burned away, manages to vaporize Anumun the raksha. Now you must finish what you have started.


You begin to chant, and for the first time you feel the Chancellor's aura directly. He is powerful, but you know you are stronger. He is merely human, and you are an angel. You cannot resist goading, even if it breaks off your spell. "Am I the first angel you've fought, or were you the one who killed my mother"


"You are no angel!" the old man shouts, his breath labored. "You are a daemon and a master of daemons, and your kind will all be destroyed!"


Typical daemonologist nonsense, and his words only inflame your anger. You can feel your power prevailing over his. It is almost over, just a few more words. You only need to keep up your focus, and the old fool will be dead and your mother's murder avenged.


Suddenly Seria shouts "My love!"
> You finish Fogg
This is your moment of triumph, and even love will have to wait. You complete the spell, and the old man gives one last gasp. His body shrivels up like a raisin, tinier and tinier until it fades into nothing. You feel stronger than you've ever felt and a little angry that there are no more enemies to slaughter.


The feeling does not last, however, as something strikes your side at that moment. You look down to find a silver spear, its tip jagged and cruel. Your flesh is cut and blood pours out, but the burning is far worse, a cold fire that starts in the wound and radiates out in horrible pulses. This cannot be, you think, for you are an angel, and silver is only poisonous to daemons.


You watch as Seria charges towards your assailant, and you dimly recognize him as the student who fled from Lignor's blade. He must have escaped, but the blasted man did not know it would be better to stay away. Seria makes short work of him, tearing open his chest with her teeth and feasting on his heart while you try to remember a healing incantation. It is very hard to think with this vile cold in your side. You try to pull the spear out, but the barbs catch on your flesh and make you want to scream.


Seria is at your side once more, her breath hot on your skin, but even that cannot keep you warm. "Come closer, my love," she whispers, and you try to obey. She holds you tight, though the silver must pain her too, and when her tears come they fall like hot rain on your flesh. She kisses you, one long, last kiss, and faintly you taste berries and wine. The rest of the world dies away. There is only Seria, her lips and her eyes and her warmth.


She keeps holding you long after your life fades, keeps bringing her lips to meet yours and burying her face in your chest. "You are mine," she murmurs again and again, "and I am yours."<|endoftext|>
