> You turn
Still chanting, you whirl away from the Chancellor and look at your love. Seria runs towards you, pointing out into the darkness, and when you glance that way you notice a figure, his arm cocked back and something in his hand. Seria flies past you, teeth bared, and arrives to tear out the man's throat a moment after the spear leaves his hand. It whistles through the air, silver tip gleaming beneath the moon, and you easily leap aside.


Fogg, meanwhile, has regained a little breathing room in your battle. He pulls something from his pocket, a tiny bundle, and even through the confusion you can smell its sickening odor. He hurls it towards you, pitifully weak and inaccurate, but the old bastard makes it burst with a quick word, sending a shower of herbs in all directions. Some lands on your skin and seems to sink in, burning and rotting the flesh away wherever it touches. You want to itch, to tear the hateful stuff out, but you focus on the task at hand. You recognize the scent as rosemary and lavender, though you can't imagine why it would smell so foul or burn your skin.


The Chancellor's little trick may have bought him some time, but you know that your victory is inevitable. When a handful of your daemons try to join in the fight you hold them back. This is your kill. Seria's smile, her lips still dripping with the spear-thrower's blood, makes you forget the pain.


Fogg draws a great shuddering breath, his shoulders heaving. He looks twenty years older, and he was not, of course, a young man to begin with. Still, he refuses to give up the struggle, still muttering softly and making complex signs with his hands. While you're half-curious to learn about this way of casting spells, you've grown tired with the old man. You raise you voice, chanting the final words of his doom, and you feel his aura contract, shiver, and finally fade away. He is at your mercy.


A few more words send him soaring a hundred feet into the air. He hangs among the stars for a moment, limbs dangling absurdly, and then you let him fall. The grass muffles his crash, but it could not stop his scream, the dying gasp of an ancient wretch. Yfrigge checks the corpse. "He is dead," she says triumphantly. Your daemons begin to howl and stomp their feet, but you pay them no mind. There is only one who matters, and you can feel her breath upon your neck and her hands upon your skin.
> You time passes...
The bed is lovely. You are quite comfortable underneath your blanket, and moonlight has just begun to stream through the window. Perhaps there are bats twittering somewhere far away, but you don't pay much attention to anything. Everything is soft and warm, and though you hardly need to sleep these days, you are happy to indulge your lover when she is in this mood.


Then there is something against your lips. It is soft and warm too, and you smile. Your mouth is full of sweetness and the taste of great ripe blackberries. You picture them hanging on the bush, gleaming dark on a summer day. Now it is like wine, and now like honey.


The thing against your lips pushes a little harder, and the flavor grows stronger. The taste of the wine alone is intoxicating, driving you mad, and then it changes to blood. You remember how they died, first the professors who murdered your mother, then the students who would have learned to be murderers too. There have been many since then, daemonologists across Britain and Europe, foolish sorcerers among the pagans, even the odd and unlucky traveller who wanders across your home. You like to picture the bloody deaths the most, and none more than Peter Aubrey's, the boy who was your friend, the boy who tried to keep you from your lover. His throat poured blood like a river, and the thought never fails to excite you. For it was his blood that awakened your mother's in your veins, his blood that made you what you were meant to be. It does not matter that men call you daemon and not angel- you are your mother's son, and you are powerful beyond measure. You bite down suddenly, hard, your teeth drawing blood from your lover, and she moans in ecstasy.


Sprawled across your body is a woman with purple lips, so purple they seem almost black. Seria gazes back at you, her eyes full of hunger, her body heaving with desire. You cannot spend another moment reminiscing about the good times of the past, you cannot even think. You only look at her beautiful face and those lips. You watch her spread a pair of vast silverly wings around you, and you unfurl your own until you are locked together in a close embrace. "I am yours," you whisper.


She rubs her hand across your chest. "You are mine, and I am yours."


Then, blood on both your lips, she bends forward and gives another kiss. <|endoftext|>
<|startoftext|>He wears a tattered cloak, and even at night you can see how pale and gaunt his face is. It is Peter.


"What are you doing here?" you ask.


He stops, trying to catch his breath. "I arrived from London this evening and woke when I heard the explosions and screams. Half of Covingsford must be awake by now too, though I don't blame them for staying in their beds. What on Earth has happened?"


You look at your friend. He has a little silver knife, the kind you might use for practice in Dr. Young's class. You find you cannot lie. "Daemons are attacking the College, daemons I summoned." You see the shock on his face and continue. "I do not have time to explain everything, but the daemonologists are evil, more evil than the spirits they fight. They killed my mother, Peter, murdered her because she was an angel, and I won't let them escape justice."


He runs a hand through his hair. "Who killed your mother?" When you admit you don't know, he takes a step towards you. "I believe you, but this cannot be the best way to have justice. From the sound of it, the daemons are killing every professor here and a fair number of students too. Most of them probably had no part in your mother's death."


"They protected whoever did kill her. They broke bread with a murderer, and they're all guilty of a dozen crimes besides. Do you think everyone killed in America is a true rebel, Peter? No, but when you live and work with criminals, you have no cause for complaint if you get caught up in their punishment."


"Then this is vengeance and no justice."


You laugh. "You may call it what you will. It does not concern you, however, and I have no wish to see you dead. Go back to your bed. Go back to London and your Lizzy, and I swear no daemon will follow."


"It's her, isn't it? Your succubus. You must listen to me, as your friend- she cannot be trusted. For God's sake, she's a daemon!"


You throw the punch before Peter finishes the word. He stumbles back to his feet after a second, nose smashed. "Go," you say, turning around. You only make a few steps before he finishes a spell. A jolt of electricity arcs from his fingers into your back, and you swear. It seems you are not the only one who practiced advanced magic in secret, though you can tell your friend is no match for you.


"I do not want you dead!" you shout, but Peter has already released a second spell, this one a jet of green flame. "Stop!"


"I will not," he grunts, and sends yet another jolt of electricity. You knock it away with a word, and he frowns. He must know that this fight is hopeless. You mutter another incantation and he is forced to the ground. He rises unsteadily and, seemingly empty of magical power, resorts to throwing a rock. "You'll have to kill me," he cries, his sallow face alive with determination and a hint of fear. His eyes have the familiar metallic glint. "Or bring your daemon bitch to do it for you."


Now you are truly angry, and it does not help when Peter throws his knife and nicks your arm. You can feel your aura growing, and twenty or more curses spring into your head. You could boil him with the water vapor in the night sky above or tear him down the middle without a second thought, you're sure of it, and none of his brilliance will save him.


"You're her slave," he yells. "I'm your best friend, and you're going to kill me for her. You'd best get it over with, I wouldn't want her to get impatient with you."
> You spare him
"You're her slave." The words don't make a difference at first, but something about them stops you from blasting Peter away. Bullock thought you were a daemon's slave, and your other professors all warned against daemonic manipulation. You remember how Seria sent you dreams, how she came and gave you slow drops of knowledge, always mixed with sensual pleasure. You look down at your friend, your brilliant, stubborn friend, his hand scrabbling in the dirt for another rock. If he says something, you should listen.


"I'm not possessed," you say slowly.


Peter nods. "Certainly not. But you can be a slave in effect if not by nature. Remember Aristotle's distinction between substance and accidents?"


The reference is so absurd that you laugh, and more than anything that makes you certain that you will not kill him. How could you have even thought of doing so? He is your friend, and he is only trying to keep you from killing a great many innocent people. He laughs too, and you release him from your spell with a wave of your hand. "Tell me everything," he says, and you do, horrible as it is. 


Your stomach drops as you describe what you have done. Your own father is dead at your hand, as are Coghill and the other professor. Faber, Young, and God knows how many others are dead because of you, and the daemons are still rampaging through the College grounds. Perhaps they have even overcome Dr. Fogg by now. Maybe one of them killed your mother, or maybe not, but Peter is right. This is not justice, it is only butchery.


You find it hardest to talk about Seria. You cannot hate her like you now hate the other daemons you summoned, no matter what she has done. You touch the mark on your cheek and remember her words. You are hers, and she is yours. It is sheer madness, but perhaps you can stop her, convince her to leave everyone else alive. 


"I need to go. Perhaps I can stop them," you say.


"Not by yourself," Peter adds. You want disagree but know there's nothing short of death that could dissuade him, and you've already ruled that out. You set out for the main battle, hoping that it isn't too late. Peter limps a little, which you solve with a simple healing prayer, and together you make your way through the moonlit paths of Covingsford College.
> The battle is fierce
And it rages in the heart of campus, the great open field in front of the library. There are bodies strewn everywhere, many more than the number of professors. It seems that the students, or at least a good number of them, joined in the defense of the College. Dr. Thewliss and five or so students are clustered in one corner, Dr. Hopkins and two are in another, and in the center of it all, Chancellor Fogg stands alone. 


Each battles several daemons, though you see that their ranks have thinned, too. The minotaur Lignor and a few others face Thewliss' band while viper-headed Jarobaal and Yfrigge, still wearing the guise of a young girl, fight with Dr. Hopkins. The Chancellor has the most enemies- Anumun the raksha, four daemons you don't recognize, and Seria, her flaming eyes visible even from far away. Chanting in many languages mixes with howls and shouts of pains, while knives and bundles of herbs fly in all directions.


Hopkins is closest, and you run to relieve him first. Peter shoots another green flame, which distracts Jarobaal enough to let the professor deal him a mortal blow with a saber. You would never have imagined the stooped man would be so quick on his feet, but he wastes no time exulting in the victory. Even alone, Yfrigge is dangerous. When she sees you she frowns. "Twice traitor."


Seemingly without effort, she knocks all her other enemies back and begins walking towards you. Hopkins is the first to recover, and he starts to chant, but her defenses must be very strong. You add your power to his, and all the while she is coming closer and closer. You back up, still chanting, but she shows no sign of weakening. You can see a vein on Hopkins' neck- it looks ready to burst. Fumbling in your pockets, you look for something, anything that you could thrown, but there is nothing. She is three yards away, one yard, one foot.


Suddenly one of the other students launches himself at her, and they go tumbling together into the grass. He has nothing but a rock, but he makes good use of it, bashing her skull open and flattening it for good measure. Yfrigge screams long after a human being would have died, but the rock and you and Hopkins' chanting is enough to defeat her. You watch as her body sinks into the ground. A little essence oozes out and gets carried off the by the wind. Yfrigge's assailent clambers up off the ground. It is John Keating, scraped and glowering but very much alive. "Kind of you to join us," he grunts.


The rest of the battle still rages. Dr. Thewliss now fights with only two students at his side against the minotaur, whose enormous axe cannot quite catch the tiny man, though he is not nearly as quick as he was before. Chancellor Fogg has defeated one of the daemons, but Anumun, Seria, and three others still press him close, and you can tell the old titan is faltering.


Hopkins, Peter, and the others run to aid Dr. Thewliss while you head for Fogg. His long beard is smoldering, though you can't tell if it's from a daemon's attack or the sheer power he's wielding. Seria sees you coming and smiles, those dark lips so beautiful beneath the moon. It nearly makes you change sides again, but you are stronger now. You mouth a spell, one you encountered scribbled in the margin of an old Greek translation of an Egyptian manuscript, and one of the other daemons yelps. His scaly wings begin to convulse, covered in what looks like a moving blanket, and soon the pain reaches the rest of his body. The other daemons stop a moment to watch the thousand scarab beetles devour him, which gives Dr. Fogg the chance to strike one down with a sudden, blazing light.


You hear a cry. The minotaur finally caught Thewliss, his body split in half by the huge blade. The others circle him, wary of being next, but Lignor just bellows and keeps swinging.


Seria stalks towards you, every motion seductive and terrifying. If she was frightening before you fell in love, that is nothing compared to the fear you feel now. Her eyes are no longer like fire. They are dark and beautiful. Her chest heaves, and you realize she is crying. "You betrayed me."
> You speak
Seria is strong, perhaps stronger than you even at the best of times and certainly after everything that's happened. With a bitter laugh you realize she was wrong- your mother's blood never awakened, not after any of the stresses of this night. If it had you might have a chance in combat, but as it is you will have to hope her love for you is real.


"I am yours," you whisper, trying to block out the noise and excitement of the battle which swirls around you. She keeps walking towards you, and you stand your ground. You study her features, the face that haunted your dreams and then became real. The lovely eyes and lips, her flawless skin and hair. Even now, with the corpses of your professors and fellow students littering the ground, you cannot believe she is pure evil. A bit from Saint Augustine floats into your mind, something about how evil has no positive nature. It is only a vacuum, emptiness without light or love. Looking into Seria's eyes, you hope against all reason that there is something there.


She stops about a foot away, though the space feels like miles. "You are mine," she says at last. "How could you forget that?" There is a moment's pause and then she is in your arms, her tears falling like rain and burning your skin. It is all too much. The pain, her scent, and your love. "You are mine, and I am yours."


With Seria holding your face in her hands and your arms wrapped around her, you lose all awareness of the battle that surrounds you. All that matters are her tears, and you begin to cry too, knowing you have failed her. She stands with you, love holding love, while the remnants of the daemonic army are destroyed around you. She does not fight. You kiss her forehead, and she kisses your chest, and you do not notice Fogg, his beard nearly all burned away, approaching to land the final blow. She snaps your neck and gives you one last kiss, her dark lips pressed against your lifeless ones.


"You are mine, and I am yours," she murmurs again, and then, still holding you close, you depart together for oblivion.<|endoftext|>

Seria stalks towards you, every motion seductive and terrifying. If she was frightening before you fell in love, that is nothing compared to the fear you feel now. Her eyes are no longer like fire. They are dark and beautiful. Her chest heaves, and you realize she is crying. "You betrayed me."
> You fight
You cannot let her come any closer. You do not trust yourself, not if she leans in to kiss you or lets her fingers dance across your body. Even now, you realize, you cannot bear to see her so sad. You want nothing more than to comfort her, to kiss those lips again, and to spill the guts of Fogg, Peter, and anyone else who stands in your way onto the winter ground.


Backing up, you try to think of any spells that might be effective. Seria is powerful, and she knows you very well, which means you're unlikely to surprise her. Thinking over everything you've seen, you decide that physical force is your best hope, though it is a small hope indeed. With no other weapons, you throw a punch. Lightening fast, she seizes your wrist and breaks it. You fall to the ground, clutching your arm, trying to force out the words of a healing spell. Seria stands above you, magnificant and terrible, and her tears fall like rain and burn against your skin.


"You are mine," she says softly. "And you betrayed me."


"I am yours," you echo, "and you are mine." She looks down, and you gaze into her eyes. Slowly, painfully, you try to rise, try to press your lips against hers. When she does not move, you whisper "I am sorry."


She remains still, and then her tears stop. Her eyes begin to blaze, brighter than you have ever seen them before, but you cannot move. Seria brings her hand to your cheek, to the rose emblazoned there. Suddenly she grabs your hair. "You are mine, and you betrayed me," she snarls. "And there can be no apology." With a great roar she tears your head from your neck, blood spurting up into her face, and throws it far off into the darkness. She licks the blood from her lips, eyes burning and full of hate, and turns to the battle. Victory may be out of reach, but she can still kill many before she too is killed.<|endoftext|>
<|startoftext|>Life has never been so good. Each day you work greater and greater magic, though still in the confines of your room, and nearly every night Seria comes to reward you. You feel guilty about it, sometimes, having so much pleasure when your mother's killers still breathe, but you know that you must have patience. Your anger no longer burns quite so hot against the professors, perhaps because you release a lot of energy during the night. The other daemons are almost convinced, and you are almost strong enough to summon them.


This is, you learn, your essential role in Seria's plan, and so you've been studying the basics of summoning in secret. Each of the spirits was banished long ago by one of the professors, which explains their willingness to risk destruction for revenge. It takes someone with more power than the banisher to reverse that kind of magic, and she believes you are close. Thankfully, one of the spells you've come across lets you dimly sense another's strength, though it is not exact. Chancellor Fogg is the only daemonologist who could certainly best you. Dr. Hopkins is powerful too, as are a few professors you don't know well. The others are pitiable weak, substituting useless knowledge for their lack of natural strength.


Speaking of Hopkins, he and Peter are the only people that keep you from complete allegiance to Seria's plan. You don't care at all if innocent professors are slaughtered. They sheltered your mother's killers and probably did similar things themselves. You don't even mind if some students are killed, though Seria assures you that your allies have no interest in doing so unless the students try to resist their attack. You hope Peter will not, but you aren't sure how to warn him without raising his suspicions. Hopkins is the one professor whom you wish did not have to die. He has always been kind to you, and he doesn't seem to have the same attitude as the others, the attitude that you now find so hypocritical. If he has to die, so be it, but you'd like to find a way to spare him.


Thewliss is in a way the worst of them all. You find it hard to believe you once respected him and felt grateful when he gave you the ankh. His lectures are full of what you now recognize as sanctimonious nonsense. To hear him tell it, spirits have been oppressing mankind since the dawn of time, and daemonologists have defended them. You've done a little reading of your own and know now that the truth is very different. Your mother's murder is only one of many through the ages, innocents killed by overzealous daemonologists. Soon she will be avenged, and all the others too.


Still, the matter of Peter and Dr. Hopkins preys on your mind. There must be some way to explain what's happening, some way to get them to see reason. You need to act quickly, however, since Seria's been hinting that the attack will come quite soon. Last night she told you she won't be back for a few days. Apparently there's one more spirit to convince, a mighty raksha in Bengal who Bullock encountered during a brief job protecting the East India Company. This should give you a chance to warn them, but who should you speak to first?
> You dr. Hopkins
Seria promised that students would not be targetted, and you trust her. Hopkins, though, is one of the strongest professors at the College, and unless you can convince him to flee will surely be killed. You aren't sure it will work, but you must try.


You wait through practical metaphysics the next day, trying and failing to think of anything but the truth that will convince dr. Hopkins. As the students file out, he is still pacing back and forth, genially saying goodbye. It is curious that this stooped, kindly man would have such power, probably even more than you, but you know it won't be enough to fight off the daemonic army Seria is gathering.


"Well my boy, another excellent demonstration of magic prowess. Sprouting flowers from seeds is a difficult thing, but once again you had no trouble. I'd better watch my back with you around, or else the Chancellor will send me packing and hire you straightaway." He stops pacing and chuckles. "Or perhaps you're too busy with that succubus to care much about employment. I haven't heard you mention her in a while, has she finally found someone better to pursue, or did you tire her out?"


You decide to be direct. None of the stories you rehearsed are convincing, and Hopkins is a clever man. "Sir, there's going to be an attack on the College."


His smile immediately drops away. "When?"


"I'm not sure precisely, but soon. There won't be any chance of victory, the daemons are too strong and too numerous. If you leave, though, you can survive."


Hopkins stares at you a moment, lost in thought. Finally he asks "How do you know?" He keeps muttering to himself as you answer. You hadn't expected the news to rattle him so deeply, but perhaps he isn't as powerful as you thought.


You take a deep breath. "My succubus hasn't abandoned me. She's gathering forces into an immense army, and they'll utterly destroy everything in their path. But I don't want you..." Your body suddenly locks in place, your mouth still open.


Hopkins grimaces. "I'm sorry, my boy, but I could never flee while the College is in danger, and I could never let you side with a daemon against us. Why did you do it, why did you listen to her? It's probably my fault, filling your head with all that nonsense about the pleasures of the succubi and even giving you that protective charm. Never thought you'd actually be enslaved. I'll say it again, I'm sorry, but I must take you to the Chancellor."


You try to protest, try to explain that you are not enslaved and that the daemonologists deserve everything that they will get, but your body stays motionless. Hopkins mutters another spell and you begin to float behind him, out the door and building and to Chancellor Fogg's office.
> You meeting Fogg
Hopkins does not bother knocking and barges right through the Chancellor's door. He is at his bookcase, but as soon as he sees you enter walks calmly over. "Dr. Hopkins, I presume there is a very good explanation for this intrusion? Is that young Latimer?"


You try to protest but are reduced to simply hoping Seria will arrive in time, just as she did with your father. Hopkins quickly explains everything, how you are almost certainly in league with a succubus to destroy the College. You never thought he cared much, but it seems you greatly overestimated his cynicism and unorthodoxy. Hopkins does admit his share of blame, but Chancellor Fogg silences him with a quick motion of his arm.


"This is quite serious, the most serious offense a daemonologist may commit. It is far beyond my jurisdiction. It is a matter for the King and the courts, and it is to London that you will go. But first I would hear your side of the story."


Since Hopkins immobilized you, your anger has been building, and you are in no state to explain why you've done what you've done. Instead, as soon as they unbind your face you begin shouting every invective you can think of, raining down curses on them both and ranting that all daemonologists are murderers and hypocrites. Needly to say this does not help your case, and the Chancellor soons tires of it and renders you motionless once again.


Once he realizes your power, Fogg decides it would be best to escort you to London himself, and you leave at once. The journey is an uneventful carriage ride, though you're certain he must have given the horses a little extra speed by magic. He does not release the binding spell until you're safely in a jail cell designed specifically for magical criminals. The bars are silver and laced with glyphs and intricate designs, and you find that none of your spells do the slightest good. Once again you can only hope Seria can find you and arrives in time.


You go to court the next day, bounding in a netting of silver cord. You can feel it choking your aura, preventing any magic. Fogg and Hopkins both testify against you, and you do not bother to speak in your defense. Seria is your only chance now. You are swiftly found guilty and sentenced to hang at Tyburn.


Justice is quick, and your sentence is carried out the next day. The crowd is pleased to watch the hanging of an evil sorcerer, though you barely notice them. Your eyes are scanning the sky for any sign of your succubus, your eyes listening for the sound like rushing wind. Even when they place the noose around your neck, you are convinced she will save you. It is only in the instant of death, as your body falls and your neck mercifully snaps, that you realize you have utterly failed. Your mother's death stays unavenged. Perhaps Seria will manage to succeed, even without you, for all you can do now is rot in a common criminals' grave.<|endoftext|>
<|startoftext|>You stare into her dark eyes. The words do not make sense. No one murdered your mother, she died from eclampsia right after you were born. If anyone killed her it was you, but you know that kind of talk is only foolishness. Seria stares back for a long time and then, in a low voice, adds "the daemonologists."


Your father gives a great cry, but you do not hear him. The daemonologists could not have killed your mother, they are sworn only to fight against evil spirits, against daemons, never against angels. It is impossible, absurd, unthinkable.


"No," you say, shaking a little, "it cannot be. Not the daemonologists I know."


Seria grabs your hand and holds it, tight. "The daemonologists who said I must be a monster but who gave you nothing but bits of metal to defend against me? Who fight among themselves and care more about prestige and little quarrels than with protecting the innocent? They care only for status, only for prestige and power, and your mother had plenty of power."


Her words are like knives, but as you gaze into her eyes they make terrible sense. You do not want to believe them, you want her to be quiet, but she continues. "They must have sensed her aura for a long time, living so close to the College, even if she tried to hide. But the birth was difficult, and so, when you were only a few days old and healthy, she ventured out into the countryside for a walk, perhaps to clear her thoughts, to enjoy the sunshine and the grass. I imagine she hated to stay cooped up indoors. That's where they caught her, and that's where they killed her, leaving you, just born and already all alone in the world, to fend for yourself."


Your father struggles to his knees and clutches at your leg. "She was killed, but you were not alone, my son. You had a father..." Seria catches him with another slap, and he falls to his back. You share in her surge of anger. You had no father, or as good as none. When did he care, when did he speak to you or tell you anything about your mother or your heritage? How can he try to claim innocence when he chose some whore over his own wife?


But your father will not stay down. "She was killed, my angel was murdered, but..." With a sudden roar, Seria slams her elbow into his neck. He would not give them until Seria came, why should he have the chance to say them now?
> You resist the urge
Your father's face is cut and bruised all over, several of his teeth lie scattered on the floor, and he can barely open his eyes. His great bulk trembles behind him, and every breath causes immense pain. You stare down, and slowly your anger dissolves. You feel no pity, though, merely disgust. This the man whose disapproval you feared for all those years, the man who your angelic mother chose to marry?


"Let him speak," you say, your voice flat. Seria looks at you, one perfect eyebrow raised, and for a second you think she will finish your father off right there, but then she nods.


It takes nearly a minute for him to regain his voice, and when it comes it is a hideous croak. "It was only one man, not a pack. His name was Hopkins." This shocks you more than anything you have heard. Genial Hopkins, joking Hopkins, the one professor who did not assume Seria must be evil. It is preposterous, the last daemonologist who would do such a thing.


"You...you must be mistaken."


Your father shakes his head and continues. Seria's eyes are fixed on him, her face unreadable, though you notice she is slowly flexing her fingers. "It was Hopkins, the one with the back bad, and it was an accident. A tragedy. You must understand, my son, that he had to act quickly. A daemon had escaped from the College, a powerful fiend, and Hopkins had no time to track it down. I will not pretend to understand his magic, but your mother must have been caught by whatever spell he used."


"Then why does he still live?" Seria asks suddenly. "If you knew it was Hopkins all along, why have you avenged your wife?"


"I did confront him!" your father cries, "And that was how I learned it was a tragedy and not an act of evil. I...I tried to do as your mother would have, though I confess my bitterness still poisoned my heart. I have never trusted the daemonologists as I ought, not since that awful day, and I have not truly forgiven Hopkins, though I pray for the strength to do so each night. I...my son, you must believe me, the man was a wreck himself with the knowledge of what he had done!"


Curious then, if Hopkins felt such guilt, that he would not say a word about the matter to you. You watch your father babble, and the disgust grows. How could he live just minutes from your mother's killer and do nothing but pray? When you turn away, Seria understands immediately, and you gaze up at your mother's portrait while she beats his skull against the remains of the desk. He failed you, you whisper, but I will not.


When the deed is finished, Seria's eyes glitter like black pearls, and she grabs your shirt with bloody hands. She pulls you close, her voice deep and husky.  "Take me. Now."


You obey, and soon you both have shed your clothes. Bodies locked together, you feel her, hot all over, and it makes you forget everything you have learned these past minutes. Those darks lips are everywhere, and everywhere they touch burns with a cruel and insatiable fire. Your lusts burn together, and it seems nothing could ever quench them.


You last longer than the night before, and when you finish she purrs contentedly. Lazily playing with the strands of her hair, your eyes drift to your father. His face is unrecognizable. Truth be told, it is hardly a face anymore, just a pile of blood and brains. The sight is sickening, but you master your nerves. You did not exactly desire his death, even after everything you learned, but now that it is done you do not feel guilty. He was an adulterer, and against your mother. He let you think her death was your fault, let you join the College and learn from the very man who murdered her, let killer live and made excuses for his evil. Your father's sin probably drove her out of the house in the first place, drove her to her death. You can feel your mother's eyes watching from her portrait and are filled with a sudden rage. Death is too good for the fat old bastard, and with a great roar you begin to pummel his lifeless form.


Seria lets you go for a minutes and then grabs your arm. "Enough. Save your hatred and wrath, we will need them both. This man disgraced your mother and mistreated you, but the one who killed her lives and breaths. I doubt he even remembers the deed." You nod, fully intent on marching straight to the College to slaughter Dr. Hopkins or die trying, but she keeps speaking. "No, young one, you are not strong enough, not yet. Your mother's blood gives you great power, but it will only bear fruit in time. If you strike now it will be in vain, and the wretch will add another of our family to his list of murders."


"Our family?"


She smiles. "Yes, cousin. Amelia was my aunt, my mother's sister. The divide between angels and daemons is not sharp. What does it matter that my mother chose the darkness and yours the light? Blood is what matters, and revenge against the ones who spill it." Suddenly she bends forward and bites your ear, just enough to get a few drops of the stuff. It is barely visible on her lips, but you could hardly miss the way she licks it off.


"Return to the College. Continue with your studies until everything is ready. Rest assured, soon it will all be in place, and together we will avenge your mother. I will visit often, for I know I will not be able to resist tasting you again. You are mine, and I am yours." Seria gives you one last kiss, and then she is gone.
> You time passes...
Mrs. Littlethwaite returns a few hours after Seria's departure, wizened arms laden with food from the market. When she sees your father's body, you do not even have to lie. "Business was not going well, and I feared his debts had grown, feared he had gone to thugs and criminals. What is to become of us now?" she wails. You do your best to comfort her, a little shaken that his death would cause such a reaction, but you feel no remorse. His actions were as bad, no, they were far worse than what you did.


Charles returns a few days later to take possession of the house and full control of the Latimer business interests. If he is at all affected, he does not show it. His analysis is sober. "Father made a string of bad investments, and then some ill fortune compounded the problems. He was too stubborn to listen to my advice, and I suppose he thought he could handle his creditors. But what's done is done. With luck they'll catch the killers, and in time I will rebuild our family's reputation and wealth." You also learn that your father gave Simon his notice a week before, another casulty of his bad investments. Charles assures you that your tuition will still be paid. "We are not so desparate as that."


Christmas comes and goes, a somewhat solemn holiday. Charles returns to London most of the time, so you are left alone with Mrs. Littlethwaite. You speak of little things, your studies at the College and her relations in Norwich, but the sight of your father's body seems to have rattled her quite severely. You spend a great deal of your time in your room reading, or walking else walking with Mrs. Littlethwaite around the town and countryside in the crisp air and snow. You've taken to picturing your mother's death during these walks, imagining Dr. Hopkins casually waving his arm and sending forth the spell, imagining how she must have fallen somewhere nearby, caught alone and unaware. You do not doubt that it was an "accident," that Hopkins did not deliberately hunt your mother down, but that does not dull the anger. He should have been more cautious, not so indiscriminate in his magic as to kill an innocent woman. His intentions matter very little- he is guilty. Sometimes you are not certain you'll be able to wait for Seria's plan, the rage is too strong. Despite her promise, she does not return. You can be patient, however, since her absence means your revenge will come quicker.


Come January you return to your lodgings in the College dormitory. Classes are much more interesting, now that you've learned the theory and the basics, though Hebrew is still a dull slog. Peter is a day late, and when he returns he is thrilled to tell you that he and Lizzy are engaged. "It will have to be a long engagement," he admits, "but her father is no longer opposed. No more secret meetings, unless perhaps I need a strong distraction form my studies." You are pleased for your friend, the first real happiness you have felt in a while, aside from picturing the moment when you Dr. Hopkins lies at your feet, finally paying for what he did.


Those fantasies are, unsurprisingly, particularly severe during practical metaphysics. You want to interrupt Hopkins and ask him why he did not take the time to kill only his target, why he has not apologized or even mentioned your mother's name during all the months you've known him. Perhaps he really has forgotten, or perhaps he thinks that your father's pathetic forgiveness means the matter is ended. The illusion is shattered, and you now loath the man who was once your favorite professor. His little jokes are vile, and his serious lectures are even worse. How dare he prattle on about fighting evil after what he did. Your opinion of all your professors has soured somewhat, too. They must have known what he did, and yet they worked with him as though he were an innocent. You do not hate them, as your hate is reserved for Hopkins alone, but you cannot respect them as you did.
> You hatred does not keep you from learning, though...
And after a few weeks, you are surprised and pleased to learn that your practical metaphysics class will now cover basic magic. Dr. Hopkins stresses the dangers of this sort of thing, but that doesn't do much to dampen the general enthusiasm. "You'd better be sure your Latin pronounciation is good, or you'll end up looking worse than me," he cautions. You force a laugh along with the others and watch him chuckle at his little joke. Still, you can put up with a thousand such japes if it means you can learn true magic, and you laugh for real when you picture using Hopkins' own teaching against him.


Working real magic is complex, and it is only after a week of study that you get the chance to attempt it. You've used the occaisional prayer in your Practicum, of course, but this is different. Hopkins explains how, eventually, some of you will be able to use magic to make light and fire, to calm storms, and, most important, to defend against daemons. You have to bite your lip to keep from shouting at the last one- would he really call your mother's murder an act of defense? The first task is simple, the prayer short. You are each given a small red candle and told to light it. Everyone chants the same words, but the results are quite different. For most, nothing at all happens. A few, including Peter, produce a bit of smoke, but yours bursts immediately into a plume of fire nearly a foot high, burning your fingers a little.


Hopkins is thrilled. "Marvelous work, my boy, marvelous!" You can't help but feel that the praise is over-generous, as you're sure your ability just comes from your mother's blood and not from any work on your part. Still, it's exciting. If you could do this on your first try, how powerful will you be when your angelic heritage is fully manifest? You wonder if Hopkins will be quite as pleased when it is head head that you set aflame and not a candle.


Peter is a good sport and congratulates you, and you realize this is the first time you've really excelled. It's annoying that Hopkins insists on devoting the next month to similar tasks, trifles like filling a cup with water or making a bell ring without touching it. Still, you can be patient, though you decide you'll head to the library to find some more books of magic. There's no reason you can't do a little advanced work now, just to see how far your power stretches.


It takes a while for you to find the right section in the cavernous building, but you are well-rewarded once you do. Spoiled for choice, you spend nearly an hour pulling books from the shelves at random, fascinated by everything you could try. You end up bringing half a dozen to your room, where they join the more mundane works on mathematics, Hebrew, and the like.


You flip through the pages until something catches your eye. It's a prayer to make inscriptions permanent, recorded by a monk named Clement in Britanny in the 13th century. Apparently he used it to keep his most prized manuscripts pristine, which makes you laugh a bit. You take a piece of charcoal and fix the design on your chest, making sure it is exactly as it should be. Then you begin the incantation. "Domine Deus..."


There is prickling sensation on your chest, but it only lasts a few seconds. When you've finished the spell, you try to rub away the charcoal pattern and are pleased to see that your fingers cannot even smudge the lines. A glow of pride fills you, and you eagerly search for another incantation to attempt. You find a curious one in a very ancient scroll, nearly falling apart. It's written in Hebrew but bears the intriguing title "To Awaken What Sleeps," and with the aid of your dictionary you puzzle out its full meaning. The Hebrew is complex, but you're fairly certain that your first thought was correct. This should unleash your angelic heritage, should bring forth all the power you've inherited from your mother. Revenge against Hopkins would be within your grasp, and perhaps Seria would sense the change and return.


Of course, your Hebrew is not perfect, and magic is always a bit unpredictable. Still, without risk there can be no reward, and you could always stop chanting if something goes wrong.
> You perform the spell
You've grown tired of waiting, and if this will give you the power to defeat Hopkins, then you must attempt it. Your mother's blood is a precious inheritance, after all, and you dishonor her by leaving it dormant and useless. You read over the incantation a few times silently, making sure your pronounciation will be perfect, though you are not much worried about making a mistake. That much, at least, you managed to learn from Faber.


"Ha'am hazzeh hara hamme'anim lishoa et-devarai, haholechim bishrirut..." you begin, the words flowing easily despite their unfamiliarity. "Lahem vihi lo tishma'uaha..."


You do not feel any change, but that hardly means that the incantation is not working. You continue, letting your mind focus completely on each syllable. It is not long, and with the final "tivkeh-nafshi mippenei gevah" you are finished. There has still been no change, apart from a pang of annoyance. It was unlikely to work at all, you suppose. Perhaps one of the original letters has worn away completely during the long centuries, or perhaps the magic was never really effective, just an interesting experiment or rhetorical flourish.


Then you hear something, a dull thundering that does not stop. If it is a storm, it must be the most ferocious storm you have ever witnessed. Your puzzlement grows when you realize that the sound is coming, not from outside, but from directly below your feet. It grows louder and louder, and the room begins to shake. The old scroll falls off your desk, and then your books do. It is all you can do to avoid being knocked to the floor as you clutch the wall, but this does not help when the wall itself begins to crack.


You make a split second decision to run for the stairs, meeting up with a number of other students, faces terrified, who are doing the same. You stream out of the dormitory, dodging falling bricks and bits of wood, to find that the ground outside is quaking too. The noise is painfully loud, and as you watch, the dormitory finally collapses in on itself and crashes to the ground. The rubble is only still a moment, however, before something huge bursts from the debris. Everyone tries to run while the gigantic figure stands upright, flexing its huge arms and nearly blotting out the Sun. It looks something like a man, but the features are hideous and out of proportion and, of course, it stands at least fifty feet tall. You are transfixed, wondering in silent horror what you have done, what you have awakened.


The thing notices you, the only person who has not fled, and regards you through its seven bulging eyes. "I am Beelzebub," it rasps, "and now I am free." You do not have much time to be terrified or to guess at what this might mean for the world, since it reaches down, snatches you up in one mishapen hand, and devours you with its cracked and blackened teeth.<|endoftext|>

It's written in Hebrew but bears the intriguing title "To Awaken What Sleeps," and with the aid of your dictionary you puzzle out its full meaning. The Hebrew is complex, but you're fairly certain that your first thought was correct. This should unleash your angelic heritage, should bring forth all the power you've inherited from your mother. Revenge against Hopkins would be within your grasp, and perhaps Seria would sense the change and return.


Of course, your Hebrew is not perfect, and magic is always a bit unpredictable. Still, without risk there can be no reward, and you could always stop chanting if something goes wrong.
> You wait
There is no need to be rash, and staking your life on your knowledge of Hebrew seems a good way to lose it. The day is not over yet, so you leave your room and head for Dr. Faber's office, rotting scroll in hand. You try to think of a convincing story, but there's probably no need. Faber has no reason to be suspicious, and he'll probably treat the scroll as nothing more than a vaguely interested grammatical problem.


You are startled to hear someone's low voice singing through his office door, and even more startled when you realize the words are German. You knock tentatively and the singing stops. "Come in," Faber calls, and you do. He looks at you sheepishly and then grins. "Vun of ze songs of my land," he explains.


You nod, just happy that he seems to be in a good mood. "Sir, I came across this scroll while doing some research for practical metaphysics, and I couldn't quite make out the Hebrew."


Dr. Faber takes it and scans the faded letters. A look of concern comes across his face. "Zis scroll should be destroyed!" he yells suddenly. "Vat sort of library vould leave such a thing lying about?" He beckons you closer and points to each word as he explains. "Zis is a curse, a most terrible curse, to avaken ze horrors zat sleep far beneath ze Earth. Ze great devils, ze strongest daemons. Baal himself, perhaps, or Asmodeus, but zere are others too. Zese...zese are evil vords." He stares at the scroll for a moment and then promptly tears it to shreds. When he is finished he casts them into his fire. "Now ve are safe," he declares.


Speechless, you simply nod again. "I thank you," Faber says seriously. "Vere it not for you, zat scroll might be found by anozer, vun who vould be mad enough to actually use it!" He shakes his head and you depart, a little disconcerted at how close, if your professor is to be believed, you came to unleashing a true catastrophe upon the world. As you walk away, Faber beings to sing again. Though you cannot understand the words, his voice is sad. "Ich hab die Nacht geträumet wohl einen schweren Traum, es wuchs in meinem Garten ein Rosmarienbaum..."


His voice echoes through the corridor around you and makes you miss Seria. It is strange how easily a bit of music can change the mood, but now all you want is for her to return. Even revenge is forgotten, if only for this moment, as Dr. Faber's sweet, melancholy melody makes you dream of your succubus.
> You that night
Seria pays you a visit, and you wonder if she could sense your longing. She notices the magic on your chest immediately, though she seems happier that you had the power to do it than at the spell itself. "Your strength grows, young one, and it will grow stronger by far. It is intoxicating. Bind me, take me, ravish me!" Her voice changes to a moan and she tears away her thin robe. You are more than happy to obey, all traces of your sadness and your near-disastrous mistake forgotten, though you don't require any magic to throw her onto the bed, nor to ravish her. You get little sleep.


After a few hours Seria decides she's in the mood for conversation, though her hand is still working lazily below your blanket. "They are almost convinced. It will only be a little longer now, and then we can strike."


"They?" you ask.


"My allies, powerful spirits. This Hopkins is a strong spellcaster and clever, and we will have to be strong and clever too if we want to punish him. He has wronged many of my kind, many of our kind in the past, and there are no shortage of daemons who are eager to aid in his demise. And, now that you have begun to use magic, there is little doubt your angelic blood will awaken soon. I can afford to come back to you, I need to come back, perhaps even every night."


Her words surprise you a little. Your mother must be avenged, of course, but can you really let a daemonic horde into the College? "And these daemons, they will only kill Hopkins?"


"He will be the main prey, but if others join in the fight, they too must be destroyed. The daemonologists tend to stick together, at least against spirits, so I suppose at least some will try to help him. After all, they protected him for years after he killed my aunt."


You nod, satisfied with her answer. "Very well, but between you and the other daemons, I'm not certain what role I'm meant to play in this plan. I've only just begun to learn magic, and I am certainly no match for Hopkins."


Seria laughs and gives you a kiss. "Your modesty is adorable, but I want you to know your true power. Hopkins is strong compared to most men, but he would have no chance against you, not once your mother's blood shines forth. None of the professors would. You might even be able to vanquish him before your blood awakens. Hopkins and the others, they are learned about some things- dead languages and moldy books, but we are speaking of raw power. Of strength. Of will. Of domination. Of hunger." She gives another moan and you decide that the time to talk is over. There is little doubt that you both have a great deal of hunger, and you do your best to satisfy it in the hours until dawn.


She departs just before sunrise, promising to return when it is dark. You say goodbye with one last squeeze and she laughs again. You laugh too and think about Peter and his Lizzy. Love comes, it seems, in different forms.


The day passes quickly, your mind quite unable to focus on Hebrew grammar and the like. As soon as your classes end you hurry back to your room to practice more magic, and soon you can make small objects levitate, shatter glass with a flick of your finger, and produce food from thin air. It takes you a few tries to perfect some of the more advanced spells, but focusing on Hopkins and your revenge has a wonderful was of focusing the mind.


Before you know it, Seria is back, and you spend this night in much the same way as you spent the previous one. If this is how your life will be while you wait to avenge your mother, you can hardly complain, with days spent gaining strength and nights spent in Seria.
> You time passes...
Life has never been so good. Each day you work greater and greater magic, though still in the confines of your room, and nearly every night Seria comes to reward you. You feel guilty about it, sometimes, having so much pleasure when your mother's killer still breathes, but you know that you must have patience. Your anger no longer burns quite so hot against Hopkins, perhaps because you release a lot of energy during the night. A cool hate has taken its place, and you know that this will serve you better than fury and madness. Seria has almost convinced the other daemons, and you are nearly strong enough to summon them.


This is, you learn, your essential role in Seria's plan, and so you've been studying the basics of summoning in secret. Each of the spirits has some particular grudge against Dr. Hopkins- he banished them from their favored haunt or thwarted their efforts to ensnare someone. It is distasteful to rely on daemonic allies, but you know it is necessary. One of the spells you've come across lets you dimly sense another's power, though it is not exact, and Dr. Hopkins is still likely strong enough to best you. Chancellor Fogg is the only one who you're sure is stronger, and the others are pitiable weak in raw talent. So you must summon the daemons, bloodthirsty and unpredictable as they are, and hope that no innocents choose to die alongside the guilty one when you finally get your revenge.


Seria assures you that your allies have no interest in killing anyone but Hopkins, and you trust her, though you know they will defend themselves with lethal force if any professors or students join the fight. This causes you a bit of worry, particularly for your friend Peter. He is brave and determined, precisely the sort who might rally to Hopkins' side. There is no way to warn him without giving up the entire plan, however, and so you decide that you must rely on stealth. If you can lead the daemons to Dr. Hopkins' home in the middle of the night, with a little luck no one will even know he is dead until morning. There is no need for a real battle and the destruction of innocent life which it would necessarily entail.


You know the moment is coming, and soon, so after practical metaphysics on day you strike up a conversation with Hopkins, hoping he will walk home. His conversation is revolting, full of jokes about other professors and Seria, but you lie and laugh your way through, and he is none the wiser. You walk out of the grounds and through Covingsford, the streets full of people. Many bow to the professor, which you do your best to ignore, and eventually you end up at a little house on the outskirts of town, just where the north road opens up to fields and a little copse of trees. You do not see or sense any obvious magical defenses, but you have no doubt there are there, cleverly hidden and ready to kill or capture any intruder.


Dr. Hopkins shakes your hand before entering his home. "Be careful out there, my boy," he says, his voice a little more serious than usual. "There are dangerous beings that walk this world, dangerous even to the most learned daemonologist." He regards you for a second and then adds, his voice jocular once again, "and one of them haunts your bed, does she not?" With a final wink he opens his door and leaves you alone to meander back to the College.


Peter meets you by the great iron Gates, his face even paler than usual, clutching a letter. "Lizzy is sick," he mumbles, his voice different than you have heard before, soft and with a slight tremor. "Her father writes to bid me return to London. I...I fear the worst." This is enough to drive all thought of revenge from your mind, and when Peter asks you to accompany him to the metropolis, you agree immediately.


Grim as it seems, the timing is perfect- last night Seria told you she won't be back for a few days, perhaps even a week. She wants to hold a meeting with all the daemons, to smooth over any rivalries or disagreements they may have with each other so that everything goes well when you summon them. You should have no trouble making it to London and back, keeping Peter's mind from dark imaginings, and perhaps you can convince him to stay a little longer so that he misses your attack.


Quickly, you gather you things and meet Peter again at the Gates. He has already contracted a carriage, and, less than an hour after he received the letter, you are off.
> You to London
The journey to London is uneventful, and you do your best to keep Peter's mind focused on happier things, or at least on anything that might serve as a distraction. You talk of magic and literature, of mathematics and politics, of the entrance of the French into the war with America. Peter talks of London, of its cathedrals and castles, the narrow streets lined with every imaginable shop and bursting with men and women. He is astounded to learn you have hardly spent a week in the capital during the entire course of your life and immediately sets out to educate you on everything you have missed as an ignorant provincial. You are happy to indulge him.


"And set into the dome are great statues of the Church Fathers- Saint Augustine, Saint Basil, Saint Jerome, and all the rest. The dome is magnificent, designed by Wren in the Continental style, of course, and built after the Great Fire. The building itself is cruciform, a Latin cross, though Wren had original planned for arms of equal length. My dear man, are you quite serious that you knew none of this?"


Your ride passes quickly, and the countryside changes slowly to the outskirts of the great city. Soon you are in its heart and disembark, bags in hand, for Lizzy's home. It is on St. Martin's Lane, above neat shop with a brass sign reading "Mr. Thomas Norrell, Bookseller." Mr. Norrell turns out to be a well-dressed older man with enormous spectacles. He embraces Peter, a gesture which clearly catches your friend by surprise, and ushers you both upstairs.


You wait in the corridor while Peter speaks to his fiancee. Mr. Norrell strikes up a conversation about, naturally enough, books, and you spend the next twenty minutes discussing the comparative merits of various Hebrew dictionaries and editions of the Greek classics. His eyes keep darting from your face and to his daughter's door, and when Peter emerges he rushes at once to grab his hand. "How does she seem?"


Your friend leads you a little ways from the door and then responds. "She is better than I dared to hope, and when she speaks her thoughts are perfectly lucid, though her voice is very weak. But she tells me she cannot keep down food, and her face is so terribly pale." He runs a hand through his hair. "I am no doctor, sir. What do the physicians say?"


Mr. Norrell explains that he has had three doctors examine Lizzy, and each made a different diagnosis. But two, he says quickly, are quacks, and he has decided to follow the recommendations of the third. He turns to you. "She is starved for company. Peter will help a great deal with that, but if you would sit and talk to her awhile it would do a world of good." You nod and walk into her room, not sure exactly what to expect, as Peter and Mr. Norrell continue to discuss the situation.


Even through the illness Lizzy is beautiful, her golden hair strewn messily across the pillow, her blue eyes undimmed by the disease. You quickly introduce yourself and she smiles. "Peter's friend," she says softly. "I have heard about you from him, and now I would like to hear about him from you, and about everything at the College." She motions towards a chair, and you sit. Peter was right, her mind is not at all affected, and she asks intelligent questions about everything you say. Before you realize it, you have explained quite a lot of daemonology, about practical metaphysics and history and the relevance of mathematics.


Eventually Mr. Norrell and Peter join you. "It is time to sleep," her father says quietly, and Lizzy nods. Peter takes your place by her side and holds her hand, and you get the sudden feeling he is about to cry. You are not a very religious man, but now you pray silently to God not to take this woman from your friend, not to leave him without his love. 


Mr. Norrell accompanies you out and leads you to a spare room. "My wife and I had many children," he explains, "but death has claimed them all. All but my Lizzy." You try to think of something to say, but before you can he gives a stiff bow and departs. You sit on the bed, wondering whether death will visit this house again while you are a guest. You cannot bear to just sit and wait; now you are the one who needs a distraction. Perhaps a walk would do you good, though it is well past twilight. Mr. Norrell also has no shortage of reading material, though you doubt there is anything engrossing enough to take your mind off Lizzy's illness.
> You walk
No, a book will not distract you, not tonight. London is the greatest city in the world, and surely something in it will catch your attention. You slip out of the bookshop and draw your cloak close against the chilly wind. There are still a good many people about, walking quickly about their business, lingering outside taverns, or begging anyone who will listen for a coin. You set off south, thinking that a walk along the Thames would be just what you need.


It works splendidly, and after a few minutes, you stare out into the great river, twinkling with boats' lights and moving slowly in the darkness. It makes you think of the night Seria first appeared in the flesh, the night she claimed you as her own. How curiously afraid you were, how ignorant and confused! You thought the rose on your cheek was a mark of slavery or worse, but now you know it is a sign of love, a love no less real than the one that Peter and Lizzy share.


You wish Seria would find you here, alone amid the London crowds. You imagine the scene- the sound of her wings like the rushing wind, her face, beautiful and pale, as she walks towards you. You embrace, your lips meet. The people would scatter at the sight of her, as frightened as you were that first time. Your thoughts become fantasies as you picture Seria's body, and you do not feel the cold air anymore.


A voice from behind, low and raspy, breaks through your reverie. "Your purse, dreamer, or your guts will feed the fishes tonight." You feel a blade against your stomach and see the hairy arm that clutches it wrapped around your body. Glancing around, you realize with a jolt that you have wandered far from any part of the city you recognize. No one else is around, no one but you and the rasping man with the knife.


It takes you a moment to remember the words, but as soon as you can you begin muttering an incantation. It will teach the thug a lesson, you think, when you knock him back a hundred yards and break every bone in his body. Unfortunately for you, the cutpurse has dealt with daemonologists before, and he recognizes the danger in your words at once. He is quick and efficient, disemboweling you and then rifling through your cloak for coins. You watch the steam rise from your organs in the dim moonlight, the last thing you ever see, and it makes you think of Seria's face, so white and lovely.<|endoftext|>
<|startoftext|>The journey to London is uneventful, and you do your best to keep Peter's mind focused on happier things, or at least on anything that might serve as a distraction.
