> You book
There is no need to go wandering around London in the middle of the night, courting trouble. You venture downstairs into the shop and peruse for a few minutes. You decide on a handsome new edition of Pope and carry it back to your room. He is hardly your favorite poet, but you think perhaps it will help you sleep. You are quite correct, and halfway through his Essay on Criticism you nod off, just before he warns that "fools rush in where angels fear to tread."


Breakfast is an uncomfortable meal, and neither Mr. Norrell nor Peter has much to say. You speak to Lizzy for a few minutes, and she appears unchanged, but you spend most of the day exploring the great city. St. Paul's Cathedral is awe-inspiring, as is Westminster Abbey, and you do not disdain from gawking like the most rustic peasant.


When you return in the evening, the entire atmosphere of the house has changed, and you sense it the moment you set foot inside. Mr. Norrell seizes your hand and shakes it energetically. "She has kept down her breakfast, she has kept down her breakfast all day!" he repeats, his face shining. Peter smiles too, and you do not find sleep nearly as hard to come by as the night before.


The next day is still better. Lizzy kept down her supper and has quite an appetite this morning, and when you go in to speak with her, her face is noticeable rosier and her voice not nearly as weak. She still cannot stand, but everything in time. Another day goes by and the improvement is even more marked. Mr. Norrell pronounces it a miracle brought on by Peter's presence; there is no trace of the enmity you know he once had for your friend. By evening all the doctors concur. She will live.


Peter insists you return to Covingsford now that the danger has passed. "You have missed many classes already, and I thank you. I'll follow soon enough." He leans in for a conspiratorial whisper. "The wonderful old man has promised we shall wed in June. In June!" He beams, happier than you have ever seen him.


Your ride home is dull, as your companions in the carriage are two rather deaf women who sleep the entire way. You quickly make up for the lessons you've missed- Dr. Bullock shouts at you a little, but your other professors are all quite understanding. 


Two more days pass without Peter or Seria returning. Your magic is stronger than ever, as you learn during a walk in the countryside when you send a sudden bolt of lightening from the clear sky. You are thrilled, however, when Seria finally surprises you while you're asleep, waking you up in a very interesting way. You spend a while on pleasure and then turn to business, though you can't resist playing with her body a little while you talk.


"Everything is in place. We need to strike now," she says, her suddenly serious tone quite a change from her earlier moans. 


"Tonight?"


"Yes. Our allies are not as patient as you and I, and if you don't summon them now they may move on to easier prey."


You consider it. "Hopkins is strong, but I believe I am stronger. The danger is that others join him, that we do not eliminate him without notice. Even with the daemons, I doubt I can handle more than a few at once, and the Chancellor is far more powerful than I."


"Do not worry, my love. Even if every daemonologist in England joined your mother's killer, it would only add to your strength. The bloodier the combat, the greater chance your angelic blood will awaken, and when that occurs you will be unstoppable." She gives you a deep kiss, and you spend another couple minutes distracting yourselves from the work ahead.


Finally she pulls away and grabs a piece of charcoal. It is time. You take the charcoal and begin to draw the summoning circle. The time you have waited for is nearly here, and you swallow your distaste at what you must do to avenge your mother.
> The summoning
You have come across many different summoning procedures during your research, though you've decided to use a simple one originally created by the Cathars. Seria stands on the other side of the circle, ready to tell you the different names of each daemon you will call up. You have the incantation written somewhere among your notes, but you're confident you know it by heart.


"Quid sum miser tunc dicturus, quem patronum rogatorus, cum vix sit securus..." you intone. The charcoal lines begin to glow with dim blue light. "Ingemisco tamquam reus, culpa rubet vultus meus supplicanti parce..."


Seria's eyes are locked on your own, and you stare right back. You are hers, and she is yours. Together you will do what should have been done years ago. A flicker of fear seizes you, not fear for today but for the future. How long can you continue as a student at the College while the love of your life is a daemon? Someday, perhaps, you will have to choose, and you cannot say what your choice will be. Whatever happens, you know she will stand by your side, first to kill Hopkins and then against whatever tries to keep you apart.


"Propet hoc lugebit terra et infirmabitur omnis qui daemoniat..." Seria has a hungry look on her pale face, and the circle's lines are now very bright. It is time to call the first spirit.


"Lignor," she murmurs, and you repeat the name. The air inside the circle ripples like water, and slowly something like pale green fog begins to swirl. You continue chanting as it coalesces, growing larger and larger, and then all at once the daemon is fully there. He is a minotaur, nearly seven feet tall with curling horns and broken teeth. He bows slowly and steps outside the circle.


"Propet hoc lugebit terra et infirmabitur omnis qui daemoniat..." you chant methodically once more. This time the daemon is Nephilaxet, who would look like a perfectly ordinary merchant if it were not for the two long, curving scars that stretch from each side of his mouth to his ears. Then he smiles wide, and you notice that his gums are bright red. He too bows and takes his place beside Seria and Lignor.


Then Jarobaal, who has the head of a great viper, Semkhapu the sphinx, and Spulliso, who has no face at all, only a terrible blankness, deathly white, where eyes and the rest should be. You soon lose track of the names and each one's particular monstrous appearance, though a few, like Yfrigge, who looks for all the world like a timid, frightened six year old girl, manage to stand out. Each one bows and joins the others, watching as you call forth more and more. Last of all is Anumun, a raksha covered from head to foot with a tiger's fur and stripes, and when he bows, you see that his tail is a cobra.


Then it is done. Seria nods, and you mutter the final words of the summoning. Your eyes flicker from one daemon to the next. The room is quite full, and you guess that there are at least two dozen spirits inside. It seems excessive, far more than you need to eliminate Dr. Hopkins. Each one is staring back, and it is with a jolt that you realize that you, not Seria, are their leader. It is you who must keep them from devouring the hundreds of innocents who sleep in the College and in Covingsford.
> You speak...
Though you are not entirely sure where the words are coming from. "Tonight we will gain revenge on Dr. Hopkins. From the moment I met him, he tried to worm his way into my sympathies with jokes and a facade of kindness. I am ashamed to say it nearly work. It would have worked if it were not for Seria, for she told me the truth. Hopkins murdered my mother, a powerful spirit, and he has wronged each of you too. Tonight we will make him pay for what he has done."


It is a simple enough speech, but it seems to inspire the daemons. "We will follow you, great spellcaster," Jarobaal says. It is disconcerting to hear good English come from a snake's head, not to mention to receive obedience from a daemon, but you just nod. The others give their assent too, and Seria comes to your side.


Her voice is forceful and her face wears a sneer as she speaks of the enemy. "Hopkins is asleep in his bed, so and if fortune favors us he will be dead before he wakes. There is a chance, however, that he will raise the alarm, and then we will have a true battle on our hands." She squeezes your hand. "The students are not to be touched at first and nor are the other professors, though if they attack you may of course slaughter them. But it would be better to put the fear of daemons into their veins, to teach them never to oppose us."


You whisper a quick spell, and your window vanishes without a sound. The daemons leap out at once and you follow, commanding the wind to soften your landing. You lead them slowly from the grounds and into the streets of Covingsford, watching for any sign of trouble, but there is none. The town is silent and deserted at this time of night, and only the stars and the vast moon above witness your daemonic army on the march to Dr. Hopkins.


About halfway there, you begin to notice some muttering between two daemons near the back of your column, their voices carrying easily in the quiet. Semkhapu the sphinx seems to be arguing with the raksha Anumun, her voice nearly a hiss. "We follow where he leads and kill his target first. Then, and only then, will we settle all our other unfinished business."


Anumun growls, unable to keep his voice low. "I have waited long enough for my revenge. Bullock must die, I must feel his life petering away as his blood pools at my feet. We hardly need so many to defeat one man, no matter how strong." They go back and forth for a while, oblivious that you are listening. The other daemons can clearly hear them too, and from the looks on many of their faces, they are of the same mind as Anumun. You realize that Seria did not tell the whole truth- these spirits have little interest in Hopkins, at least most of them; they are here for their own private grievances, probably against every professor at the College.


Seria, watching you, leans in close to whisper. "They are strong and rebellious, but you are stronger by far. You can master them, make them fear and respect you. It is the only way to kill Hopkins." You nod, trying to decide how to persuade a band of daemons to follow your orders against their instincts.
> You use fear
You stop and turn to face your horde. They gather around you in a semicircle, their eyes roaming to the houses and shops that line the street, no doubt wondering which you will attack. Taking a deep breath, you speak, your voice admirably confident. "We have a ways to travel yet, but there is something I must say. Some of you, it seems, believe that I am a man to be triffled with, that I am a mere student. You believe my orders can be disobeyed, that my direct command that no one but Hopkins should be harmed does not bind you."


"Anumun," you shout, "step forward and face me." The raksha does so, his yellow eyes gleaming wildly. "You do not think we should all attack Dr. Hopkins, do you? You want to kill Bullock instead?" He simply stares, unblinking. A little disconcerted, you continue. "I have summoned you, Anumun, and I can banish you, any of you, if you are disobedient. And I can do far worse than banish you. I can end your very lives, can make your last minutes a torture so severe that you will beg for death. Now, Anumun, will you obey, or will you be destroyed?"


The raksha keeps staring as the seconds tick by. Eventually you decide that his time is up. "Very well. You others, see what will befall all who disobey, uh." Your voice cuts out when Anumun's tail, lightening fast, strikes against your throat, the cobra's fangs sinking into your skin. You feel them pushing venom into your blood, but through the sudden agony you still manage to choke out a quick spell.


Anumun is aflame in seconds, and the fire burns purple and blue and green. His howls are horrible, and you watch him writhe upon the ground. The other daemons have fighting too, though you cannot tell who is on what side. Desparately you try to think of a spell, a prayer, anything that might help you resist the poison, but it is so hard to think. You begin to twitch and the world falls away. There is only the pain, coursing through every vein in your body, boiling your blood and melting every bit of flesh.


Slowly you stop twitching, and your body becomes immobile, though the pain does not lessen. It would take almost an hour for you to die, but as luck would have it, Seria manages to kill several of the rebellious daemons and fights her way to your side. She gazes down, and though her tears burn your skin, you cannot feel them. She raises a shaking hand and, in her final gift, tears out your throat.<|endoftext|>
<|startoftext|>Though you are not entirely sure where the words are coming from. "Tonight we will gain revenge on Dr. Hopkins. From the moment I met him, he tried to worm his way into my sympathies with jokes and a facade of kindness. I am ashamed to say it nearly work. It would have worked if it were not for Seria, for she told me the truth. Hopkins murdered my mother, a powerful spirit, and he has wronged each of you too. Tonight we will make him pay for what he has done."


It is a simple enough speech, but it seems to inspire the daemons. "We will follow you, great spellcaster," Jarobaal says. It is disconcerting to hear good English come from a snake's head, not to mention to receive obedience from a daemon, but you just nod. The others give their assent too, and Seria comes to your side.


Her voice is forceful and her face wears a sneer as she speaks of the enemy. "Hopkins is asleep in his bed, so and if fortune favors us he will be dead before he wakes. There is a chance, however, that he will raise the alarm, and then we will have a true battle on our hands." She squeezes your hand. "The students are not to be touched at first and nor are the other professors, though if they attack you may of course slaughter them. But it would be better to put the fear of daemons into their veins, to teach them never to oppose us."


You whisper a quick spell, and your window vanishes without a sound. The daemons leap out at once and you follow, commanding the wind to soften your landing. You lead them slowly from the grounds and into the streets of Covingsford, watching for any sign of trouble, but there is none. The town is silent and deserted at this time of night, and only the stars and the vast moon above witness your daemonic army on the march to Dr. Hopkins.


About halfway there, you begin to notice some muttering between two daemons near the back of your column, their voices carrying easily in the quiet. Semkhapu the sphinx seems to be arguing with the raksha Anumun, her voice nearly a hiss. "We follow where he leads and kill his target first. Then, and only then, will we settle all our other unfinished business."


Anumun growls, unable to keep his voice low. "I have waited long enough for my revenge. Bullock must die, I must feel his life petering away as his blood pools at my feet. We hardly need so many to defeat one man, no matter how strong." They go back and forth for a while, oblivious that you are listening. The other daemons can clearly hear them too, and from the looks on many of their faces, they are of the same mind as Anumun. You realize that Seria did not tell the whole truth- these spirits have little interest in Hopkins, at least most of them; they are here for their own private grievances, probably against every professor at the College.


Seria, watching you, leans in close to whisper. "They are strong and rebellious, but you are stronger by far. You can master them, make them fear and respect you. It is the only way to kill Hopkins." You nod, trying to decide how to persuade a band of daemons to follow your orders against their instincts.
> You use reason
You stop and turn to face your horde. They gather around you in a semicircle, their eyes roaming to the houses and shops that line the street, no doubt wondering which you will attack. Taking a deep breath, you speak, your voice admirably confident. "We have a ways to travel yet, but there is something I must say. Some of you, it seems, disagree as to the wisdom of our plan. You wish to gain vengeance for the wrongs done to you, not just by Hopkins but by all the daemonologists. I understand that, I who have hungered for revenge ever since I learned of my mother's murder. But we have come too far to turn back now. There is too great a danger that we will be spotted, than someone will raise the general alarm. So I say we continue to Hopkins' house, and once he is dead, we can discuss our next move." 


The daemons murmur their assent, and even Anumun gives a slow bow. You certainly haven't solved the problem, but at least it won't interfere with your primarily goal. You'll just have to think of something later to dissuade or prevent them from wrecking general mayhem on the College.


In a few more minutes you are at the house. No light burns in the window, and the nearest building is a quarter mile away. You are quite fortunate that Hopkins lives on the very edge of town. The viper-headed Jarobaal comes to your side as you gaze at the door. "I am experienced in defeating defensive charms, lord," he says, his voice just barely audible. "Let me try." You nod, and he takes your place and stares. Occasionally his thin tongue flicks from his mouth. A few minutes go by, and you are nearly ready to try something else when he draws a sharp breath. The daemon begins to murmur in a strange language that makes your skin crawl, and you watch as a thousand tiny black lines form on the door, slithering together in a pattern far more complex than the one on your chest. They are still moving when he turns back to you. "It is safe."


You lead the horde through the door, which is not even locked, and it seems that Anumun was right. None of your spirits suffers any ill effects, and so you creep up the stairs. You can hear someone snoring and follow the sound. Now that the moment of revenge is finally here, you can hardly contain your excitement. Your forces gather around the bedroom door, and you give everyone a second to get ready.


Then you give the signal, and the minotaur Lignor smashes through with his great axe. There is a scream as you lead the charge, and the room is covered in the door's splintered remains. Running to the bed, you grab the figure that lies there, the words of a terrible curse already on your lips.


But you stop when you see that it is not stooped Dr. Hopkins whose neck you are gripping. It is a mousy woman in a gray nightgown, her face terrified. It is Hopkins' wife, and you shove her back roughly. A wave of disapointment washes over you, but you soon master it.
> You question the woman
"Where is your husband?" you shout, your face only inches from hers. The daemons cluster around to hear her response with bared teeth and hideous expressions.


She does not answer, and you repeat the question again. Her mouth moves, but no sound comes out, so you wait patiently for her to regain a little courage. This goes unrewarded, however, as her eventual answer is a long and surprisingly detailed string of expletives and insults against you, the daemons, and everyone you've ever known. 


Spulliso taps you on the shoulder. His blank face means, of course, that his expression is unreadable, and when he speaks his voice is similarly flat. "I can make her talk." You have no doubt that he is right, but the sight of these daemons salivating over an innocent woman has reminded you that you are different. They seek only vengeance and to inflict more suffering, most of it on innocents like Hopkins' wife, but your revenge is true justice. Hopkins killed your mother, so you will kill Hopkins, but you will not let the blank-faced man torture this woman.


You tell him so, and he slides away calmly, but your words start off a fresh round of complaints from the others. Your suggestion that they split up and search the house buys you a little more time, but you know you will have to deal with this bloodlust eventually. It does not help that the search is fruitless. Hopkins is not at home. You stare at his wife again, choosing your words with care. "You will not tell your husband that we are hunting him. If you do, I will leave you to the tender mercies of my associates here, and you will wish I had strangled you when we first arrived." She does not answer, and you doubt the warning will do any good if she does have a magical way of contacting Hopkins, but it is better than nothing.


Once you are out of the house you turn to address the daemons again. "We need to be quick. He could be anywhere in Covingsford, but I'm almost certain he is at the College. We will break into groups and search, and hopefully each will be strong enough to defeat Hopkins if they find him. If not, signal for assistance. Remember, killing anyone else will only draw more attention." They agree and divide up, grumbling but obedient for now. You stay with Seria, naturally, as well as the girl Yfrigge and Semkhapu. The others bound away into the darkness as you lead your daemons back a different way.


You enter the College through a little-used gate in the walls you discovered one evening. It is near the library, and you are unsurprised to see that lamps and candles still burn dimly behind its windows. There is almost always someone researching inside. You did not, however, anticipate the trouble this would cause.


The sphinx darts away, sniffing the wind, and returns a moment later. "There are daemonologists inside, young ones." Semkhapu's eyes are bright, and her fangs shine in the moonlight. "They are vulnerable."


"They are students," you correct, "and they are not to be touched. We need to find Hopkins, and I think he might..."


She interrupts you with a roar. "Enough about Hopkins! If you want him dead, go and tear his head from his shoulders, but I will feast on these young ones." She regards you for a second. You only have one chance to change her mind.
> You command
"You will not attack the library, I forbid it. I will banish you if you take another step towards those students," you say quickly, running the words together. Gone is the authoritative voice you used earlier, and so you are surprised when Semkhapu listens. She does not move from her spot and gazes down at the ground. Good, you think, she is humbled.


"As I was saying, I think that Hopkins might be in his office, and if not then we can look for him at a tavern. I know he favors the Stag, but there are a few other..." Your voice trails off as you notice the sphinx pawing at the ground. Puzzled, you open your mouth to ask her what she is doing when she jumps, her powerful legs pushing her through the air and onto you. You hear Seria scream and glimpse her rush towards you, but it is too late. Semkhapu's huge jaws have locked onto your head, swallowing up your entire upper body, and with a great and sickening crunch she severs you in half.


Then she gives a screeching roar and falls back, and your frenzied brain can just barely make out Seria, holding the sphinx's spine in her hands, her face full of rage. Their screams mingle as you pass, and by the time Seria comes to cradle your head you are gone. You hope she will track down Hopkins out of love for you and tear out his spine as well, but die not knowing if your mother will ever be avenged.<|endoftext|>

You chose a particularly vicious incantation, and you watch Semkhapu writhe as her organs melt away. In less than a minute she is nothing but a little fog, and then her essence fades away completely.


"I trust we may now continue to our real enemy?" you ask, and Yfrigge nods. These delays are making you angrier and angrier, and you make a split-second decision. "Seria, you and Yfrigge go to Hopkins' office. I doubt the others are still even searching for him, so it is up to us to ensure that my mother's killer dies tonight." Yfrigge nods again, but Seria looks concerned.


"We may not be strong enough to defeat him, and your blood has not yet awakened. It would be safer to stick together." She comes closer. "I will not lose you."


You pull her in for a quick kiss. "We will never win if our goal is to remain safe. I hate to leave you, but we must. Those fools will probably alert every daemonologist in Covingsford to our attack, and we'll have little time before they gather together. No, we need to find Hopkins and kill him now, and the best way to do that is to split up. But I am yours, and you are mine, and I promise I will come back to you." Seria holds you close for a moment, and then you explain how to find the professor's office.


They depart, and you head for town to begin searching the taverns. It is infuriating that you have not already found Hopkins, and for the first time you let yourself consider the possibility that you will not get your revenge before the night ends. The professors will, you hope, manage to repel the daemons' attacks, and Seria will likely remain safe. But will they uncover your role in all this? You could be expelled, and, you realize, even hanged for what you've done, and if Hopkins still lives then it would all be for nothing.


You double your pace, nearly out of the grounds, when you hear something moving near the wall. At first you think it might be a daemon, but then a figure comes into view, stumbling a little.  You guess that he is drunk, and no daemon that you have heard of would touch alcohol. The person leans against the wall to catch his breath and you sneak closer, but the shadows hide his face and he wears a long cloak. Probably a student, you decide, and are about to leave when he steps away from the wall.
> The figure emerges into the moonlight
He meanders towards the College buildings, his back stooped, and then he catch a glimpse of his face. It is Dr. Hopkins.


Instantly you leap forward and, before he can react, chant an immobilizing spell. His legs and arms lock, as does his face, and he falls to the ground with a dull thud. His eyes still move, however, and when you step into his field of vision they widen in shock. You breath deeply, staring down at the man who you have hunted, everything else forgotten. You would never have imagined that it would be so simple, that you would be this lucky.


You spent a long time thinking of what to say when the time came, trying to decide whether Hopkins deserved any explanation as to why you were killing him. You liked the idea of filling his final minutes with terrified confusion as he wondered why his student would put him to death. But, you eventually realized, that would be doing your mother a disservice. He had not given her any warning or explanation, had killed her without much thought at all, and you refuse to sink to his level. No, he will learn exactly why he deserves to die, and then you will kill him.


"Do you remember my father, sir? you begin, savoring each word. "A large man, taller and broader than me, and a businessman of some importance. I believe he once came to speak with you. I would not be surprised if you do not remember, though. It was quite some time ago." Hopkins, of course, cannot respond, but his eyes are fixed on yours. "He told you how you killed my mother. He never told me, not until we forced the words from his mouth, but he told you. I believe he was trying to get revenge, but something you said made him give up the idea. Do you remember what it was?"


You pause. "I'll remind you. You explained that her death was an accident, a tragedy caused by an ill-chosen bit of magic which you used to destroy a rogue daemon. It was a tragedy, sir, for her. You see, she was an angel, sweeter and more lovely than any human woman, and you killed her without even sparing a thought. It was a tragedy for me too, as I grew up without a mother, and with a father whose only response to the tragedy was to forgive. And, I suppose, to mistreat me and never bother to inform me of my true nature."


These last words remind you that your blood has yet to awaken. You think that perhaps Hopkins is thinking the same thing, so you keep speaking. "But my mother's blood is still a precious gift, sir. I am strong, stronger than you even without my full power, and I will not need much strength now." You bend down and pull open Hopkins' cloak and, while he watches, remove his own silver knife. The blade is clean and sharp. It feels good in your hand, and you run your thumb along its edge as you speak. "I never imagined I would find you like this, drunk and powerless. I pictured a titantic battle, but this is somehow even sweeter." You pull him up by his hair and place the knife against his throat. "I am going to kill you in a moment," you add, "but first I will let you speak. This is justice, and justice demands you have a chance to defend yourself. One word of any spell, however, and you will die even more disgraced than you already are."


You release the spell on his face, and Dr. Hopkins immediately screams in pain. You wait for him to stop, and he does, and a few seconds later he beings to speak. "My boy," he begins, but you push the knife a little against his skin and he changes his tone. "It is true, everything you have said is true. I killed your mother with a hastily chosen spell, and it has haunted me ever since. A daemon had escaped confinement, and I had to act. I did not know there was another spirit in Covingsford, but...but I do not wish to defend myself. I should have been more careful, I should have tracked the daemon down and banished it."


You did not expect this, but your cold hatred does not abate. "And yet you said nothing to me. You made jokes and laughed as though you were an innocent man, you dared to lecture us about combating evil."


"I was weak. I am weak, and when I learned that your father chose not to tell you of your heritage, I felt I could not contradict him. I feared...I suppose I feared exactly what has come to pass. But now, enough talk. I am ready to die, truly I am. I know I am guilty. Give me what I deserve." He closes his mouth and shuts his eyes, though he draws quick, rattling breaths.


You squeeze the knife, and it is your mother's face which you picture. After so many years, she will finally be avenged, her murderer will pay for his crime. She was innocent, was pure and kind, and Hopkins killed her. The knife is in his skin and draws a drop of blood.
> You kill him
"Give me what I deserve." Hopkins' words fill your mind as you open his throat, and when the hot blood pours out onto your hands, you feel no jubilation. This is justice, impartial and complete, blood for blood and life for life. He cannot help but scream as he dies, but you barely hear his cries. Your mind is fixed completely on your mother, on her face in the portrait that you have known for so long. She can rest in peace now, you know, and justice has been done.


Justice. It is a simple enough thing, and yet, as you release Hopkins' corpse from your spell and watch it sprawl out into the pool of blood, it can be messy indeed. The daemons you summoned, the ones who did nothing to help avenge your mother and cared only about settling their own grudges and causing mayhem, they care nothing for justice. Even now, you realize, they are probably killing the innocent for their own vile pleasure. The thought disgusts you, and you set off immediately to try to find and stop them. It is likely to late to prevent every death, but you know you must do the best that you can.


As you walk through the grounds, you think about Seria and her role in what you have done. Unlike all the others, she helped you get revenge. Without her you would never have even known about your father's sins and Hopkins' evil, and you certainly would not be here tonight, walking from his bloody corpse. Your heart swells with love as you picture her face, pale and beautiful. She is probably trying to stop the other daemons too, trying to make sure they do not shed any more blood than is neccesary. Hopkins was right; she is not evil, and she proved it by helping you kill him.


You wonder why you ever thought there was a conflict between your love for Seria and your calling as a daemonologist. After all, what is your calling but to pursue justice, protecting the innocent and punishing the guilty? You were far too late to protect your mother, but you punished her killer, and in the future you and Seria will do the same across the world. You are bound by love and by blood, and nothing can stand in your way.


You can make out a good deal of noise coming from the center of the grounds, and you hurry towards it. It is a jumble of sounds, chanting in many languages mixes with howls and shouts of pains, and when the scene comes into view it is precisely as you had feared. The daemons have gone berserk, fighting indiscriminately against the College's professors. The sight is sickening, but you are not afraid.
> The battle is fierce
As you run to the action, you see that a few bodies already lie scattered across the ground in front of the library. But there are still many fighting, many professors and, you realize with a jerk, a few students too. You survey the scene, wondering how to stem the flow of blood that has accompanied your revenge and looking for Seria. Dr. Thewliss, Dr. Coghill, and a few others you don't recognize are clustered in one corner, Dr. Bullock, several other professors, and two students are in another, and in the center of it all, Chancellor Fogg stands alone.


Each battles several daemons, though you note with hope that their ranks have thinned, too. The minotaur Lignor and a handful of others face Thewliss' band while the raksha Anumun and Yfrigge, still wearing the guise of a young girl, fight Bullock. The Chancellor has the most enemies- Jarobaal, blank-faced Spulliso, four daemons you don't recognize, and, you are surprised to see, Seria, her flaming eyes shining brighter than the stars above. He must have attacked her, you realize, or she would not have joined in the brawl.


Since Bullock is the closest, you run forward down to help him beat back the daemon's savage attacks. He is an unpleasant man, but he does not deserve to die. He wears a set of silver knuckles and throws punch after punch with his powerful arms. Anumun's claws are deadly too, and the two are locked in an intricate and lethal dance. You begin to chant while the daemon is distracted, but you are just a little to slow. He manages to slash Dr. Bullock across his chest and then his throat, and you watch the man die. Anumun does not have long to exult in his victory, however, as he is soon set aflame, the fire burning blue and green and purple. In a minute he is dead.


You turn to Yfrigge. Even alone she is dangerous, and you do not let your guard down. When she sees you she simply frowns. "Twice traitor." Seemingly without effort, she knocks all her other enemies back and begins walking towards you. You hold your ground and start another spell, but her power is great. She is not as strong as you, but vanquishing her magical defenses will take time, and all the while she is coming closer and closer. You back up, still chanting, but she shows no sign of weakening. Fumbling in your pockets, you look for something, anything that you could throw, but there is nothing. She is three yards away, one yard, one foot.


Suddenly one of the other students launches himself at her, and they go tumbling together into the grass. He has nothing but a rock, but he makes good use of it, bashing her skull open and flattening it for good measure. Yfrigge screams long after a human being would have died, but the rock and your chanting is enough to defeat her. You watch as her body sinks into the ground. A little essence oozes out and gets carried off the by the wind. Yfrigge's assailent clambers up off the ground. It is John Keating, scraped and glowering but very much alive. "Kind of you to join us," he grunts. You remember how he has teased Peter and make his life miserable for the past few months. He does not deserve death, but you mutter a quick curse, and he falls to the ground howling as your bolt of electricity strikes his side. Justice.


You see that Dr. Thewliss now fights alone against the minotaur, whose enormous axe cannot quite catch the tiny man, though he is not nearly as quick as he was before. Chancellor Fogg has defeated one of the daemons, but Jarobaal, Spulliso, Seria, and three others press him close. The old titan is faltering, and you remember how he seemed to you when you were young, a perfect image of the daemonologist.


The other professor and the students run to aid Dr. Thewliss while you head for Fogg. His long beard is smoldering, though you can't tell if it's from a daemon's attack or the sheer power he's wielding. Seria sees you coming and smiles, those dark lips so beautiful beneath the moon. You mouth a spell, one you encountered scribbled in the margin of an old Greek translation of an Egyptian manuscript, and one of the other daemons yelps. His scaly wings begin to convulse, covered in what looks like a moving blanket, and soon the pain reaches the rest of his body. The other daemons stop a moment to watch the thousand scarab beetles devour him, which gives the Chancellor time to eliminate another with a word.


Seria runs to your side, away from the fight, but then you hear a cry. The minotaur has finally caught Thewliss, his body split in half by the huge blade. You remember his kindness, how happy he was when you passed your entrance examination and how he gave you the ankh. The others circle the daemon, wary of being next, but Lignor just bellows and keeps swinging. Peter is among them, you realize, his eyes glinting beneath the moon as he mouths spell after spell.


Seria reaches you, every motion sleek and seductive. Her eyes are no longer like fire. They are dark and beautiful, but there is a hint of flame there too. "What have you done?" she asks softly.
> You say "Justice"
The hint of flame in Seria's eyes is swallowed up by dark beauty, and she glides to your side, wrapping her slender, porcelain arms around your neck. You wrap your own around her waist, and your lips meet, the Chancellor and daemons forgotten. When you finally break the kiss, she gestures to Fogg, still locked in combat with Jarobaal and Spulliso. "He began it," she says, her voice half-taunting, half-apologetic.


"Hopkins did not," you reply, "and I killed him much quicker. You must be losing your touch, my love, but I am here now." She flicks her tongue and turns back to the Chancellor, whose breath now comes in gasps. He still manages to sputter incantations, though, and you would be a fool to consider him beaten. Your voice is clear as you begin to chant, pitting your power against the greatest of the daemonologists for the first time, and you feel neither fear nor nor anger. You had no quarrel with Fogg before this day, but he attacked your love, and for that crime he must die.


Your mother's blood may not have awakened, but you feel a surge of strength as you watch Seria, fighting with nothing but her nails and pointed teeth. The Chancellor has erected some kind of magical barrier, and your succubus whirls around him like dark lightening, slashing with wild elegance for the tiniest fracture in his protection. He pays her no attention and likewise ignores Jarobaal, who is once again hissing in some strange tongue, and Spulliso, who paces slowly in a great circle around the brawl. No, it is you who Fogg stares at, you who have become the target of his magic.


You are younger and fresher, however, and you can sense his power weakening. Seria manages to get closer and closer with each passing moment, and you know that soon it will be over. Whether it will be your spells or her lovely, lethal body, he is not long for the world. You focus on the man, watching his every motion to prevent some last, desperate act of trickery, but he does not attempt any tricks. <|startoftext|>He meanders towards the College buildings, his back stooped, and then he catch a glimpse of his face. It is Dr. Hopkins.

His eyes still move, however, and when you step into his field of vision they widen in shock. You breath deeply, staring down at the man who you have hunted, everything else forgotten. You would never have imagined that it would be so simple, that you would be this lucky.


You spent a long time thinking of what to say when the time came, trying to decide whether Hopkins deserved any explanation as to why you were killing him. You liked the idea of filling his final minutes with terrified confusion as he wondered why his student would put him to death. But, you eventually realized, that would be doing your mother a disservice. He had not given her any warning or explanation, had killed her without much thought at all, and you refuse to sink to his level. > You family history (Background)
The Latimers are an old merchant family, moderately wealthy burghers of Covingsford. Your great-grandfather sold wool, your grandfather invested in lead and copper mines in the southwest, and your father has a hand in everything. He owns shares of shipping companies, printing houses, steel foundries, slaughterhouses, insurance brokerages, and plantations in America (though he's had some trouble collecting payments since the war started). Your mother Amelia died from eclampsia shortly after giving birth to you. Her picture hangs in Augustus's study. She was thin and pretty, quite the contrast from your father. You favor her looks. When you were younger, you used to gaze at the picture for hours, wondering what she was like and why she had to die.


Your brother Charles is five years older, a broad-shouldered man of business just like your father. He spends half his time in London, managing the Latimer properties there, and even when he comes home he has little time for a bookish younger brother. > The world (Background)
Britain in 1777 is, as everyone knows, the center of the civilized and Christian world. King George is hardly popular, what with the troubles in America and at home, but the nation faces no real threat from the rebels, the French, or any other power. The British Navy rules the seas, British merchants and manufacturers are the wealthiest on the globe, and the English Church is well-known as the most learned and pious communion among the many factions of Christendom, perfectly suited for a humble and pious people. Literature and the arts are flourishing, as are the natural sciences, a testament to the superiority of British education and culture over the Continent. British power stretches from sea to sea, from America to India.


Security is never assured, however. The American rebels have the audacity (and stupidity) to seek independence, and though the war is not going poorly, it does seem to be dragging on rather longer than anyone anticipated. There is always the chance that France will ally with the colonies, which, though hardly enough to defeat His Majesty's forces on land and sea, would certainly be an annoyance.


And danger is always possible from the daemonic realm. Though a Christian people like the British need not fear for the sake of their souls, daemons can do a great deal of harm to their bodies and their property. They are constantly seeking to attack, to torment, and to tempt human beings, to draw them away from God and towards ruin. Though the Church and her ministers oppose them from the pulpit, it falls to the daemonologists to oppose them in the field of battle. 


In Britain, these defenders are trained (at least formally) only at Covingsford, but other countries have their own institution- the French at Poitiers, the Austrians at Prague, and so on. No power, not even the pagans of the East or the infidel Turks, would be mad enough actually ally with the daemonic forces, no matter how dire the need, but there are always individuals who are desperate or greedy enough to do so. So the daemonologists must always be ready. <|endoftext|>

You stumble several times, but eventually make your way to your door.The college dorm hall is in complete darkness. You hear the sound of girls screaming and guys laughing. You see your RA, Peter, stomping down the hallway.


"What's going on?" you ask him.


"Just go back to your room. The power is out right now. No one is allowed to leave."


"But I have a 10 page paper to finish!"


Peter shrugs his shoulders. "I'm sorry, I can't help you there."


He keeps walking down the hallway, eventually getting swallowed by the abyss of darkness.


You sigh and head back to your desk to turn on your laptop. You find it strange that your laptop turned off with the power outage, especially since your battery is in pretty good condition. Maybe the power outage caused some weird electrical impulse to surge through your laptop and crash the system? Perhaps you clicked on something you weren't supposed to. What if you caused the power outage?! Nevertheless, you boot up the desktop and search for your paper.


"Uh oh...the paper didn't save!"


It looks like you'll have to start all over again! You feel your inner primate sense wanting to throw the laptop across the wall. Your laptop's battery is at 60%, so ideally you do have more than a couple hours without power to go. You try to brainstorm ideas on what to do now...


Important Choice: Do you risk leaving the dorm to get your paper done? OR Do you stay here and wait for the power to go back on?
> You risk leaving dorm to get paper done.
You have decided to risk leaving the dorm to get your paper done.


Grabbing your laptop, you unplug the power brick and slide everything into your back pack. How are you supposed to type your paper in this darkness? Who knows how long it will take for the power to go back on. Slowly, you tip-toe your way to the front door and gently rest your ear on the cold surface. You don't hear much, besides the chirping of crickets from outside your window.


You put your hand on your door handle and slowly open the door. Peaking your eyes out like a hawk, you search for Peter. The hallway is completely shrouded in darkness. Even if Peter was outside, he probably would have no chance of seeing anyone.


Like a sly fox, you slide out of your dorm room and gently pull the door shut. 


click


The door silently locks in place.

Despite the fact that the dorm hall is in darkness, your eyes get used to your surroundings. As you make your way to the stairwell, you hear Peter. 


"I swear, if I catch anyone that sneaks out of their dorms, they are going to be in some serious trouble!"


Uh-oh. Better hide from Peter! The door to the staircase opens, just as quickly, Peter comes out and dashes down the hall. As the door is closing, you slide in between the open threshold and make your way outside.


The smell of freshly cut grass, the sound of crickets chirping in the night, the crescent moon in the sky...it feels good to be free from that dorm room. You make your way down the path to a fork in the sidewalk. 


On one side, you see a peaceful looking bench in the college park. On the other side, there's the way to the campus library. 


Decisions decisions.
> You go to the Park Bench
You make your way to the park bench and sit down. Surrounding the bench are several oak trees. You can hear the sound of an owl from high up above. 


Hoo hoo! Hoo hoo!


Unzipping your backpack, you pull out your laptop and continue typing your paper. The relaxation of being outside clears your mind, and you manage to take out another page of your paper along the way. 


Pages increased by 1!
> You continue

"That's crazy! I can't believe that something like that could happen here! It's not even storming or anything either."


You nod in agreement at Nick's observation. Perhaps it wasn't a storm, but instead a crazy college scheme that caused the power to go out. Whatever the case may be, you have a paper to finish.


Nick pulls out his phone and starts scrolling through it. 


"I've been seeing the craziest snapchats of the frat party tonight! Did you finish your paper so we can go?"


You look at Nick, eyes gleaming at his phone in excitement. As far as you know, Nick doesn't have too many friends, and he's been so adamant on wanting you to go to this party with him. You look at your laptop page count and then back at him. Maybe going to the party for an hour will alleviate some stress. It's not like you'll be there the whole night. What's the worse that can happen?


On the other hand, what if Nick gets drunk? You'll end up spending the rest of the night watching him and making sure he doesn't do anything stupid. Or you could just tell Nick that you haven't finished the paper yet and need to get it done. That frat party does sound pretty fun though...


"I..uh..well..."

Nick lets out a sarcastic laugh. "Yeah, and so is laziness...I have an idea."

Important Choice: Do you risk leaving the dorm to get your paper done? OR Do you stay here and wait for the power to go back on?
> You stay in the dorm and wait for the power to go back on.
You have decided to stay in the dorm and wait for the power to go back on.


The dark doesn't scare you! Opening your laptop, you go back to Microsoft Word and start typing your paper again. Your laptop battery happens to be at 50%, which should be good enough for a couple hours...you hope...


With the power being out in your dorm, you realize how quiet the place really is. All you can hear is the sound of crickets chirping. Occasionally, you'll hear Peter, your dorm RA, pacing back and forth in the hallway. Other than that, it is the most peaceful place you've ever encountered it to be.


After about half an hour, you finish a page of your paper. Way to go!


Pages increased by 1! 


Knock Knock Knock!


Looks like someone is at the door. Quickly, you save your paper and walk over to the knocking sound.


"Who's there?" you ask calmly.


"It's Peter, the RA." you hear Peter's voice from the outside the door. He sounds like he's been breathing heavily. You open the door and are attacked by a wave of bright lights. 


"My eyes!" you shout loudly. Peter moves his phone from your face.


"Oh crap! I'm sorry. Didn't think you'd open the door that fast!"


"How's the power situation coming along?" you ask him. From what you can see through the abyss of complete darkness - save for Peter's lighthouse of a phone's camera flash - Peter sighs and rests his back on the wall next to your door. 


"It looks like the power situation is going to be much worse than we thought. I'm coming by to let people know that they can leave the dorms for now. As it turns out; however, people are sneaking out! Little do they know, they're going to get quite the write up when they get back."


You sigh in relief that Peter can't see your pale face in the dorm hallway. Good thing you didn't risk sneaking out of the dorm. 


"Anyway, I really appreciate that you listened to me. After all, safety comes first."


With that, Peter walks away, allowing you to leave your dorm. You step back inside your room to grab you belongings. Good thing you got at least another page done! With your laptop battery on the verge of dying soon, you figure finding someplace else to do your paper would be the best course of action. You step outside, lock your door, and make your way down the staircase to the exit.
> You continue
The smell of freshly cut grass, the sound of crickets chirping in the night, the crescent moon in the sky...it feels good to be free from that dorm room. You make your way along the path and come to a fork in the sidewalk.


On one side, you have a peaceful looking bench in the college park. You suppose you could get a page of your paper done there. The weather is pretty warm for a Friday, and you don't recall seeing rain in the weather's forecast. On the other side, there's the way to the campus library. The campus library could be a pretty relaxing place to get work done as well. (And it has power!)


Decisions decisions.<|endoftext|>

- Try to make honest decisions, it will make the story much more meaningful to you.

<|startoftext|>When you first laid eyes on her she was unconscious. And underwater. But, she was still an amazing sight.

You had been snorkeling off the coast of your seclude island you live on, in taking the beauty of the multi colored fish and billowing sea plants. You see fish wandering over to a part of the ocean you hadn’t snorkeled near before. Curious, you followed them and were shocked to find a girl lying unconscious on the ocean floor. You immediately plunge down and grab the girl, pulling her to the shore.

You didn’t know much about CPR, with living alone on an island and all, but luckily you didn’t need to. As soon as she reached the surface she started breathing. You carry her from the soft sand to your hut made out of sticks and palm leaves and you laid her on your couch. Years before you lived on the island you had packed up everything you owned in your house that didn’t need electricity and basically moved to the seclude island. You were fed up with all the noise of the city and you decided you wanted to become a hermit—with the basic comforts of modern day like a bed, couch, and other furniture.

As she lay on your couch, you were able to get a good look at her. Her brown hair was like a waterfall on her shoulders and she wore a silk blue satin dress that flowed on her legs like a mermaid tail. She obviously wasn’t dressed for swimming. You thought that maybe she just fell overboard from a boat and the crash knocked her out. Though why she was so close to shore, you didn’t know.

Hours later, she comes to. She opens her marble blue eyes and looks around, looking quite scared. She spots you and her eyes widen and she tenses up. You have to calm her down.

 
> You soothe like a mother

> You ask her name

"I-I'm not ready," she stutters quietly, not looking away from you.

"You talked," you whisper, leaning lightly against the wall. "If you can talk at all, I think you're ready to tell me your name."

She looks down at the floor. "Marina."

"Marina?" You almost laugh. "I've never heard of any name like that."

"My parents were from Spain, so they wanted to give me a Spanish name. They named me after part of the word 'seasalt' in Spanish. Sal marina is seasalt in Spanish. Sal wasn't a very suitable name, so they went with Marina."
