<|startoftext|>You thrust a final time, your ragged cry of release filling the air and startling a pair of birds overhead. As they wing away you clutch Mondy to you, whispering, “Thank you,” and kissing him passionately as the scarlet leaves overhead drift down onto his golden hair.

These last couple of years have been hell. The two of you had your love put to the test more than ever before. It’s been utterly draining--physically, emotionally, financially--but as you look into Mondy’s eyes you know it was all worthwhile, and you know he feels the same. Such a warm feeling of peace and joy suffuses you, and you can’t help but kiss him again.

Days drift by, careless and lazy.

The two of you spend the evenings fishing, and during the day you glean whatever you can find from the overgrown fields. Mondy is still in recovery from his long illness and a bit weak, so the bulk of the work falls on you. Not that you mind. The days are quiet and peaceful, and it’s a joy just to be alive as you greet each sunrise, your love at your side.

It’s really just the two of you out here now; there were only a handful left in the village after the sickness came, and since then they’ve all packed up and left. No future out here. You heard those words often enough, even in your younger days, and there was even a time you believed it.

And of course, there were uglier words.
> You days past
The first meeting with Mondy came while dropping off a necklace of your mother’s. The clasp needed repairing, and he was still a jeweler’s apprentice then. You’d always been considered eccentric, and Mother had stopped bothering to ask you when her dear boy Mirk was going to find a nice girl and give her a grandchild long ago. You’d expected you’d die alone, and a virgin, if you were being completely honest with yourself. But when you met Mondy...there was a spark between the two of you immediately, and before long it lit a bonfire in your heart.

The two of you had never tried to hide your love.

At first, when you and Mondy pledged yourselves to one another under the tree on the hill, and then again in the village square, the others had been...accepting enough, even if a few of them clearly thought the both of you mad. But your mother had given you her blessing, and took Mondy into her heart almost as a second son, and that was the most important thing.

Near the end, however, things changed. Personally, you blame the priest. Or perhaps it was the sickness weighing so heavily on everyone’s souls that turned them twisted and cold. But the looks grew darker. The whispers grow uglier, and then stopped being whispers at all. They said the love you shared was an abomination. The priest stood in he doorway of the church and thundered that a demon had poisoned your mind.

Any of that, all of that...you could have borne without complaint, and gone on about your life. Mondy’s love was all you needed. But when your mother lay on her deathbed, and her last words were begging you to leave the man you loved? It broke something inside of you.

After her funeral you and Mondy had a long talk...a long cry, really, on your part. There was never a question of you leaving him, of course. For your mother to even suggest it felt like a betrayal, though you knew she wasn’t herself. She was weak, ill, just like Mondy had been, and being quite old and frail as well her mind had easily been poisoned against you.

But the two of you knew when you were no longer welcome, retreated from life in the village, and moved to a cottage on the other side of the hill. Eventually, the others all left. “Good riddance to that lot,” you’d muttered to Mondy, watching the last cart being drawn away. “We can do as we like now.”


What would you like to do?
> You look around the cottage
The cottage--well, it’s more like a shack--has seen better days. And it wasn’t much even back then.

The fire has gone out, and the only light comes from the gaps in the boards that are now also letting in the icy bite of winter. It’s early for a first frost, and you have a feeling this year may be a bad one.

Opening the pantry, you find nothing but a cloud of dust that drives you into a coughing fit. Sneaking a guilty glance at where Mondy is resting on the bed, you relax when you see you haven’t wakened him. He was sick for so long, on the verge of death, that even now he hasn’t recovered his strength, and you worry constantly he’ll have a relapse.

There’s no firewood in the box. How long has it been since you’ve replenished it? You really have been letting things slip around here. Perhaps it’s time you start thinking more seriously about what you’ll do in the coming days. To tell the truth, you’re not confident anything about this place will be enough protection in a bad freeze or heavy snow.
> You walk to your tree
This tree at the top of the hill--a sugar maple--as a lonely, awkward little boy you would play here, and when Mondy came into your life it was the place the two of you would sit and talk for hours, even before you finally mustered up the courage to say the words that had gone unspoken so long between you. You’ve been calling it ‘our’ tree for the last four years, whenever either of you speak of it.

Your hand caresses well known lines in the bark; a heart with the names Mirk and Mondy inside. On impulse you pull out your knife and carve it all in deeper.

The branches are bare now, and the wind up here is quite a bit stronger, and carries a bitter chill. You really ought to find some firewood and supplies. Can’t have Mondy getting sick again.

Below, you see the abandoned shops and dwellings of your old village, huddled together around the little church you eventually came to hate.<|endoftext|>
<|startoftext|>Your life was perfect before. For generations your family ruled over the land stretching before your eyes.

It endured long forgotten wars. It endured cataclysms of epic proportions. It had even endured your own mistakes in your youth.

It was here that you were born and raised. Your childhood was a happy collection of bygone memories, your adolescence bitter of strife and uproar. This land molded you into the man you were supposed to be. Its stark streams taught you caution; its rolling hills forced you to become more perceptive; the people infected you with their stoicism. 

This all made you into the man you are now. As you stand up from your seat, you look onwards, onto your land. The calm skies glace over mortal matters peacefully, the tall trees croak their ever enigmatic song and the rolling hills lie peaceful in their eternal rest. They are all indifferent to your hardship. 

"Sir, we have found the den!" An overeager young page runs up. The excitement is practically dripping off his face. You force yourself to smile. 

"Well done boy. Go to Garreth and tell him to prepare the dogs."

"Yessir, at once sir."

You watch the boy, a decade old page now, run back into the forest. Life hadn't broken him yet.

"Alright lads," you yell. "You heard the boy. Mount up and let us catch the bastard. By tonight I want my belly filled with tough meat and my head full of cheap ale!"

Around you a group of sixteen knights perk up, yell their approval and jump on their horses. The action forces your worries away. Moments later you feel the cold wind of air passing by your face as you gallop onward. You leave the hills behind as you enter the forest, through the road your ancestors paved so long ago.

Onwards, onto the hunt indeed.
> A hunt you need.
The ancient path has many different splits and many curves. Some stretches are littered with holes and tough roots, others are steep enough to warrant dismounting. Most routes have overgrown entirely, their destination long forgotten. You know the road to Garreth's place well. It's a longer route, the only one available with a party your size. 

It is here that you often found peace in dire times. It is here that you refound your determination and often regained your blinding energy. Already you feel the woods taking in your sorrow, the ache trailing behind you as you trot forwards. Slowly the sympathetic bushes around you make way for the ancient oaks your house is known for. You soon hear the familiar sound of splashing water.

At the waterfall, you hold up your hand. You have to stop here.

"Sir Myre, take the horses and let them drink here. You two," you point at two novice knights too anxious for your taste. "Accompany him and keep your eyes open. You never know what the ancients have in store for us."

"Good luck, Sir," the old knight responds dutifully to your surprise. "And give Garreth my regards."

"Thank you, Myre. We will be back in a few hours." You turn around to face the rest of your group. "Follow me. The huntsman is just a few minutes from here."

You expected some reluctance from Myre; it's nothing for him to easily shy away from glory. You dismount and retreat back into your thoughts as you climb the familiar steps from your childhood. Had he noticed your sorrow, your anger? Did anyone else? Would you even want them to?

With these questions in mind, you reach the top. A quick glance shows your loyal knights trailing behind you. Ahead of you is a small dirt path leading to a seemingly abandoned hut. Next to it the young page anxiously shifts his weights from one leg to the other, as he stares into the forest.

"Boy." The young lad practically jumps into the air. "Did you give notice to Garreth?"

"Yessir, I did! He's right inside." His skin had transformed into a white pallor. "And sorry about my reaction, Sir."

"Never focus your attention on just one splot lad. You let your own state of mind cloud the reality which surrounds you."

You realize the same could be said of yourself.

You shake the thought and give a knowing nod to the knights surrounding you. Let them cheer the now downtrodden boy up while you enter the hut.


 

 
> You garreth awaits.
As you enter the hut, you are taken back by memories. Scenes of a furious father force themselves up. You fled him and his beatings, into the arms of your unofficial mentor. Garreth was never one to bow to civilization, and he was the only one capable of standing up to the former baron.

He stands in front of you. His deepset eyes are exacerbated by the darkness in the room; they have an unnatural sharpness, focussing entirely on you.

"There is something wrong," Garreth notes. He saw straight through the facade you upheld. He always did. "Tell me, what is it and who knows."

A heavy sigh escapes your chest. Dead air that you had held on to all day forces its way up, and with it your repressed thoughts. They all come together, clashing to assert themselves first. "It's my wife. She... The duke! She..-"

"You are not ready yet. Compose yourself! There are men waiting for you outside, and now is not the time for weakness. Put it aside and focus on the here and the now." The old huntsman snatches your jaw and forces you to look up.

"My dogs smelled something far better than whatever you castle folk found. There's been an immigration of bears into the area. Now, will you continue to wallow in your own self pity? Or will you become the man I've trained and join me in my hunt?"

The words do nothing to quiet the internal turmoil you feel. You sense the pressure building in your cheeks, behind your eyes. You hurt. It's a hurt that you never felt before; it's something lonely and depressing, as if the rotten roof is solely supported by your own failing shoulders. As hard as you try, you can't hold it. You can't hold back. The world around you crashes and collapses until you are left alone in a sea of darkness. You can't swim; the sea envelops you, swallows you whole.

A slap forces you out of your inner battleground. You force your nausea down. 

"Why did you do that?" You let some anger seep into your voice.

"Why did you let me?" Garreth replies unfazed.

The old man had a point. Your attention shifts outwards yet again. 

"Weakness," you grumble in response. It's answered with a curt nod.

You pressure the heavy laden sadness to transform itself into an icy determination. Numb and seemingly several years older you once again face your old mentor eye to eye.

"Lead the way," you hear yourself say.


 

 
> You both go outside.
It's eerily quiet. You crouch through the thick underbrush, carefully planting your feet where there's still green vegetation. In your right hand, you hold the leashes of the hunting dogs; in your left, you hold a long sturdy spear. It should be enough to face your prey.

You are surrounded by grim faces. Most of them are veterans. Garreth is up front as always. Compared to him even the veterans are inexperienced amateurs.

His hand shoots up. Everybody halts in their steps. He motions you forward.

"Two prey, still oblivious." His hand points to two black silhouettes.

"Any vultures?" He always had superior eyesight.

"Nothing, we are clear."

You look towards the most experienced of your hunting party and signal a split. A nod of acknowledgment and a pincer maneuver is executed. The wind tears your eyes as you wait for the two teams to sneak into position. You are left alone with Garreth, the dogs and mainly your thoughts.

"Now."

You release the dogs. They don't bark; they don't growl. As a soundless mass, they charge forwards. You both move closer. The bears are alarmed. A deep resonating roar fills the space between the trees. Moments later, you hear the impact. The dogs throw themselves at the bears, oblivious to any danger. Some are swatted away; others succeed and bite into the resilient skin. The hounds have no hope of killing the beasts. At best they will succeed in keeping them distracted and pinned down.

The two hunting parties now move in, their long spears ready and in formation.

This is what you live for. The battle, the carnage makes you feel alive. You are yet again master of your surroundings, master of your own fate. Garreth has seen enough and looks back at you.

"You are back. I've missed you." A small smile escapes his lips as he closes his eyes.

That was not something he said easily.

"Not back, just recovering." You return the smile. "You shouldn't let me hold you back. Enjoy your hunt, partake in the glory."

"My boy, once you reach my age you'll know a clear victory when you spot it."

Your mentor leaves you nevertheless. 

One bear has now been skewered and held in its place. Its defeated moans tell the world its a threat no longer. The other one, a stronger and more ferocious beast altogether, holds its own against the tide. It crushes one dog beneath its leg. It mauls another with its enormous claws and then rushes through the wall of spears, ruthlessly disrupting any plan of encirclement your party might once have had.

That's when Garreth arrives. He makes himself a big target, yelling at the top of his longs to draw attention. The beast is provoked. He crouches as it charges. At the last moment, he rolls forwards, stabbing his dagger at the soft underbelly. It happens so fast. He stands up, bloodied.

Meanwhile, the other hunters have rallied themselves. They skillfully close the ranks, leaving their target encapsulated in an ever-shrinking circle of spears. The old man had prevented chaos, but they did not allow him to claim the glory. Their advancement goes steadily, step by step. The trap had been laid and set.

The bear checks its solidity. Agitated, it paces around, angry at being denied its kill. Its wild eyes frantically search for any point of weakness. With angry roars, it makes its failure known.

That's when the hair on your neck starts to rise and something tells you to run. You try to duck and turn around, but a bone-shattering force hits your back.

You fly to the ground. Your world goes black for a moment as you hear a deafening roar mere inches from your head. Pretending to be dead, you hear panicked shouting. Sounds of battle are drawing closer and time crawls into a standstill.

Your body is numb once again. You strain yourself to look up and into the beast's maw. There is a moment of recognition. Its brown eyes stare into yours and you see your wife's in them. The battle around you fades away as she calls to you, as she soothes you. My Isa..

She tries to pull you into her memories. You look up and you see..
> The love of your life.
Isabella...

You first met her during a long voyage. Both of you were so young and full of life. You fell in love with her laugh, with the twinkle in her smile, with the simple dress she wore. You remember how you immediately excused yourself from your father's entourage and ran up to her. You had no words ready, your eagerness only expressed with an awkward smile.

She smiled back then. She smiled back at you! At that moment you did not care about the words of your father. You held no love anymore for the betrothed you were supposed to visit. You laughed together, you shed tears together and you loved each other. You spurned your father and brought her back with you.

She smiled less. Your Isa felt unwanted, hated even, for winning your heart. Whenever the chance arose you slipped into the woods. The escapades back then were glorious, full of adventure and passion. You commiserated together in your hate for your father. Memories of wild schemes and impossible plots come back to you.

She smiled. Your father fell ill. The baron was dead, long live the baron. You could finally marry your Isa. Ah, your marriage ceremony was worthy of an emperor. Your Isa became your wife. Whenever rulership threatened to overtake you, she brought you back. She practically made you into the man you are now. You could share everything with her, wild ambitions and impossible choices. She helped you stay on top.

She... She became more distant over the years. Unreturned smiles, frigid kisses, and cold talks became a common occurrence. Whatever you tried, you could not manage to get an heir. You did not care, blinded by love, but your Isa did. She withdrew herself, her once warm heart became hard and emotionless. You feared for her, did you do the right thing in taking her to your lands?

Then, suddenly, she bounced back up. Her beautiful voice could once again be heard in your keep. Her eyes twinkled once again. You couldn't believe it. The love of your life was back.

You spent those days working as an advisor for your duke. The work was hard. The duke didn't listen often. However, the pay was good, and the connections even better. Together with your Isa, you managed to broker vital trade deals. You worked with and earned the respect of other barons. Together with your Isa, you were unstoppable.

 
> You though love causes the most grieveous wounds.
Then it all went so horribly wrong.

You don't want to; you try to resist. But you can't stop reliving that once sunny day. You remember how tired you were. The council meeting was a catastrophe. Somehow the duke managed to be even more stubborn than usual. Everything you said was either ignored, or simply glossed over. The meeting was canceled early. You found yourself humiliated, without even realizing it.

Your duke, the slimy treacherous pig, even pulled you apart at the end of it.

"Listen, I know I haven't been at my best lately. I apologize. You need to know how much I appreciate you being here for my support." His round face nigh exhumed his compassion.

You actually believed him. How could you be so wrong.

"Thank you, milord. I do everything I can in order to keep your demesne stable and your people prosperous."

"I know you do, Sir Robert. I don't know what I would do without you. Listen, I have a problem. There are three mayors waiting to give their usual demands. I need to keep them satisfied while offering absolutely nothing in return," he said mischievously giving you a quick guilty wink. "Can you do that for me?"

"I will deal with them at once milord, do not worry about it."

Oh how you were so naive, so eager to please him. The duke hadn't worried about the mayors for a moment.

You quickly left the room. You weren't looking for long before you found the mayors. You went in hard, trying to gain a tactical advantage in the negotiations that would follow. Oh, how wrong you were. They didn't even want to ask for anything. Appalled as they were, your mistake made you the laughingstock of the court. Shamed twice, you immediately retreated to your quarters.

You needed to blow off steam; you needed your wife. The absence of any guards wasn't even noted. You entered the hall, silently to surprise her with your early return. She would be sitting there with her books, reading strange tales about even stranger places. You would grab her from behind, confess your love and fantasize about the adventures you'd experience together. Just like old times.

The hall was empty. The hall was dark. Still, you found your target. Her beautiful voice reached your ears. Was she practicing a play this time? 

"Tell me how good I am." You heard her say.

She acted so naughtily, so brilliant. Your Isa was back.

"Oh milord, it feels so good."

You should ask her to perform that play tonight privately.

"Yes! You are the best!"

Wait, could it be?

"Yes! Yes! Keep doing it!"

No, it could not. No...

You investigated, following her heartwarming sound. Following her bone-chilling voice, you saw your gorgeous, wretched wife lying there. Every scream of pleasure stabbed another knife in your soul. The temperature dropped below freezing. Your blood boiled. You couldn't be here any longer. Your muscles wouldn't take you away. Your world shattered.

You found yourself on a horse, your own horse. Somehow you managed to mutter to the guards to open the gates. Sick as you were, you had to go home. You rode without stopping. The first day turned into night. The road never stopped, you were left alone with nothing but your own misery, repeatedly mulling over what had transpired. 
> A sharp jolt wakes you.
Your head hurts. Your body does too. The light blinds your eyes as you wake up. This is your bed; you are in your own room.

"Thank the ancients. He made it," the voice echoes, leaving an aching ring in your head.

"Oh my Robert, how is he?" 

You feel a delicate hand touching your own. Is it her?

"Isa," you manage out barely.

"Yes! Sweetie, I am home. I was so worried, I came back as soon as I heard the news!" her voice grows more animated causing a groan to escape your lips.

"Sorry, please rest now my love," she continued to whisper. "I heard about the hunt. You were so brave." Her giggle fills the room.

"Rest now, my valorous knight, and forget slaying any more beasts. I want you back as soon as possible."

Before you can respond several footsteps leave the room. Unable to move you are left alone with nothing but your own thoughts. You were attacked, completely taken by surprise. You let your guard down and paid the price. Your mere survival is a miracle, you should be dead now. 

"That was a rookie mistake. I had trained you better."

The voice startles you. A sharp pain flashes through your body.

"Twice now," Garreth remarks drily. "Boy did she really do a number on you."

"When did you enter?"

"I never left your side since.. well since the hunt."

The memory makes you shudder.

"Those bears were unnatural, cursed. I never heard a beast so large be so silent, so cunning," you pause for a moment. "How much time has passed?"

"Four days. And every day they were certain you wouldn't survive till the next."

"I had to pull through." You force yourself to grin. It comes out grotesquely, like a madman's. "I couldn't die like that."

"She kept you going, didn't she?" Garreth asked back. Again he went straight through your smokescreen.

"...Yes."

"Do you still love her?"

This question makes you stop. Your mouth opens and closes again. Do you still find love for your Isabella? Your mind goes back to all the things you've experienced, to the trials and to the pleasures. She did love you, comfort you before you she struck a knife in your back. But afterwards she also came back. In the end, she had wept for you and stood guard by your side.

 
> You say "She is dead to me."
As the bitter words come out from your lips you realize them to be the absolute truth. Your wife held you back, only to kick you while you were down. She betrayed you. But you have become a stronger man for it.

"She ripped into my heart and gave its pieces to another man. I want them both gone."

"What are they to you?" Garreth bounced the ball straight back.

"Loose ends. I need to transform, be better. Their likeness will only hold me back to the ignorant tomfool I once was."

"Robert, you are gripped by the cold hand of vengeance. The path it will lead you is dangerous and corrupting." He grips your hands. They are warm to the touch. "This is not the boy I knew, shielded and mentored. Abstain from this madness!"

"The boy you knew died in the woods. He left this world betrayed and abandoned. I am all that is left, and I am absolutely clear of what I want." The tone of your voice hardens as you pronounce the last words. It begets no insubordination.

"I am sorry Robert. I cannot follow you in this. Whenever you need my aid, decide to relinquish this foolishness.. well you know where I live." His footsteps start to leave the room, then halt. "Please look into yourself. Please find your mercy." 

You don't respond.

This leaves you in absolute loneliness. You are once again alone with your angry thoughts. You stare at the roof above, thinking up your next moves. On one hand, you have the cretin of a duke. He is far more powerful than you could ever be, his lands are rich, his cities populous and his castles well manned. Still, while he proved capable of deception, his hold on his vassals is weak. You could look sabotage his realm from within.

That brings you to your second target, your wife. As far as you know you hold one important advantage. They are both unaware their secret had come out. They both still believe you as naive and loyal as you were before. You'll have to uphold this image at all costs, even if it takes faking your love.

As you see it, your first move of action is to find good advisors. Garreth had filled this void once before you met her. Before he showed his true colors. You have Sir Myre, a veteran of war. He is utterly loyal to your house. He has known you for years and will do whatever you ask him to. However, while he is properly experienced in martial matters, you doubt he will provide you with the subtle intrigue you'll need.

On the other hand, you have your new steward. She is an outsider, coming from lands far outside the kingdom. Elaria was her name. She recently took over the post after the former steward was found dead with some wench. There is something about her. While you get the feeling she isn't content, wanting a grander station, you haven't properly met her yet. She could be a loose cannon or she could be exactly what you need.

Myre or Elaria, a hard choice. While you could go for them both, their different outlook would sow discord and hesitation within your plans. It would risk everything. Luckily you have all the time to make up your mind. The rays of light turn bloodred. You absentmindedly accept the serving of some tasteless mush before being left alone. Somewhere in the night, after hours of pondering your moves, you've decided.
> You ambition and fresh blood will serve you better.
The next morning you call to your servant, one of the newer recruits.

"Milord?" He approaches meekly, apparently, Garreth made an impression yesterday.

"What is your name?" You try to soften your voice, you'll need to win his loyalty.

"It's Brutus, Milord, my ma named me after the ancients," he says surprised.

"It's a powerful name, honor it, Brutus." Although he will probably never amount to anything. Still, flattery from a superior practically feeds someone like him. How could you have been so blind before? "I need to speak to miss Elaria, can you bring her here Brutus?" 

"At once, Milord."

Moments later, faster than you imagined, the servant returns with your steward in tow.

"Thank you for your swiftness, Brutus. Please leave us and close the doors. We must not be disturbed by anyone."

"Understood Milord." He leaves the room, and you wait until the double door close with a heavy thump.

"How are you, my Lord?" Elaria asks and performs a quick curtsy.

"I have been better. Please sit as I'm afraid I won't stand up," you smile, which she returns.

"Do you want the reports, my Lord? It must be tedious being stuck in your bed."

She is uncertain you realize. She doesn't know what you have planned and tries to poke her way in.

"Oh, I assure you, I have had enough to ponder about." You smile once again. "However your reports would provide me with some much-needed distraction."

As she tells about the state of your barony, you observe her. She has a keen mind, using it to notice and improve upon any mistakes of her predecessor. She is excited to finally show her work. You can tell by her eyes that she wants to be noticed. However, you are not certain to her attitude towards you, or your household for that matter. Whenever you bring the topic onto your wife she flatly sidesteps the question. Whenever you ask for her personal opinion, she deftly states obvious facts.

As she finishes her reports, you'll have to decide how much you trust her.
> The earlier she knows, the more she'll trust you.
She is ambitious. You have to open up an opportunity for her to pounce on. Make her see the great heights you plan to reach and she'll be sure to see you as a lifeline out of this backwater. You'll have her eating out of your hand in no time.

"You must be asking yourself what I have really called you for, don't you?" you ask.

"My lord, were my reports not satisfactory?" Another neutral reply. She doesn't even flinch.

"They were, you did an outstanding job. But we both know it's not worth our time. Listen, I have seen the want beneath your eyes. You desire something more than a position in a backwater barony. You share that desire with me. I am planning something grand, a plot to propel us to the grandest station in this country." 

You pause for a moment. You haven't lost her yet, the next step should be safe. You try to sit up, portray a powerful figure.

"The duke betrayed me and my allegiance. He is a slothful hedonist that spits on those that support him. I want him gone, I want to dispose of him. While we are but a barony, I have met many that secretly share that goal. I want you to join me. Help me in this rebellion and we'll rise together."

Elaria opens her mouth, before closing it again. She bows deeply.

"My lord, thank you for this opportunity. I will prove myself ever as your trustworthy servant."

"Please, Elaria stand. Let us always show our true faces to another."

She rises, straightening her back and setting her jaw. "Very well my lord."


 
> You and thus the ember of your rebellion has been lit.
Over the weeks you often come together. As your plans grow in plausibility, your body slowly recuperates in strength. The healmasters even allow you to stand and walk within the confines of your room. This first victory rejuvenates you like nothing else.

Brutus proved himself a useful servant. Though he confirmed your suspicions of his dim wit, he had a knack of being ignored and possessed a good memory. Whenever you were certain you could walk without help, you sent him out. He became your personal eyes and your ears. He kept you updated on everyone, most of all on your wife. She proved that once again she could not be trusted. Her many trips to the dovecote showed you her traitorous loyalty.

You've kept up your charade. You maintained you were too tired, pretending to be asleep whenever she entered, saying your traditional lovewords whenever you failed to do so in time. You think she bought it. However hiding your hatred saps your energy, dims your determination. You have to proceed quickly to the next phase of your plan.

Elaria made it all worth it though. Her mind proved as valuable as you hoped. The last weeks she hired, blackmailed or persuaded an increasing amount of people to her newfound corps of spies. You were the mastermind clustered to this room, she was the expert practitioner out in the fields.

You both agreed that the next phase would be gaining further allies. Her spies told her of grumbling discontent within the duke's palace. She told you the mayors were discontent once again. Your leave had granted them a direct audience with the duke. The latter ignored them as you were ignored once. You would earn a considerable amount of wealth were you to gain their allegiance to this rebellion.

So the question remains, do you want to travel to the capital or remain here to build up your position further?
> You must leave at once, wealth and fame awaits.
You force yourself out of your bed. While you still have trouble getting up, when you stand, you stand comfortably. It's a good day.

"Brutus! Come, we'll look for miss Elaria today."

"Milord, do you feel good enough to leave your room?"

"Come, my man, I feel better. Let me enjoy my own castle for a moment."

This leaves you an opening to make a few decisive steps. They come out a bit wobblier than you'd like, but they must do. You walk out of the two heavyset oaken doors for the first time in weeks. The sudden change in temperature chills you, makes your joints cry out, but the fresh air makes it all worth it. You enter the hallway and walk through the corridors. You greet everyone you meet to their joyful surprise. However, after some minutes the underlying atmosphere infects you. Your castle feels sick and rotting.

You start to lean on Brutus more and more as you enter the steward's chambers. She is not there, leaving you time to look around. She has recently acquired a lot of luxuries. An expensive-looking exotic carpet adorns the whole floor. A grand mirror stands behind her, wrapped with artful decorations. You are just admiring a large bookcase when you hear footsteps approaching.

"Ah splendid, I think we could manage even more in the future."

"Thank you. My Lady, I've been really looking forward to our conversations."

"And so have I, you've done well Elaria," your wife responds as they pass the corner and see you.

"Oh Robert, you are walking!"

You did not expect your wife, especially not here. It takes you a moment to regain your composure and bottle up all your emotions. It is hard.

"Yes. I felt good today, decided to stretch my legs a little. My, you both look splendid today!" Quickly you attempt to redirect the topic. "This view alone makes it all worth the effort."

"Oh you old charmer, you should know better. What brings you here of all places?" she responds with a slight blush. You've failed.

"I wanted to speak to the both of you, "you lie through your teeth. "I was planning to leave for the capital within the week. Elaria, please prepare a rapport about your plans in my absence. And you, my lovely wife, would you like to accompany me on this journey?" It almost hurt to say these words out loud.

"Of course I will my love." Her words make you nauseous. "I shall have my belongings packed immediately." She winks at you and almost glides away. She leaves you where you want to be, undisturbed and planning your revenge.

"Elaria, please close the doors."

"Yes my Lord, so you've decided to leave?"

"I have, although not the way I have planned." You give a knowing nod to the door. "Having her with me on this journey leaves us less options to get rid of her and less space to maneuver." The unspoken thought of bringing her back to the duke makes you sick.

"Then why not kill her on the journey?"

Kill her.. killing her has been on your mind since that day, but to hear it spoken back to you... It stops you in your tracks. A part of your screams to not do it. You try to squash it, repress it.

"Arrange it. We will leave in two days."
> Back in the woods.
You are in your carriage along with your wife and, as you've decided, with Elaria. The horses pull it over the overgrown roads. The escort consists entirely of her agents. You've hinged the plan on the fact that your wife is blind to martial matters and thus far it's been a success. She does not suspect anything at all. You do your part in upholding idle conversation, but in your mind, you are following the route. Just a few turns, a few more minutes and you'll enter the woods. Once there the escort will be ambushed by hired bandits. In the confusion you and Elaria will escape, leaving your target behind to get killed. None will suspect a thing.

The road is full of holes. The wagon shakes. Good, it only masks your own anxiety. You look outside and see the first saplings growing. These pioneers are risk-takers, they loyally expand the woods with their determination. Today you will take the risks, you will expand your own power. It starts to rain.

You are so close, the small saplings have turned themselves into small trees. Just moments lefts. Can you do it? Can you see it through? Your squashed heart roars up in its displeasure once again.

What little remains of the sun is now blocked out. You've truly entered the forest. A few turns are all that stands between her and her life. Does she feel the end nearing, a hidden sixth sense?

"Robert?" It's your wife. Perhaps you should indulge her last words. Your stomach starts to hurt.

"Yes?"

"Why did you go on that hunt?" She must be onto something. An insidious unease creeps up your back. But it's too late, she is already in your trap.

"I had to clear my mind, refresh my soul." You try not to talk about your broken heart.

"Did you plan for things to go this way?" she asks unsteadily. What is she trying to do?

"What do you mean?"

"Would you say you've been led on this path or was this all your doing?" Her face twitches, contorts with intense hate.

"Woman, what has gone into you!" you retort shocked. The ambush is just around the corner, buy more time.

"What has gone into you! Look me in my eyes and tell me you still love me!"

You can't say anything else, you can't say what she wants to hear. You can hardly look into her eyes.

"You, Robert, are a disgusting slimy coward. LOOK ME IN MY EYES AND TELL ME WHAT YOU PLANNED!"

Her words hurt more than her fists do. Fuck.

"Isabelle!" you bellow while jumping forwards. You try to restrain her, take back control. Then the wagon suddenly shakes once more. You're both tumbling through the cabin. In the end, you find yourself subdued with a dagger at your throat. You were still far too weak.

"You filthy pathetic rat! Don't you dare lay a hand on me." she breathes heavily. The ambush is soon, the ambush is soon.

"Elaria.." you manage beneath the cold steel. A dribble of blood stains your shirt.

"Elaria won't help you, snake. She went to me immediately after you so heroically shared your plans. You couldn't even deal with me yourself, had to run for help like always. How could I ever have loved you, Robert?"

"Bitch..."

She pushes the knife in deeper. Your involuntary spasm lacerates your throat.

"What did you expect? You hardly even talked to her."

You try to stem the blood. You try to breathe. You clutch your throat as tight as you can.

"Robert," she is forced to pause, emotions dangerously boiling over. "I once loved you. I still do in some sick way. I am sorry. You forced me. I am sorry for everything." She is starting to lose control over her voice.

You try to sputter, you try to make it up. You want to promise her that you'll be better. Your heart still roars its love for the woman that just cut your throat. Tears fill your eyes. Blood fills your lungs.

"Leave him here. Leave him to the woods he once so loved.. Maybe he'll remember."

The door opens. Strong arms pull you out of the coach. Maybe there is still hope, maybe the bandits will find you and hold you ransom. "B..adits.."

However as you are thrown on the wet road, no one saves you. You are dying alone, abandoned and full of regrets. The woods, once so welcoming, are so distant now. Not even the wolves come to end your suffering.


"Is..a..b..b.elle..."

<|startoftext|>Over the weeks you often come together. As your plans grow in plausibility, your body slowly recuperates in strength. The healmasters even allow you to stand and walk within the confines of your room. This first victory rejuvenates you like nothing else.

Brutus proved himself a useful servant. Though he confirmed your suspicions of his dim wit, he had a knack of being ignored and possessed a good memory. Whenever you were certain you could walk without help, you sent him out. He became your personal eyes and your ears. He kept you updated on everyone, most of all on your wife. She proved that once again she could not be trusted. Her many trips to the dovecote showed you her traitorous loyalty.

You've kept up your charade. You maintained you were too tired, pretending to be asleep whenever she entered, saying your traditional lovewords whenever you failed to do so in time. You think she bought it. However hiding your hatred saps your energy, dims your determination. You have to proceed quickly to the next phase of your plan.

Elaria made it all worth it though. Her mind proved as valuable as you hoped. The last weeks she hired, blackmailed or persuaded an increasing amount of people to her newfound corps of spies. You were the mastermind clustered to this room, she was the expert practitioner out in the fields.

You both agreed that the next phase would be gaining further allies. Her spies told her of grumbling discontent within the duke's palace. She told you the mayors were discontent once again. Your leave had granted them a direct audience with the duke. The latter ignored them as you were ignored once. You would earn a considerable amount of wealth were you to gain their allegiance to this rebellion.

So the question remains, do you want to travel to the capital or remain here to build up your position further?
> You leaving your position at the first opportunity is madness.
The rebellion is not ready. There is still so much more you can accomplish from within these walls. Let the duke anger his vassals undisturbed, you'll continue on with your own plan. The resentment will only further fermentate the ground for your ambitious schemes.

So you stay in your room, watchful and vigilant. The days blend into each other, but nothing of worth grabs your attention. Sadly your wounds start to fester and the heels of your feet blacken painfully. The healmasters attempt to tow you out of your bed, out of your lair. You resist. Leaving would only leave you vulnerable.

Elaria and Brutus keep you updated on the declining state of affairs within the barony. Their talk of nefarious whispering, suspicious gatherings, and silent insubordination shocks you. Your servants have started to mock you, call you Lord Robert the Idle, Lord Robert the Miserable. Within your forces, the spies have witnessed talks of desertion. You have become the but of many a joke.

Then one day it all pales compared to the news Elaria brings you.

"My lord, I have dire news. My agents have sensed the stirrings of a rebellion against your name." Her flat tone makes you rise up for the first time in weeks.

"Woman, tell me more!"

"It's.. It's Sir Myre, my Lord. He has organized a group of knights in secret, brought them together to restore the realm. They've begun recruiting among your servants. I am afraid we're being surrounded by opposing forces as we speak."

You stay silent. Anger spews from your eyes.

"But there is a chance, my agent gathered they will give you a chance to abdicate. They will lie to you. They will manipulate you. They will make themselves seem overwhelming. My Lord, they are however not aware their betrayal has been revealed to us. I will plan our defense. My lord, trust me and we will end the threat."

Myre.. You've known him for years. He taught you how to swing the sword, how to pierce the spear. He was a loyal man, loyal to your family.

"IT CAN NOT BE! Myre is simply not capable of such treachery," your voice booms up. Your steward is forced to step back.

"I am sorry my Lord. I fear Lady Isabell.."

"Don't speak her name!" you interrupt harshly.

"My apologies. I fear Sir Myre has been corrupted by your wife, my Lord." She casts her eyes downward and makes herself as small as possible.

It could be true, that harpy once even fooled you. You won't be fooled any longer.

"Very well. Whenever they'll ask for an audience, let them in. I want your spies to ambush them, overwhelm them from all sides. I want them brought to the heel. Wounded, but alive. Use poison if you have to." Your voice weakens. Anger has eaten up your reserves. You fall back into your bed as you barely manage to stammer, "Now leave me Elaria. Thank you."

"Thank you my Lord." She curtsies and leaves.
> The betrayal.
It wasn't long before the day arrived when the so-called 'sir' Myre wanted to speak with you. Elaria was proven right once again. You hated it, you hated the fact you had to leave your room, you hated everything. You let yourself be carted through the castle.

The plan required a larger room to perform the ambush. The old throneroom would do. As Brutus moves you through the cold castle something strikes you. It's abandoned, there are no servants in sight. The once lively sounds of busylife are now muffled and depressed. Elaria accompanies you.

"My Lord, is there something wrong?"

"My castle seems.. empty."

"Now you say it, indeed it is. A lot has happened since your accident my Lord. Since you've been recovering there have been no grand feasts. Lady Isab.. Your wife ordered a decree of silence to help you sleep better. Everyone is working diligently and efficiently."

"Hmpf."

You are not convinced. However, you've arrived at your destination. This hall was built before the rest of your castle, it stemmed from a more grander and more decadent time. Ancient white marble and strange forms give the room a heavenly impression. Somehow, even seated in your elevated seat, you fail to comprehend the whole room. It's as if the architecture withholds its secrets. It wills itself to remain an enigma, even from you.

"It's a good room to hide," you say.

"Yes, there are thirty agents waiting in the shadows as we speak," she remarks with a tint of pride. She feels totally in control.

You freeze up for a moment. "Well, yes of course. Please let Myre and his traitors in."

"Very well." She moves in position to stand behind you.

And so it happens. A group of ten knights enters the hall. A few paces ahead of them is Myre. You almost don't recognize him. In the last months, he had aged considerably. Though it fits him well. It gives him a rugged flair of authority forged by painful struggle. Twenty paces before you he stops and looks at you questionably. Then, seeing something he doesn't like, he reluctantly bows.

"Milord, may I speak?" Myre asks, raising his voice to fill the room.

"You may." You find it hard to hate the man in front of you. Something about his posture makes him seem fatigued rather than devious. Still, you've been misled once. You won't let it happen again.

"Thank you. I come here on behalf of your loyal men Milord. They are suffering.."

"These are the lies I have warned you about," she whispers.

"..They haven't had a worthy meal in weeks. They are kept idle, are being pestered and are made miserable by that wretched steward. Milord, you have been given council by the snake behind you. You are being misled, deceived and your realm is crumbling."

"And the manipulations. Please, my Lord, allow me to end this," she continues to insist.

"Her corruption spread everywhere milord. The servants are too scared to leave their work. Young men from the village are leaving this barony. Milord, please allow me to ask you on behalf of every kind and loyal soul.."

"Alright I'm done hearing your grabble," she interjects. "Sir Myre, you are being arrested for treason. Stand down and do away with your weapons."

"Milord! You cannot allow this! Please, you have to stop her!" Panic stains his words. You hate panic.

But doubt infects your convictions. Myre did everything you were told he would do. He asks for the impossible. He wants you to throw away everything you've worked for. He demands you to do away with the one thing that kept you standing. Still, something in him strikes you as honest. He is as much an open book as he was years before. Did you go down the wrong path?

But Elaria helped you. You've heard her reports. You've heard Brutus. Wealth is entering your barony, with your steadily increasing corps of spies you finally have influence within the duchy. You have made grand plans. You would go against yourself if you turned your back on this.

In the shouting, you have a mere moment to decide. Will you go with the old, or stay with the new?




 
> You warn Myre of the ambush.
You don't know what to think anymore. Still, Myre is your friend. He doesn't deserve this. You have to save him against all odds.

You raise your fist.

"Silence!" You pause a moment. "Come closer all of you, I want to take a better look at you."

"My Lord, this is madness!" Elaria whispers. You ignore her. Meanwhile, the knights have closed the distance.

"Please tell me everything. We're safe from any vultures."

The words strike true. A flash of recognition shows on their eyes. Elaria is still unaware. She didn't hunt.

Sire Myre starts talking. He tells you everything and the knights position them around you and Elaria.

She can't believe her ears. First, she unsuccessfully tries to interrupt the confession, then true panic sets in and she calls for the attack.

But the knights are ready. The spies are intercepted before they could strike. In a fair one on one match, they are easily outduelled by the experienced man at arms. Several spies lay dead on the floor. Though they manage to regroup. The numerical superiority is still on their side.

Closer to your throne Elaria tries to slip away unnoticed. She had used the chaos to slink back into the shadows. You try to shout. Myre throws himself in the pursuit. She is no match against his trained speed and he easily catches up to her.

You hear shouting and sounds of battle over the whole castle. It seems the servants have taken up arms as well. The tide of battle swings decisively in your favor. One by one the spies are cut down. They receive no mercy, every blow kills. It's become a carnage.

On the far side of the room, sir Myre managed to subdue and put down the traitor. It's over. You still hear shouting elsewhere, but the throne is secured.
> You several months later.
You've been besieged. Your conscripts man the walls, your man at arms stand by the gates. The enemy is overwhelming, the duke had come for you.

In the chaos, your wife escaped your grasp. Apparently Elaria had been working with her in some way. She fled. She rode for your enemy, betrayed you once more. The duke was seemingly shocked at what had transpired, called for an invasion at once.

So you fought. The last months did wonders for your health, you guessed you had been slowly poisoned. You fought in the woods, called on your old mentor Garreth to help your defense. He refused, told you he saw the darkness in your veins. Whatever that meant. You've fought without him in the streets. You've been pushed back.

Now you fight at the walls. Sir Myre once again stands by your side. The walls shake, they were crumbling even before the siege. Nowadays the only thing that keeps them standing is the pure desperation of your men.

The duke had called for a final assault. This is it.

"Ready men! This is it! Whatever happens, tonight we shall feast as heroes. Our foes have the advantage in both numbers and arms. But they underestimate us! The foreign invaders are here on our terms, on our lands!" you bellow the words using every fiber of your being.

"Be ready, brave sons, valorous daughters. Fight for each other and fight for glory!"

With a roar, your men acknowledge your words. In the last months, they began to trust you again, see you as a fellow victim of filthy foreigners. This will be the wall you'll all die on together. You can see the duke's army approaching. Thousands of ants, pushing huge towers towards your castle. As you glint your eyes you spot the duke himself, and besides him... your wife. You'll show them.

Catapults have renewed their battery on your walls. You can feel it, the very ground you stand on is going to collapse any second. It doesn't bother you. You'll fight in the rubble.

Another barrage, an explosion of sounds send you tumbling to the ground. The world collapses, spins and batters you form every side. The battle had begun in earnest.

You force your body up. Losses around you have been dire. But the blood of your brethren spurs you on. As the first ducal soldiers arrive you fight as bears. You give no inch, no step without reaping offers of flesh.

Eventually, you lose track of time. Everything becomes either a target or an obstacle. You fall into your rhythm. Slash, push, parry, get hit, kill. Stab, dodge, step, slash, kill.

Until you feel someone pull you back by your shoulders. You almost stab the ambusher when you recognize its Myre, battered and bloodied. You can't understand what he yells, but nevertheless you are pulled further back and into your inner keep.

It's here the last of your defenders regroup. Man and woman, old and young, veteran and untrained, they all have the same look of dissociative determination. As the doors break they all charge in. In the close quarters, everybody is equal, chaos and luck reign over skill and grace. Somehow you manage to push back the first assault. Your numbers have thinned considerably. It will do.

A second assault. Once again you throw yourself into the fray. Every kill you make strengthens your resolve. You lose yourself in the battle, everything around you turns into shades of red. For every man you slaughter, two make take its place. You lose yourself. Eventually, you too are cut down.

You survived long enough to hear your Isa barging in. Your story and your life end in her wet embrace. You are sorry. You are too late. You die knowing it all could have ended differently.

The rest of the meeting turns into dull specifics and crunching of numbers. You had won your price. The fish had bitten down on the hook. The only thing left was the arduous process of hauling it in. It had to be slow, lest the fish knew of its capture. You've seen the way Elaria looks at you change. She trusts you more, shows genuine respect.

Still, even if it had failed, you came out of today with a solid plan of economic upheaval. In as little as but half a year, you'll have done more than your father in his lifetime. You'll have totally renewed the infrastructural backbone of your barony. It'll allow you to further your horizons and expand your influence. Then, and only then, will it be time to continue the revenge on to your dearest liege.

So the days quickly pass by once again. Your wife becomes more and more incessant in her cries for attention. It infuriates you. How dare she pretend nothing happened. She had lost you and your love. She squandered her chance at redemption. Yet she can't know that until it's too late. You'll have to keep her happy and busy in the meantime. You'll have to meet her, for the sake of safety and sanity.

"Robert!" Her voice enters your room. You steel your will.

"Yes, it's me. How are you?" you couldn't help letting disdain seep in your voice.

"Are you tired again, my love?" Luckily she's as naive as you remember.

"I've been thinking a lot. Isabella, nothing will happen here for the next few months. I'll be recovering in a daily grind, while you'll be stuck here with nothing you can do. Remember how it was last time? You'll be bored and depressed. I don't want that for you." The warm smile you fake makes you sick once again.

"Thank you for your consideration. But I want to stay here, with you. I feel we need this, honey. We need some proper time to ourselves" Like a filthy fly that keeps zooming about. Why does she have to be so difficult?

"Isabella, listen to me. If you stay here we'll only fight. I need my space and quiet, while you need your stimulation. Wouldn't it be better for us to provide that to each other? Wouldn't it be only cruel to deny it?" 

Isabella stays quiet for a moment. You sense she's not agreeing with it at all. She struggles to make up her own mind before she responds, "What are you thinking?"

"Remember all the time and energy we put into advising the duke?" Her face falters at his mention. "I wouldn't want our efforts to be wasted by my foolish recklessness." Her face shows small glimpses of guilt. You're striking a nerve. Good.

"Yes," she stammers.

"I trust you, Isabella. You were always the strongest of our duo." You're hitting your target hard. Isabella anxiously shifts her weight. "You always knew what do to and were capable of seeing the true path. There would be no one I would rather have maintaining our reputation than you."

You sense she would rather be anywhere else other than here, in this room with you. She's afraid of what's going to happen. She doesn't want to leave for the capital, but can't find it in her to fight against your judgment. Speaking up against your words would probably be too uncomfortable for her.

It offers up possibilities. Could you manipulate her further, use her as an active spy within your enemies' ranks? Would playing that game be worth facing the daily reminder of what she had done?
> You play with her some more. "I love you, Isabella."
You had been cold to her the last weeks, doing the bare minimum to uphold any semblance of a relationship. She was probably afraid. She was afraid you knew the truth, that she wouldn't recover her mistake and that she'd be lonely forever. Your words took away some of that fear but replaced it with something far more insidious.

Her hurt doesn't arise from you anymore. You've placed yourself out of her crosshairs, leaving her with nothing to focus on but to within. Self-loathing and guilt will eat her up from the inside over the next days, possibly crippling her. You'll then offer yourself as her crutch, seemingly shield her against her own demons and make her dependant on you in the process. 

So far the plan has worked. The words appeared to break her down. Her barriers faltered before your eyes. Your wife, the woman you once so loved, is now reduced to a helpless mark. You force your disgust down and replace it with a steely focus on your goal.

"I love you too, Robert, I love you so much." Her eyes are watery and enlarged. You can taste a hint of her despair, of the inner battle she fights against herself. It's time to move in position.

"Come here, Isa," you say while offering her your embrace. The possibility of her touch hardly fazes you anymore. The once raging storm had calmed into a breeze of malignance.

Good, she accepts.

"I.. I have to tell you something Robert," she starts. It's bad news. If she were to tell you of her misdoings, you'd lose any leverage. Let her wallow in her predicament all alone.

You quickly interject, "Shh, my love. It's alright, you can tell me later. I don't want to ruin this beautiful moment."

Good, it made her quiet. You let the embrace last for a few minutes more. Just when you feel her relax completely, you cut it short. Leave her wanting more, with never enough to fill the gaps entirely.

"Thank you, Isa. I needed that." Another smokescreen. "But I start to feel my wounds again, I'm sorry."

She shows a pained smile. "It's alright."

"We will write to each other right? When you'll arrive.." You let the sentence draw out, carefully picked 'when' over 'if'.

"Why would you ask that, Robert? Of course, we will." It's almost too easy. How could you once have let this harlot fool you?

"Thank you, Isa. I am sorry." You overplay a groan and lower yourself once again in your bed, closing your eyes. This meeting is over.

"Me too," she softly says when she thinks you're not listening. "Me too."
> Months pass by in fruitful preparation.
The early signs of spring make themselves known. The winter was mild, allowing good groundwork to be done on the infrastructure project. As you look outside, you see the first serfs waddling through the fields. Another year had passed for them, only for their cyclical life to start again. It would only be a month more before you would recruit them to hard labor.

The winter was good for you too. Time restored all wounds, as the healmasters always said. For once their indecipherable methods worked; you walked upright again and were full of vigor. You had used it well. Promises of revenge gave life to your days, kept you working from the break of dawn to far past midnight.

You had used the time and energy to build up relationships. You were certain Elaria, the young ambitious woman, could be depended upon. You had slowly and carefully breached subjects of treason, while positioning yourself as her father figure. You pulled your relationship away from the once cold, calculating rationality and to the warm sensitivity. You gave her another option, a safe haven in a foreign and hostile land. You allowed her to confide in you her troubles and her glee. You made yourself a key part of her world.

The same could be said of your once loving wife. Over the past few months, your letters became longer and more heavily laden with passionate agitation. You could see her self-hate, her desperation increase during her stay in the capital. You made no mistake; she probably jumped in bed with the frog as soon as she had arrived. She searched for anything to fill the holes that consumed her from the inside. She was like you in that regard.  Only you had done so successfully, let it feed on feelings of hate and vengeance. She was still searching and let the search blindly lead her away from her path.

You accepted it and used it, for he could not soothe her guilt in any way. In fact, you even gently nudged her towards him. Let her see how hollow their pleasure was, let her yearn for something he couldn't possibly offer. It was a careful balance. You wanted, needed them to be together. Your wife required a good position for her to be useful, sabotaging their relationship would only hinder that. Still, you needed to bind her to you in some way. Would she be too enamored with him, she would never betray him.

Luckily this wasn't the only thing to keep you busy. You made drastic changes to your daily routine. You practiced swordplay for hours at end, forcing your will to face the harsh conditions. Eventually, your body adapted. You were stronger, faster and tougher. Strong minds needed strong bodies.

This gave you an idea. What better way of vengeance than to slay him openly, for all to see in an officially sanctioned one on one duel. He would have to accept of course. But, with a spy among his midst, you could easily manufacture a situation where that would be his only option. You can already see yourself holding his severed head for all to see.

Elaria had scoffed at the idea, denouncing it as something detestably brutish. Her way was far more meticulous. She proposed using your renewed roads to influence your peers. She wants you to position yourself as the crucial piece to hold the realm together. When all was in place, you'd simply sell out the duke to his rivals. It would prove to be an option that would not only achieve your goals, but also increase your power.
> You needed to do the act yourself.
Revenge is a dish best served in person. You know it's not the most effective, yet it feels the best. You order Elaria to sow distrust in the capital. A plan is shaping up in your head. It'll require plenty of patience and diligence. Best to keep your enemies off-balance in the meantime.

Over next weeks you intensify your training regiment. Myre proved to be a worthy partner, capable of tricks you thought to be impossible. You have him teach you every single one. You continue until your knees buckle and then some.

More crucial to your plan is your wife. You write her every single day. You tell her of sickness and of restlessness. You want her to know you're planning on coming to the capital. Any day now you'd be strengthened enough to travel. Any day could be the day you'll arrive with a letter in person.

The letters you receive grow in anticipation. Your unknowing spy tells you about her life as well. Between the lines of want and love, you read the moves of your enemy. He grows agitated as well. The city is turning against him and he is losing his conquest.

You're certain he'll play right into your hands.

 
> You last minute preparations.
When you read the city had broken into active rebellion, you decide it's time.

"Elaria, have the spies to poison the water. When I arrive I want the revolt broken by sickness and death."

"My Lord, you don't have to risk it. We could spread the uprising, join it with a proper army," she'd begun to see you as a friend, a figure of trust and knowledge. As heartwarming as it was, she saw you as weak. That could prove dangerous.

"No. Trust me on this. It will work," you harden your voice with an icy undertone. It's an unmistakable hint of poorly concealed danger. "I will put my hands on his throat and personally squeeze the life out of him. Nothing can stand between me and that."

It worked, she unmistakably takes a little step back. "Understood. I will send out the orders."

"I know you'll be there when it counts. Now, please leave me. I have a lot to prepare."

As she leaves the room, you stretch your back one more time. As much as you can't allow it to show, it's still your weak spot. The healing process left it strained and stiff. It'll have to do.

So you walk to the knight's quarters. The castle had grown so small in the last months. You feel as if the walls enclose on you, the halls shorten. You've outgrown it, finally ready for something greater. You are ready for your reforged destiny. You are ready to leave.

A short moment and a few orders later, you find yourself at the head of a small column. You had handpicked twenty knights to accompany you. It's not enough to make the duke wary, but enough to make a statement. You want to provoke him into jumping in your trap.
> The road was silent, for everyone knew fate held the reins now.
You arrive as a spear of light into the rotting darkness. The city had gone through hell. Buildings smouldered, corpses laid scattered over the roads and every single man was either sick, dying or both. The grime stuck to everything. Flies buzzed about, imitating the few filthy healmaster that could still walk.

The gate was open, unguarded. Was the working of your poison too effective? You push those thoughts as collateral to the side. You were here for a mission. That mission stood above anything else.

Slowly you make your way through the city. The familiar streets look even worse up close. A nagging sense of guilt seeps down your spine. Did you go too far?

"Milord, it's not safe here." A knight to your right draws his sword. The unblemished metal cuts trough the rotten air, ready to be used. "We can't let them get close, what if it's spreading to us?"

"Agreed." The bastards never know the truth. "We must make haste to the keep. Keep everything at sword's end."

And thus you move together. As one band against the darkness, you force yourself through. Some desperate men needed only intimidation, others had to be cut away. It's all for your mission. You move over blockades, through some areas that witnessed heavy fighting and under viscous clouds of thick black smoke. You move until you reach the keep. It's heavily guarded.
> You and you move beyond.
"Robert! It's good to see you, especially now," your liege says, quickly approaching. It was obvious he meant anything but that. He had to be nervous; you barely entered his domain.

"I heard the tales. Is it all true?" Your strength is showing your weakness. Play the mark to catch it.

"It's even worse. Come, follow me."

He seemed distracted, but not hostile. Good. You motion your knights to follow you just in case. You never know with such a treacherous bastard.

"Is the sickness curable?"

"I'm afraid not. Everyone who has the first symptoms dies within a day. We don't know how it spreads. We don't know how to cure it." A glint of pain shows through his eyes.

"Has the keep been hit as well?"

"Yes, but luckily it was contained. Most of us here have been biding our time," he answers your question before stopping entirely. He definitely was hiding something. "Tell me, Robert, do you believe in faith?" The question catches you off guard. Where did this change come from?

"I do believe there's more. Something unexplainable just out of sight." A neutral answer to dismiss his inquiry.

"I didn't at first. Yet with you here, I can't help but see the patterns. You see, the grumbling started as soon as Isabella arrived here. And now you arrive. You came here just as the disease spreads. I can't help it, Robert..." Fuck, he was on to you. "... I can't help but think you're both cursed by faith and I am cursed for standing in between you both."

At that moment you see her. She looked weak, frail. Her skin was a sickly white pallor and her eyes were dead. It seemed she had used the last of her strength to seek you out. To come to you as her last will, her last action in this world.

"Robert..." she whispered and fell to her knees. Life itself was ebbing out of her every moment.

No. This was not the plan. You rush to her side. As much as you disdained that woman, you were both still bound to each other. You can't lose her like this. Not by something as wicked as pure chance.

"Robert..." she whispered silently. Her hand reaches up to your cheek. A tear wets hers. "I am sorry for everything, Robert." Your will leaves your icy grasp as water between your fingers. "Please, forgive me."

You don't reply. You don't trust your voice. The day started perfectly. Everything went exactly as you had planned. Yet it all turned so wrong.

One last embrace to the woman you knew so intimately.
> You there is just one more thing to do.
As you feel her strength leave her completely, you stand up. There he is. He stands like a sad pig that finally lost his favorite toy. You'll show him.

"You did this, you filthy maggot. You betrayed me, took her and now finally killed her when you got bored. You're despicable, a spineless coward unfit to rule over his own dick." Every dammed ounce of anger, sadness and hurt spills out harder with every damned word you say. "Be a man for one day; I demand to exact my right to duel."

"I wanted to honor you, you know. I wanted to support you in your mourning. Yet you show yourself the thick-headed unstable piece of shit you've always been. I accept your challenge. It'll be to the death." His eyes turn into little dark pits of pure hate. "For that's the only thing you deserve."

You relax. Both of you posture up at opposite sides of the woman you once both loved. Both of you don't want to be the first to leave her. This is what you had trained for. You unsheathe your sword.

"We do it here. And we do it now."

"Finally we agree." He does so likewise.
> You and everything else blended away.
The duel starts mirrored. You both crouch in a combat stance. Yours is lateral and wide. His is shorter, feet closer together for more power. You both circle to each other's weak side. You both circle around her. One look at her reminds you of what you're doing this all for.

You attack first. A long straight lunge. You didn't put any real power behind it. It was to annoy and hone your range. You look past your sword's edge and see it easily parried. The duke hadn't expected your speed. Good, more was still to come.

Another attack. A sidewards slash this time. Again parried. Yet it served its purpose. The duke didn't want to lose face. He attacked, as his stance predicted, with a furious and reckless enthusiasm.

Wild wide slashes came your way. They were predictable, yet powerful enough to pound your back with every parry you made. You're forced to give ground. Your circle widens. The circling grows more frenetic.

You keep him on his toes, give him no chance to breathe after his last burst. Feints are followed by light strikes. He is forced to react to every one of them, for every one could be the one with power.

He takes a step sideways, trying to throw you off-center. You react quickly and he takes steps back. As you end your flurry with an overhand you hear cheering. The duke was done for.
> You but the strike got blocked. A flash of pain soars down your spine..
No. It can't be happening. With great effort, you manage to hold onto your sword. The victor failed. Your body failed you at the worst possible time. How could your own meat stand between you and destiny?

"What's wrong, Robert?" your liege asks with sick glee. "Fight me, you can do it."

You're forced to use both hands to desperately block his counter.

"Is there something wrong? Answer me!"

Another strike, another desperate defense. You don't know if you can hold it up much longer. Your shoulders, forced to compensate, can't hold up against this onslaught. Your arms tingle with the reverberation of every strike. Sweat streams down your face.

"Come on, at least put up something more than just this," he continues to taunt. "This is just pathetic. You are pathetic, always were-"

You throw everything into one last sweeping strike, one of Myre's tricks. This was your one shot, one chance to walk away victorious. You start high and force him to guard his ribs, Then, the last moment, you slump with your entire weight and send the blade flying straight to his thigh.

Success and failure. You both end up on the ground, grunting to stand up first. None wants to be left behind in the realm of the dead.
> You forgo this pointless competition and throw yourself at him.
In order to win you sometimes have to bite through the dirt. You do exactly that. Instead of following your opponent to his domain, you spring into him. It sends you both to an ungracious fall. You both tumble through the room with him ending up on top.

He draws his dagger; you buck as hard as you can. He loses his balance; you retake your rightful position. You hit him as hard and as often as you can; he is on the defense.

The dagger, you have to fight over the dagger. Both of your hands clasp on his wrist, crush his hand.

A scream, the dagger falls.

You feel yourself reaching for it, grabbing it firmly and stabbing him. There's nothing exactly like it. The knife cuts through him as through butter. His very essence flows out through the holes you'd just made. You continue stabbing, only stopping when you've covered the floor with a thick red coat.

"He's dead, Milord." The room was harrowingly silent.

"He's dead indeed." You'd done it. You completed everything you set out to do. Yet you feel only emptiness. What now?

"The duke had left no heirs, married no wife." 

"Our dukedom will surely fall apart."

"What will we do now?"

You stand up, angry at the ones who couldn't honor this moment. You don't want to do this now. Let today's actions fill today and leave tomorrow's open.

"What's done is done. There is only one path forward. I know this will be hard for you to accept, but we need a new duke. Seeing there are no other contenders, I'll offer myself up for that position." There is no charm behind the words. You're just stating cold facts. They either accept or die.

"This is madness!"

"Milord."

"Hail the new duke."

"I won't stand for it!"

The hall had filled itself with a cacophony of yelling. Fights started to break out. The chaos was total.

This is what you'll rule.<|endoftext|>
