The memory makes you shudder.

"Those bears were unnatural, cursed. I never heard a beast so large be so silent, so cunning," you pause for a moment. "How much time has passed?"

"Four days. And every day they were certain you wouldn't survive till the next."

"I had to pull through." You force yourself to grin. It comes out grotesquely, like a madman's. "I couldn't die like that."

"She kept you going, didn't she?" Garreth asked back. Again he went straight through your smokescreen.

"...Yes."

"Do you still love her?"

This question makes you stop. Your mouth opens and closes again. Do you still find love for your Isabella? Your mind goes back to all the things you've experienced, to the trials and to the pleasures. She did love you, comfort you before you she struck a knife in your back. But afterwards she also came back. In the end, she had wept for you and stood guard by your side.

 
> You say "... Yes."
It hurts your soul, but you know it to be true. It would be far too simple letting hate take over your being. You know one thing, you love that woman. You've loved her since you first laid eyes upon her and you'll continue to love her until the days those eyes close for the last time. She makes you feel alive, even if it pains you. She's still your Isa.

"Yes Garreth." Even through the hurt, the words cause you to smile brightly. "I do still love her."

"You are a fool, my boy," he responds chuckling. "But you have a good heart. It's something that graces you."

"Why am I like this Garreth?" you ask back. "She betrayed me and she let me down. I want to hate her. I try to in hope that it makes me feel better. Still, I can do nothing but to long for her return."

"Son, you have met the love of your life. Whatever you do and whatever she does changes nothing about it. I sense the thread of fate surrounding you both. Nothing shy of madness or death could break that bond." That can't be true.

"Does she feel the same way I do? If so, why did she act that way?"

"I think not. Everybody experiences things differently, my boy." At this moment he seems to age several decennia. "Your emotions are your own as much as her feelings are hers. The question remains, what will you do with them?"

"I don't know Garreth. I want her back. But I see only the duke when I look at her. I see him on top of her. I can't deny I feel love for her but I can't forgive her for what she's done."

"And that is completely justified. The truth is that you've lost each other. I don't know why and I don't know how. I don't even know where to put the blame. I only know that your bond wavered. Life caught up to your fairytale and pure happiness turned into heavy sorrow." You almost recognize a tone of remembrance. It angers you. What does he know of your sorrow?

"And what would an old woodsman know of love?" you bitterly strike out.

"More than you think young man. Everyone was once young and full of life," he responds warmly, ignoring the bitterness that assaulted him beneath your words. "However I think it's time for me to return to my home. Think about it boy. Think about what you want to do."

With that said Garreth leaves.
> You overburdened with thoughts you fall back asleep.
That night, you dream of her, of her black locks waving across your face. You see her up close, her eyes closed in joyfull bliss. She gently waves from side to side, enjoying the sun and enjoying your company. But every time you reach out to touch her, your arms shrink and she's left out of your reach. Always just out of reach.

"My dear, wake up," her gentle voice calls to you. "Wake up, it's time for you to shine another day."

As you indeed rise from your deep slumber, you are met with a far less pretty sight. A hunched old healmaster stands by your bed.

"Wake up, Milord. You've been laying in one place for too long. We'll have to let you walk today, or you'll face the rot that has settled this bed." Somehow you doubt that could be true. Though the dream's magic has passed. There's nothing left to do but to stand.

"Well done, milord. Please don't overexert yourself."

With wobbly knees, you find yourself in the middle of the room. It is a wonder considering only yesterday you were unable to even move your head. It was too much. The world turns black as your stomach lifts itself to your throat. The healmaster is no match for your heavy body. So you fall, injuring yourself and your pride, and hit rock bottom.

And that's when your Isa enters the room. Why now, of all possible times..?

"Robert! What happened?" she cries out and hurries to your side.

"Oh it's nothing," you lie. "Nothing like a good fall to start the day." Her touch feels so good.

"The fault is mine, my Lady." You'll have to later thank the good master. "I overestimated his capabilities." Nevermind, you'll have to save yourself. You can't let her see your weakness. Not now.

"It.. was a slip. Help me up. I can walk."

You don't wait for an answer. You ruthlessly pull yourself up by the shoulders of the old man; it serves him right.

"See, as good as new. Isa, will you accompany me to the garden?" You manage to kick the protesting healmaster.

"I can't let you slip all the way there, can I?" she responds to your delight.
> You onwards to the park.
The pair of you move together. You try not to lean on her too much. As much you want to pretend everything is normal, that the looks she gives you are of pure love, you can't. The chitchat, the touches, everything feels fake. In some ways it is. However, the public is not aware of these subtle underlying tones. Wherever you two walk, you leave lighthearted chuckles and optimistic smiles behind.

Moving through the corridors you reach a small and secluded spot near the courtyard. It's been a favorite spot of yours, a little oasis of peace within the chaos of everyday life. Isabella helps you sit down. You feel the grass between your fingers. It helps remind you of simpler times.

"I am sorry Isabella," you sigh. "That hunt was madness."

"It's okay. You survived and hopefully learned a lesson out of it." She pokes you a little too hard at the end.

"That hurt!" you fake with indignation. "Still, you had to suddenly leave behind everything you'd built up." 

"I didn't have to leave, Robert. I did it out of my own volition. You could've just as easily recovered without me, no?"

"Besides," she adds playfully. "I felt out of place at the capital anyways."

You close your eyes. It's extraordinarily warm weather for fall. The sun shines brightly and warms your cheeks. This was like a dream. The love of your life lies next to you. Still, something bothers you. As beautiful as this dream could be, it's not real. She cheated on you. She betrayed you and now pretends nothing has happened. You simply don't know what parts are true and what parts are lies. Every word could be a lie; some words are definitely lies. Does she still love you? Not knowing where you stand pains you greatly.
> You try to get the truth out of her.
You simply can not handle the uncertainty. You have to know the truth that lies at the core of your present struggle. 

"Isa..." you ask, not knowing how to give words to your intentions.

"Yes, Robert? 

You can't do it. You have to divert the question.

"Why did you feel out of place at the capital?"

"It's difficult to say. I thought I'd be more accepted over there." It was true she hadn't had the best time amongst your own countrymen. Her exotic features and foreign culture scared them. "But along the way, I think I lost myself. I thought I'd be freer over there, wade in a cosmopolitan city. But I couldn't handle the freedom. It's true. I was bored here, in your barony. Things didn't work out. I felt left out with nothing to do, nothing to accomplish. But now I think that is just what I deserve." She buries her face in her arms. This woeful sight pulls your attention away from yourself.

"Come, come now. You are the greatest woman I know and deserve the world. I am so happy I got to know you. Please, you know that I'm here for you right?"

Far from what you intended, these words only escalate the situation. Your Isabella starts to cry. The very sound of it breaks your heart. It cracks your barriers forcing your repressed feelings to come out with the force of a thousand armies.

You find yourself crying together.
> You it relieves both of you.
Eventually, Isabella manages to regain herself. With a heavy sigh, she disentangles herself from your grasp and achieves some graceful poise.

"Robert, how much do you know?" she asks with renewed certainty.

"What?" You can't believe your ears.

"Don't 'what' me Robert!" You haven't heard her raise her voice like this in years. "I've seen it. I see the way you're hurt, the way you pick every single word with such care. You know, the way you look at the world has changed. I see it in the manner you look at me.  Every moment we spend together I feel a distance I've never felt before. It's as if you struggle to open yourself up. I can't handle this any longer, Robert!"

Her stream of words overfloods your thoughts. You can hardly manage a measly, "I saw it..with my own eyes..."

"Oh Robert, I am so sorry! I truly am! I didn't know, I didn't want to! It just happened and I regret it every single second of every day. Please, Robert..."

She makes her way back to you; tries to hug you, to embrace you with her very being. It's everything you asked for moments ago. You got everything you wanted. Yet, upon hearing her say those words herself, she makes you sick. When you look at her, you don't see your beautiful wife, but a wretched creature.

"Go away," you simply say.

"Robert, please..." Your wife can't believe it.
> You say "GO AWAY!"
And so you are alone once again. You regretted your outburst the moment you had it, but somehow it made you feel better. It's a hard thing, love. Once you give it a finger, it'll take your whole arm. You start to regret letting it enter your life in the first place. You don't even think you know what to do anymore. It feels like you're losing your mind.

As you absentmindedly pluck and crush the grass around you, you try to find the reason behind the last developments. Somehow you let your guard down. You grew complacent and you learned nothing from it afterward. You relied on her to make you feel alive in this world. Every day and every night you sank deeper into that dark pit. Every moment you threaded further into that alluring lie, until one day you failed to see the light of the sun above you.

You feel lost now. You had depended on that part of your life. Now you are truly alone. You are left in that pit without the illusion that made it all worth it. You feel trapped, betrayed and abandoned, with nowhere to go. It scares you.

"Milord? Is everything alright?" a guard enters your world.

"Yes," you lie.

"Lady Isabella sent me," the guard continues. "She wants you to know that you'll always find her in your heart."

"What do you mean? Where is she!"

"She told me that she doesn't want you to follow her." His face is so disgustfully unexpressive.

"Damn you! Tell me where she went!" you force yourself up to his ugly mug.

"She didn't want..." You grab the guard by his shoulders. Your anger reaches its boiling point. "Very well, she has left for the capital. I'm told she was sorry, Milord."

The news forces you to fall back to the ground. You thought you freed yourself from her influence. Yet, at the final stretch, she made you hers once again.
> You no, that road only leads you to your doom.
Your heart, your gut screams at you to leave immediately. It would feel right. Yet something resists this first instinct. Following your heart has led you to only pain. You'll have to do better. You'll have to be better.

You let loose of the poor guard's shoulders.

"Thank you. Please ready my horse."

"Milord, you want to follow Lady Isabella?"

"I have followed her blindly for long enough. No, it's time for me to go back to the woods. I need to face my demons."

"Should I get the healmaster?" His concern makes you chuckle.

"Have him look for me if I'm not back at nightfall."

"At once, Milord."

By the time you manage to walk yourself to the stables, everything is ready.  Your horse is ready, eyes eager and hooves trampling. It's almost as if he wants this to end as much as you do, as if he wants the real you back. You sigh. It's just a horse.

You find yourself riding the same roads as before. The familiar turns pass you by in one green haze. There's so much to think about, so much to reflect. The one thing that's certain is Garreth. He's as a rock standing between the breaking of the furious waves. He'll help you find the light once again.

 
> Back at the familiar cabin.
The cabin is identical to your memory, unmarred by time and struggle. It emits a peaceful sense of languidity. It's exactly what you need. A bastion of safety standing amidst the untamed woods.

Garreth is nowhere to be seen. The bastion is yours. You find yourself doing the familiarly mindless and repetitive chores. You clean the fireplace, reorder the timbers and sweep the floor. It helps you loosen your muscles and relax.

"Robert." The sudden voice startles you. "I did not expect you here so soon."

"The time was thick with events." Garreth always brought out the archaic ways in everyone he met.

"Can you walk?"

"Better than ever," you boast. This place fills you with youthful vigor. You'll be reminded of your mortality soon enough.

"Come then, follow me." Garreth starts to walk, slowly to let you catch up. He pointedly ignores your limp.

"I've come for advice," you start the conversation.

"Advice and passed time is all that's left of me." 

"I don't know what to do. It's again about my wife, Isabella. We had a fight, I couldn't handle my forgiveness. Her actions were too vile, too recent. I pushed her away when she was just opening up."

"You pushed her away when she was at her most vulnerable?" Garreth managed to utter those words with nothing but compassion.

"Yes, I am sorry."

"Don't be sorry. You did what you did. You chose yourself above putting yourself down. While that first act was despicable, it came from solid reasons and will lead you into healthier straits."

"I feel so wrong, Garreth."

"Sometimes feelings point you to the wrong thing. They nag you on when it's time to move past. Other times feelings help you discover your deepest needs. At that moment you told her off, you wanted to do it, didn't you?"

You don't know the answer. Everything is mushed together in a raging storm indecipherable to your mind. Still, what Garreth says sounds vaguely true.

"I did," you reply hesitantly.

"Then stop worrying about the past and start thinking about the future. You still love her, that much is for everyone to see. But do you find your love worth the struggle of regaining your trust, regaining your relationship?" His eyes light up in enquiry.
> You say "Of course I do,"
Garreth's eyes show a hint of guilty disappointment. Yet he remains there for you. He'll always stand by your side.

"Go on then. Follow your heart. But remember, boy. Do so tempered with wisdom. Don't let yourself get lost again." There's a hint of finality behind those words. It was as if he was concluding a chapter in his life. Could it be?

"Thank you, Garreth. Thank you for everything."

"Yes, yes. Go now and continue on your own. I fear I'll have to move out soon." The greatest and only support who helped you through your worst times now moves on. You want to feel abandoned. Yet you feel his end will allow you a new beginning. You have to move on and become better. It's only you now, only you against the world.

You both say your stoical goodbyes. There is nothing to do about it. Both of you want to leave the other with the best impression. Pride demands nothing less.

So you move out of the woods, his parting gifts a newfound sense of determination. You feel as if he's still there. He left his image to guide you further. And further is the only route left.

You leave your barony to embark on a solitary journey. The long road to Isabella leaves you exhausted. Days spent on the saddle grind through your will, strain your wounds. Yet the truth keeps you going. She is your love. She is waiting for you.
> You she is there.
You see her as you arrive. She's there, standing on a balcony and gracing the heavens with her presence. She was indeed waiting. Nothing brings you more joy. You make haste to join her.

You stable your horse as fast as you can. There is nothing stopping you from reaching her. You are ready. Let all bygones be bygones. Hope and passionate love fills your heart.

"Where do you think you're going?" the nagging voice of your rotten liege disturbs your trajectory.

"I've come to reclaim what I've lost." There is a fiery hint of challenge you never imagined you'd have. It shocks both of you.

"She fled here to be saved from you." The tone was much weaker than the words.

"Don't do this," you demand. "Let us save our marriage."

Several guards join the heated exchange. The numeric superiority makes him feel safe and spurs him on.

"Leave or be arrested." You can't let him stop you. With a quick movement, you ready your sword. You'll fight the whole castle if you have to, or die knowing you gave your life for her.

"Listen-"

"Robert..." There she is, every bit as divine as you had imagined. Your stance falters as your eyes meet. They look in pain, overflowing with boundless sorrow. Still, she came...

"Don't do this Isabella!" the duke tries to interrupt your magical moment. You don't let him and abandon your sword as you move to embrace her. There is so much said in your stare, more in your grip.

"I love you, Isa, always have. There is so much I wish I hadn't done. I was a fool, a damned fool for letting you go," you say. "Let me start by saying I forgive you; and beg of you to do the same."

There, she returns your embrace. Her delicate hands wrap themselves around your neck. "I've always felt a connection, a thread of faith between us. Even at the worst moments, I felt disgusted by myself more than anything you'd done." Her tone is one of wistful happiness. "I am sorry for everything I did. I am sorry for everything I didn't do. I love you too, Robert."

You wish you could spend your whole life like this. 
> You say "No."
"I can't let you do this. Isabella, remember everything he did. He pushed you away. He was disgusted by you. I love you for who you truly are. Don't throw this away." How did you ever look up to this man. He grew more pathetic with every word he uttered. Yet he still had you surrounded with his guards.

"Let us go, Milord. Forget this day happened. Forget all of it. We can start again. We can go and never meet each other again. Just let us go."

"Shut up! I am speaking to her." It seemed your words didn't have any effect. You look for another escape route, hardly listening to his further grovels. "... so don't choose him. Why go for a halfwitted and impoverished baron, when I am here for you?"

That frog had regressed into throwing half-baked insults to lower his competition. One glance at your wife shows she's equally unimpressed.

"You fooled me, told great tales and spun golden threads over my eyes. You actually had me fooled, blinded me to the truth behind it all. Hiding beneath all of that," she says disgusted while gesturing to him. "Is this. I'd gladly chose a halfwitted and impoverished baron over someone as deceitful and pathetic as you. At the very least he had the balls to be true to himself."

As much as you'd like to continue to enjoy seeing your wife stand up to him like that, her spirit did little to defuse your precarious situation.

"Maybe it isn't smart to insult our captor," you mutter under our breath. She pointedly ignores any sarcasm.

"Trust me," she replies.
> You say "I do."
"Then. Be. Silent," she continues. All you do in reply is gulp down your words. She now possessed a fire that you're afraid to be burnt by.

"So as I said. You have a choice. Either you continue in your wallowing and end up arresting us under false pretenses, or you be a better man and set us free. You can't order faith around, Leo. Choosing to go against her will only expose your hideous insecurities to the whole world."

You carefully look at your liege. At first, he seems merely indignant. Then his face turns a shade of red out of anger only unleashed by painful humiliation. You love her.

"How dare you, woman! How dare you speak to me like this in public? I should have you hanged for treason!"

"Do it," she replies coldly without hesitation. "Do it and show your true self to the world."

At her statement, the guards close their ranks around you. Spears and swords stand ready at a word's notice. The only thing between you both and certain death lies a furious duke.

He opens his mouth, as if to give the order, only to close it again. He seems as torn as you were weeks ago. He had everything he desired moments ago, only for it to be pulled apart by the woman at the center of it. You know how he feels, almost sympathize with him, yet find no mercy on the one who was so involved in your downfall.

Sensing his moment of indecision Isabella pulls you away. Slowly you step backward as if walking away from a threatened cow. After a few steps, you see your victory. The man had broken his posture, hanged his head in defeat. Tears formed beneath his bloodshot eyes.

You turn around to face your love. "Let's go."

You quickly run for the horse, ride as fast as you can into safety. You'd be safe at home. Your barony has defied any invaders for centuries. On the way back, you both keep a sacred silence. There is simply too much to be said to simply put in words.

You feel good.

Sometimes you see your old mentor look at you, eyes split by an internal struggle. It was a struggle you knew all too well, for he is making the same mistakes you made. You're both so alike, yet in such a different period of life. You're not ready.

The days fly you by. Every one filled to the brim with work and fulfillment. You see your work reflected back to you. Every hard day you put down makes your land just a little bit richer, your people slightly more prosperous. It's only a tiny amount, yet is enough.

Soon the duke calls for you again. Your work impressed him. He wants you as an advisor, this time an official one. You see it as the empty road of vain, it would lead you back to your old self. It would make the fruit of your struggles undone. You humbly decline.

<|startoftext|>Isabella...

You first met her during a long voyage. Both of you were so young and full of life. You fell in love with her laugh, with the twinkle in her smile, with the simple dress she wore. You remember how you immediately excused yourself from your father's entourage and ran up to her. You had no words ready, your eagerness only expressed with an awkward smile.

She smiled back then. She smiled back at you! At that moment you did not care about the words of your father. You held no love anymore for the betrothed you were supposed to visit. You laughed together, you shed tears together and you loved each other. You spurned your father and brought her back with you.

She smiled less. Your Isa felt unwanted, hated even, for winning your heart. Whenever the chance arose you slipped into the woods. The escapades back then were glorious, full of adventure and passion. You commiserated together in your hate for your father. Memories of wild schemes and impossible plots come back to you.

She smiled. Your father fell ill. The baron was dead, long live the baron. You could finally marry your Isa. Ah, your marriage ceremony was worthy of an emperor. Your Isa became your wife. Whenever rulership threatened to overtake you, she brought you back. She practically made you into the man you are now. You could share everything with her, wild ambitions and impossible choices. She helped you stay on top.

She... She became more distant over the years. Unreturned smiles, frigid kisses, and cold talks became a common occurrence. Whatever you tried, you could not manage to get an heir. You did not care, blinded by love, but your Isa did. She withdrew herself, her once warm heart became hard and emotionless. You feared for her, did you do the right thing in taking her to your lands?

Then, suddenly, she bounced back up. Her beautiful voice could once again be heard in your keep. Her eyes twinkled once again. You couldn't believe it. The love of your life was back.

You spent those days working as an advisor for your duke. The work was hard. The duke didn't listen often. However, the pay was good, and the connections even better. Together with your Isa, you managed to broker vital trade deals. You worked with and earned the respect of other barons. Together with your Isa, you were unstoppable.

 
> You have to stop. You don't want to remember.

The beast stands on top of you, guarding your perceived corpse against an onslaught of distraught knights. Your body hurts from the first attack, but you were spared any further trauma afterwards.

Your recovery has been noticed. The knights let out cheering battlecry and redouble their efforts to drive off your captor. As one they push their pikes forwards. The bear tries to defend itself, leaving you open for a move. As the bear moves his weight to its rear legs you make your way to your discarded spear, it had been left broken in half.

There! The bear is completely oblivious to your machinations. It tries to intimidate and overwhelm your men. As it stands on just two legs you take your chance and jam the tip of the spear into the back of its knee. The roar is overwhelming. The beast loses its balance and falls.

Your men pounce on the opportunity. They skewer and they cut. The few surviving dogs sense its downfall and grind their teeth into the bear's joints. You did it. It was you that made the blow that finished the beast. The threat is gone. A nearby knight hands you his knife. All that's left to do is to end its misery, end the hunt.

As you come down from your high, you take notice of your losses. You had started this hunt with sixteen men. Now only twelve are able to walk. The rest are being tended by the others as well as possible. They will probably survive. The hunting dogs, though expendable, were especially hard hit. Half of them are left either laying whimpering, or dead.

"Well done," Garreth approaches you. This hunt hadn't been good to him, every move makes his facial muscles harden in agony.

"Pure luck," you reply, though you can't help to smile.

"Sir Robert Beastslayer, you were extraordinarily brave today. And above all, you tempered your madness with a strong instinct for survival. Own it."

Your epithet had come into the world, and you know nothing would stop it.

"We need to tend to the wounded. Send Sir Erick to the horses and have him get help. With any luck, we'll all survive this day."

Sometime later you both tend the dogs. They are a vicious breed, lightning-quick and wrathful. Still, they fought well and were loyal. They deserve your help.
> Back at the castle.
At the head of a large and growing caravan, you return to the castle. Thus far you have shrugged off any healmasters demanding to tend to your wounds. Instead, you wanted to make an impression. Behind you, three carts squeak under the weight of your catches. They are escorted by those of the hunt that were relatively unharmed. These carts are followed by the wounded. Though obviously in pain, their faces beam in pride. 

For half the village has left their tasks to follow the procession. Everywhere you go, you are cheered. The size of the beasts scares the children and intimidates the men. This will be an event to be remembered for years to come. Your epithet had left the forest and follows you. The crowd whispers of the beastslayer in awe amongst themselves.

You can't help but smile yourself. You raise your broken spear and a wall of sound erupts. Your life is good.

The servants in the castle are already preparing a magnificent feast in your honor. As you approach your ancestral home you could almost forget the wear and tear. New flags are proudly displaying their bright colors at the top of the gates. Abandoned torches are relit and the staff had themselves refitted into new clothes, dutifully presenting themselves at the side of the road. You lead your procession through the gate and into the outer court.

You need to capitalize on this opportunity. Just a day ago was the lowest point of your life, you need to ride this wave of glory to the top. You direct your horse to the stairs, inviting your knights to follow you. Once at the top you start your speech.

"Approach and look onto those foul beasts! Long have they terrorized the neighboring baronies, long have they waited for an opening to do the same to us. But today we fought! Today we showed them, and the world that we are not to be intimidated! Today we have shown the world what it means to be one of us!"

The reply is deafening, the crowd is ecstatic. But you need to say more.

"The beasts were cunning. They were fast. They were dangerous. But guess what! So are we! We fought back, we were faster. We are even more dangerous! This is what happens to our enemies, to any that dares to defy us!

I want to thank the men standing right in front of me. They are true heroes, born from your blood, raised on your land. They acted with a brave heart that could only be found right here. 

I want to thank you. You are what makes us great. You work and toil hard every day to improve the lives of your neighbors. You are the true sons and daughters of Rivellon. You are her heart and her soul. You are her backbone that withstands the world. You are her arms that beat it back. You are her everyday heroes!

And most of all I want to eat! Let's feast until the night ends and then some. For Rivellon! For our future!"

As you make your way down from your horse you secretly wink at your knights. The story you told would be magnified many times until it reaches epic proportions.

You hope the feast would do the same.
> The feast is glorious.
That night you lose yourself in the decadent celebration. Everyone wants to be there with you. Everyone wants to attract your attention. You feast. You drink. You are the true heroes of the occasion and you act the part. The drinks really impact your judgment. As the night progresses, you become louder and more unrefined. You balance on your chair at the head of the hall. Seated closest to you are the men that saved your life. You all erupt in a unified chorus. That's when you black out.

The following morning you wake up in unknown surroundings. The one thing you do know is that your body is not enjoying the abuse you put it through. A groan escapes your lips, causing movement around you.

Great, a full bed.

You roll over and try to stand up. You push down your guilt together with your nausea. You didn't do it. You don't even remember doing it, however good it may have felt. You have to get out of there. Your flight leaves more moans behind. You try to forget the walk of shame that follows.

"Milord?" a guard approaches you. "Milord!"

"Yes, yes. It's me all right. What is it?" The headache leaves you little patience.

"We have received word from the capital. The duke will soon visit, taking Lady Isabella with him." The news sobers you up instantly.

"How soon?"

"Milord?" the guard replies with a sheepish face.

"How soon will they arrive?" you ask again.

"Four days, Milord."

"Very well. I need you to send word to everyone important." Upon consideration, you force yourself to specify it further. "Meaning the steward, castellan, the village elder and my knights. We'll have a meeting at noon." You almost walk away when you remember your mentor. "Oh, try to bring Garreth too."


 
> The meeting.
You choose a secluded room to host the meeting. It's large, suited with a large round table. Hopefully, it'll be large enough to make everyone understand the scope of the future.  As you take place opposite of the doors, the first participants tickle in. Your men at arms arrive first as you had expected.

"Welcome. Sorry to disturb your moment in the spotlight," you say with a smile.

"What's the matter, Milord?" a knight responds. It's sir Erick, always the fastest one.

"The duke decided to come visit." You notice one particular knight missing. "Did sir Myre survive his celebration?"

"The old man probably had a heart attack being the center of attention for once," Erick jokes. "Last I've seen him he was profusely apologizing to his wife."

"You know what they say.." you joke back.

"Talking about fun, you got plenty too, Milord."

You want to respond when your steward enters the room. She takes a moment to gather her senses.

"My Lord, you called for me?"

"Yes I did, Elaria. Please have a seat. When everyone arrives we'll have to plan our ducal reception." Her eyes light up at the last two words, her attention clearly intrigued. She's still new in your castle and vicious rumors surround her. You'll have to tread carefully with her.

"When will he arrive, My Lord?" She's all business as usual.

"We currently think we'll have four days," you reply back. However, you don't want to start the discussion early. "Did you enjoy the feast?"

"I'm afraid I had to leave early. I do not mix well with ale and rowdy feasts."

"I'm guessing you keep yourself busy mixing other things." another knight, Sir Rudolph, vehemently answers. Her rise to steward was made possible due to an untimely death. To this day many distrust her as an outsider.

"Now, now." you quickly interject. "Remember, we are all rooting for the same cause here."

Any further discussion is broken off with another entrance. Your castellan enters the room, an extraordinary young man for such an important position. His youth makes him quick to overlook. Though you hope he'll balance this table out with his youthful passion and gain valuable experience in the process.

"Milord," he says while deeply bowing. "Excuse my tardiness."

"You luckily aren't the last to arrive." you try to make him at ease. "Please have a seat."

Lastly, Garreth arrived with Myre and the village elder. Together, they look like the grumpy grandfathers of the barony.

"Welcome. Let's start, shall we?" You wait until everyone has taken their seats. "As we all know, our hunt has been the talk of the duchy. Apparently it has even reached the ears of the duke himself. In all his glorious wisdom," you continue with heavy sarcasm. "He decided to personally visit us in four days."

The news sparks a lot of discussion within your group.

"Yes, it's big news. Still, I feel it won't be all sunshine and rainbows. The duke has hidden motives and I want us to be prepared for whatever it is." A character like that wouldn't give up his luxurious home filled with sycophants for just anything.

"Milord?" your castellan speaks up softly.

"Yes, Driòr?" He really needed to work on his assertivity.

"How would you like our reception to be?"

This is a harder question than you first imagined it. With your sudden recent leave from the capital and the subsequent miraculous success, you have gotten momentum on your side. People no longer see you as just an advisor. You are a beastslayer now, and you'll have to decide how to fill in that role.


 
> You say "Grandiose."
"I want to unsettle their expectations and their balance. Throw everything you had planned out of the window. The grand hall, yes the disused one, will set the tone. I want you to expand on it."

"Yes, Milord. Please excuse me. I have a lot to prepare." Good, he was learning.

"Granted, do your best," you say and wait until he had left the room. "This leaves us with the more important task of defending ourselves."

The people in the room, all handpicked for their experience and competency, are silenced. Everyone was struck by the suddenness of events. Eventually, Garreth speaks up.

"What makes you certain we'll be under attack?"

"It's in his nature," you respond. You had expected this question. "The duke takes away his subject's happiness. He can't and won't allow anyone to outshine him. We unwittingly did during our hunt, while it was not what we wanted. Still, it's all the same to him. He'll need to crush us to feel good himself. We can't let that happen."

"We'll hold out on the ale," Myre says pointedly looking at his men. He was the most veteran of your troops. "I leave the politicking and the planning to you, but trust us to guard the castle whenever needed."

"Milord, please think of the people. If you expect war, they'll fight for you. But you mustn't leave them to die outside the walls," the village elder continues. You don't know the old man by name, only by reputation.

"Do not worry. A feast this grand will have everyone attend. I expect Driòr will talk to you soon about provisions, say he'll have to expect a couple hundred more guests." Smiles break out across the room when everyone imagines his face. "The village will not be forgotten."

As you continue talking specifics, you distinctly notice Elaria's silence. She doesn't speak, staying in the background of the discussion and only observing. Her sharp and inquisitive eyes scan across the room, nothing betraying her intentions. as she notices you, she only gives the faintest of smiles.

"My Lord," she says after the conclusion of the meeting. "Have you consider an attack of your own?"

It's a tricky question. Even discussion of this topic was nothing shy of rebellion.

"What makes you ask such things," you whisper back furiously. "Don't you know the walls have ears?"

"Those ears belong to me, my Lord. Speak openly, knowing only we can hear this conversation."

"I did. Nothing is possible without dire consequences to my lands."

"What about poison?" she asks too chipper for the topic.

"Poison is a wom-" you start.

"So you haven't. Good. Allow me then to introduce you to another world." She now brings her hands into her pockets showing three distinctive liquids.

"All of them are odorless, don't you worry about that. They'll all easily end a man's life, so that's also not a concern. No, the question is the duration and the type of death."

You're completely astounded. You'd let a woman in your castle that could end a man's life at a moment's notice and without any guilt.

"So this little fellow over here does his work within minutes. It's like some people with the cursed bees, you know. All the blood simply goes to the skin and they die. No idea why, but it looks bad. If you want the duke dead and make a statement, this is your poison."

What. Is. Happening.

"His little brother is totally different. There is something about this one that I simply can't put my finger on. You take it and you simply forget to breathe. They seem unaware of anything that's around them. Someone's old and you want them gone without too much suspicion? This is your lucky shot. Although I have heard the duke has barely entered his twenties... So maybe forget this exists."

Did she use that one on your old steward? You'll have to find out.

"The third and final option I have so graciously procured at your immediate summon is this bad boy. This is the mean uncle of them all. It'll slowly but surely end a man's life. If you take this he'll eventually shit himself to death a month later. Rest assured, the ingredients come from my home. Use this and nobody will link the death to the feast. I think it's the perfect poison for you on this occasion."

"Elaria?" you finally ask.

"Yes?" she responds entirely too innocent.

"Have you used them before?"

"That is for me to know, and for you to wonder," she says before seeing your expression change. "But yes, I did. Not on anyone here though. See it as a personal hobby of mine."

You let out a deep sigh. It was happening and you'll have to choose. Do you want to go on the attack, using these dishonorable means, or do you want to stay on the defensive, waiting for it all to blow over?
> You use the poison. You can't surrender yourself to faith.
"Do it. Use the third one. I trust you have an antidote for it?"

"Yes I do, my Lord."

"Then pour it in the goblet we'll all be drinking from."

"I understand. Alright." She moves to the exit only to pause for a moment. "And by the way, thank you for trusting me." She leaves you with only your own silence to prepare.

Tomorrow will be the big day. All will depend on it. You mentally imagine yourself standing at the top of the wall, seeing them approach. You see their horses, their weaponry. Out from the distance they come. Like ants, they trek through the fields, no amount of arrows able to stop them. They are scaling up your walls. You simply can't handle the tide. You can't stop them. You can't save your barony.

"Hey! Wake up." Garreth entered your view with a worried expression. "Everything will be all right. I trust you."

"We are so powerless. We can only surrender ourselves to him. If he wants us gone, we are."

"Don't worry about possible failures, you'll only be invoking them."

"I can't help it. The stakes are so high."

"Then worry about the day after. What will you do?"

This is when the poison kicks in, when you'll finally be rescued from your chains to that frog.

"I'll sing and dance and thank the gods we've survived the whole ordeal."
> You he doesn't seem impressed.
You stand on top of the walls. It feels like your entire barony stands side by side with you. There are grim faces, white knuckles and an overall sense of stressful anticipation. You needed to do your ancestors proud. You needed to show everyone you were something special. 

In the distance you see a grand column moving toward you. It is escorted by hundreds of shining armors. It feels like a force prepared for a siege. Your heart thumps in your throat. You want this. You're excited.

There, leading the mass are two solitary riders. One must be your cursed wife, the other the feared duke himself. They're close enough.

You move to the tower, down the staircase, and through the gate. It's been opened. The heavy metal bars will no longer protect you against the trespassers. You will have to suffice.

"Welcome, welcome to our lands my liege," you say bowing respectfully. "It's a great honor for all of us."

"The honor is mine," he smiles back. "For it is not every day my subjects perform such a great act."

"Thank you, Milord. Please follow me." You pointedly ignore your wife as you turn around and lead them into your home.

"As you can see, the castle has undergone heave reconstruction upon hearing of your liege's arrival."

Your duke watches with amazement as impossible colors mix with incomprehensible shapes. You would never be able to do it without heavy inspiration from that old hall. The one hall that had survived for centuries. You copied it's strange designs and enlarged it to show to the world. They are plastered over the walls, drawn on the roads and envelop the houses.

The duke is simply amazed. You can't help but let yourself smirk.
> You say "Wait until you see the real deal."
The old throne room was everything you imagined it to be. Strange and exotic geometric shapes broke the light in a thousand different ways. There was no central seating, the strange walls and art compartmentalized the room is a hundred little secluded tables. Everybody was as equal as it could be. You enjoy it tremendously, mingle with every group. The duke decidedly less so, yet you try just enough to keep him at the very least satisfied.

Eventually, pleasure makes its way for business. When you get the signal from Elaria, you raise your glass.

"Milord, let's have a toast."

"A splendid idea," he replies to your great joy. "Let me lead it."

"Alright, Milord." For once his abrasive nature doesn't faze you. It'll only lead him to his demise. You can't hold a slight chuckle.

Your liege stands up. Only to be ignored by the rest. It's only when his guards shout for silence, that the room actually listens.

"Ahem. As we all know, we've come together today to celebrate. We've come today to show you the honor you have so long yearned."

"Damn right!" some drunk quickly replies. He's escorted out shortly.

"For this courage, this valor and skill is what makes us great. As you've demonstrated there is nothing separating us from the grand days of yore. What you have done is nothing short of what is being written in legends."

There's a catch. He'll implicate himself soon.

"It was I that ordered the hunt. When I saw Robert, I immediately saw his potential. There was a fire behind his eyes. A fire that I so rarely see outside my own mirage. It was that fire that earned him my trust. Let's toast together, all of us, on that fire. May it burn in every one of us!"

You glady sip your wine in reply.
> The seed has been planted.
It takes less than a month for tragic news to reach your court. The duke had died leaving no heirs. The realm was in upheaval. Rivals were at each other's throats. People looked to a strong man for guidance.

Maybe it was because you had that month to prepare. Maybe you were a changed man. Maybe you were simply the one at the right place and the right time. The result was the same. People flocked to your banner. With your trusted council by your side you claimed the higher Lordship for yourself.

It was contested, as you expected. Yet every great man in history became nothing without a struggle. You poisoned the opposition, moved around them, or simply destroyed them in battle. Eventually, your rule was uncontested.<|endoftext|>

> You trust her. Still, you don't want to use her talents.
"Thank you for showing me this. I fear we'll have much use of your talents in the future," you start. It's always wise to keep such a dangerous woman content.

"Let me guess. You won't do it."

"I don't think this is the right path, Elaria. When was the last time a vassal murdered his liege and got away with it?"

"Roughly three years ago," she responds factually.

You gulp, "Well, the risks are too great. This is not us."

"Very well. Let me know when you'll regret it, maybe it won't be too late." She promptly leaves the room.

She's dangerous. Knowing her darker side, you can't totally ascertain yourself of her loyalty. She is not a loose cannon, but her ambition may lead her astray.

You return to your rooms mulling over what had transpired. The meeting was good. You have no doubt everyone will be ready for that day. It'll mean the difference between a rise to power and certain doom.

"Alright, the duke won't like this. But it's time to show the boy the world doesn't spin around him. We are our own people with our own customs. He'll have to play according to our rules. Take it or leave it."

"He won't like it," Garreth says. "It's not smart."

"At what point do we stop bending over?" Sir Erick responds.

"Are you willing to die for your beliefs?"

"You aren't?"

Garreth only replies with a grunt. Someone played him at his own game.

"I want to do this without directly taunting the duke," you shush them both. "And I want to do this without selling ourselves out to a city boy."

"Trust us. We'll behave," Sir Myre says pointedly looking at Erick. "And we'll be preparing a nice surprise for our guests. Oh, and we'll need the villagers too."

"If both Driòr and the elder agree..."

"Yes, yes. We'll talk to them afterward."

"Then go ahead."

"As you can see, your fast arrival left us without much preparation. What you see here is authentic. These are our lands as they are."

"I see..."

"Before we start the feast, tradition calls for an offering in blood. My finest knights will offer themselves as a worthy opponent in a grand melee." It was overexaggerated, of course. "Also my townsmen are forming their own company. If you have any not of noble blood that wants to test their mettle, they are free to do so as well."

"Hmm..."

You see the duke is far from impressed. Tough luck, your people are what they are. They are ready and you can't change that.

Luckily your wife breaks the stalemate. She whispers something and his entire demeanor changes. It makes you sick. There she is, so close yet so far away.
> You see her again at the feast.
Both melees have been won. You're proud of your people. Yet the duke's reaction worries you. You had expected more maturity, at the very least more dignity. Yet he acts like a petulant child. He's only kept in check by your wife. You see now that you've lost her. She has sold her soul to that vile frog. You soften your sorrow with a few more drinks.

That is what the feast descended into. For all your instructions have been abandoned. When swept up in glory, your people can't deny their drinks and fun. The hall descends into something resembling a shady pub. It's not long before drunken brawls start breaking out. The tension had reached its boiling point.

The brawls spread. The duke panics. Complete chaos descends and envelops every one of you. It's not long before swords are drawn and two camps arise. You try desperately to calm things down. But what is one man against the flood?

The two groups charge leaving only bloodshed, death, and destruction. You had failed. You know you'll never survive this day.
> You flee.
Your barony has been lost. Your people are slaughtered in front of your very eyes. Some deep part of you growls its satisfaction; they deserved it.

But not you. You wait, pretend to join the fray and quietly move out to the door. It's open. You slam it shut behind you and run as fast as you can.

"Where do you think you're going?"

The harsh voice interrupts your escape. It's a ducal guard, top brass. He moves in to block the way as he's joined by his men.

"I'm afraid I need some fresh air." you try as sweetly as you can.

"Duke's orders. No one goes in or out. I'm afraid you'll need to-"

The moment you hear his refusal you step in, draw your dagger and plant it firmly in his throat. There's no time for arguing. Before the others have time to react you slice another open. The last guard stares at you with shocked eyes. It is the last thing he sees.

You run, don't stop for anything. Your castle is in flames. Any remaining villagers have been murdered and their homes pillaged. It's a catastrophe.

You run for the only thing you know to be safe. You run for the woods. You know there are pursuers, hear horses speeding up to you. 

You lose them all in the green hell. None of them return.

Over the years people start to fear the forest. Ancient dark spirits kill any who dares to enter their realm. Hunting parties search for the lost baron. They hunt you like a beast. You're smarter than them.

You spent the rest of your short life fighting.

You have so many regrets.<|endoftext|>

<|startoftext|>You choose a secluded room to host the meeting. It's large, suited with a large round table. Hopefully, it'll be large enough to make everyone understand the scope of the future.  As you take place opposite of the doors, the first participants tickle in. Your men at arms arrive first as you had expected.

"Welcome. Sorry to disturb your moment in the spotlight," you say with a smile.

"What's the matter, Milord?" a knight responds. It's sir Erick, always the fastest one.

"The duke decided to come visit." You notice one particular knight missing. "Did sir Myre survive his celebration?"

"The old man probably had a heart attack being the center of attention for once," Erick jokes. "Last I've seen him he was profusely apologizing to his wife."

"You know what they say.." you joke back.

"Talking about fun, you got plenty too, Milord."

You want to respond when your steward enters the room. She takes a moment to gather her senses.

"My Lord, you called for me?"

"Yes I did, Elaria. Please have a seat. When everyone arrives we'll have to plan our ducal reception." Her eyes light up at the last two words, her attention clearly intrigued. She's still new in your castle and vicious rumors surround her. You'll have to tread carefully with her.

"When will he arrive, My Lord?" She's all business as usual.

"We currently think we'll have four days," you reply back. However, you don't want to start the discussion early. "Did you enjoy the feast?"

"I'm afraid I had to leave early. I do not mix well with ale and rowdy feasts."

"I'm guessing you keep yourself busy mixing other things." another knight, Sir Rudolph, vehemently answers. Her rise to steward was made possible due to an untimely death. To this day many distrust her as an outsider.

"Now, now." you quickly interject. "Remember, we are all rooting for the same cause here."

Any further discussion is broken off with another entrance. Your castellan enters the room, an extraordinary young man for such an important position. His youth makes him quick to overlook. Though you hope he'll balance this table out with his youthful passion and gain valuable experience in the process.

"Milord," he says while deeply bowing. "Excuse my tardiness."

"You luckily aren't the last to arrive." you try to make him at ease. "Please have a seat."

Lastly, Garreth arrived with Myre and the village elder. Together, they look like the grumpy grandfathers of the barony.

"Welcome. Let's start, shall we?" You wait until everyone has taken their seats. "As we all know, our hunt has been the talk of the duchy. Apparently it has even reached the ears of the duke himself. In all his glorious wisdom," you continue with heavy sarcasm. "He decided to personally visit us in four days."

The news sparks a lot of discussion within your group.

"Yes, it's big news. Still, I feel it won't be all sunshine and rainbows. The duke has hidden motives and I want us to be prepared for whatever it is." A character like that wouldn't give up his luxurious home filled with sycophants for just anything.

"Milord?" your castellan speaks up softly.

"Yes, Driòr?" He really needed to work on his assertivity.

"How would you like our reception to be?"

This is a harder question than you first imagined it. With your sudden recent leave from the capital and the subsequent miraculous success, you have gotten momentum on your side. People no longer see you as just an advisor. You are a beastslayer now, and you'll have to decide how to fill in that role.


 
> You say "Welcoming."
"We are facing a man that wants no other light in the world shine brighter than his own. He wants to be the strongest, most valorous and most charming. I trust you know what to do Driòr?"

"Yes, Milord. I'll make him the center of attention. If I may; I have a lot to prepare."

"Go ahead," you say and wait until he had left the room. "So now you know what we face. It is a jealous man, hellbent on usurping our glory. He wants to leave these lands with our honor by his side, or he'll leave these lands burnt to ashes."

Garreth speaks up first, "I agree. We can't hold him back if he's there with an army by his side. His superiority is just too great."

"Then you would demote us to mere slaves?" Sir Rudolph, always quick to anger, replies in anger.

"I would demote us to survivors."

"I'll whip the men up in good shape, just in case," Sir Myre adds to the conversation. Rudolph stays silent. "We can't win, but we can show the man it would cost him dearly."

"What about the common people, Milord?" the village elder asks.

"In the worst-case scenario, we need as many abled bodies within these walls as we can manage. Make sure to tell them only the bare minimum. I don't want any panic."

The answer seems to comfort the old man. He'll stand by your side. The knights look less impressed. The discussion eventually devolves into tedious specifics. You notice Elaria doesn't participate at all. Instead, she seems to stay behind in the shadows, carefully observing every man's word. As she catches your eyes, she gives only the faintest of smiles.

"My Lord," she says after the conclusion of the meeting. "Have you consider an attack of your own?"

It's a tricky question. You have considered it. Yet there's nothing you could find, nothing that could save you.

"I did. Nothing is possible without dire consequences to my lands."

"What about poison?" she asks flatly.

"Poison?" you ask.

"So you haven't. Good. Allow me then to introduce you to a whole other world." She now brings her hands into her pockets showing three distinctive liquids.

"All of them are odorless, don't you worry about that. They'll all easily end a man's life, so that's also not a concern. No, the question is the duration and the type of death."

You're completely astounded. The rumors were true. Sir Rudolph was right. Your steward hid dangerous talents, useful talents.

"So this little fellow over here does his work within minutes. It's like some people with the cursed bees, you know. All the blood simply goes to the skin and they die. No idea why, but it looks bad. If you want the duke dead and make a statement, this is your poison."

"We can't have that. The whole world will denounce us."

"Then you'll also dislike his little brother. Leaving us with only the third option," she continues without missing a beat. "The third and final option I have so graciously procured at your immediate summon is this bad boy. This is the mean uncle of them all. It'll slowly but surely end a man's life. If you take this he'll eventually shit himself to death a month later. Rest assured, the ingredients come from my home. Use this and nobody will link the death to the feast. I think it's the perfect poison for you on this occasion."

"Elaria?" you finally ask.

"Yes?" she responds entirely too innocently for what she'd just said.

"How certain are you they'll work?"

"Oh, they always work. The trick is having our target drink it without anyone knowing. I give you my word on that."
> You have to do it.
You stand on top of the walls. It feels like your entire barony stands side by side with you. There are grim faces, white knuckles and an overall sense of stressful anticipation. You needed to do your ancestors proud. You needed to show the world you could survive against all odds.

In the distance you see a grand column moving toward you. It is escorted by hundreds of shining armors. It feels like a force prepared for a siege. Your heart thumps in your throat.

There, leading the mass are two solitary riders. One must be your cursed wife, the other the feared duke himself. They're close enough.

You move to the tower, down the staircase, and through the gate. It's been opened. The heavy metal bars will no longer protect you against the trespassers. Open arms will have to suffice.

"Welcome, welcome to our lands my liege," you say bowing respectfully. "It's a great honor for all of us."

"The honor is mine," he smiles back. "For it is not every day my subjects perform such a great act."

"Thank you, Milord. Please follow me." You pointedly ignore your wife as you turn around and lead them into your home.

"As you can see, Milord, we are glad to have you among us. The whole barony has worked tirelessly to better accommodate your every need."

"Thank you, Sir Robert. I am blessed to have such fine subjects."

"Please, Milord. I am only blessed for such a gracious liege as you are." The key trick to sycophantry is making sure you'd be nauseous. "Allow me to show you the hall."

"Very well. Show me the way."
> You your castellan had outdone himself.

The evening progressed into the night as everyone wined and dined. The few glances show you your liege is enjoying himself greatly. It leaves you room to enjoy yourself for a moment. Although he would soak up all the honor, it is still your feast.

Your liege stands up. Within moments the whole room becomes silent.

"Ahem. As we all know, we've come together today to celebrate. We've come today to show you the honor you have so long yearned."

"For this courage, this valor and skill is what makes us great. As you've demonstrated there is nothing separating us from the grand days of yore. What you have done is nothing short of what is being written in legends."

<|startoftext|>It's eerily quiet. You crouch through the thick underbrush, carefully planting your feet where there's still green vegetation. In your right hand, you hold the leashes of the hunting dogs; in your left, you hold a long sturdy spear. It should be enough to face your prey.

You are surrounded by grim faces. Most of them are veterans. Garreth is up front as always. Compared to him even the veterans are inexperienced amateurs.

His hand shoots up. Everybody halts in their steps. He motions you forward.

"Two prey, still oblivious." His hand points to two black silhouettes.

"Any vultures?" He always had superior eyesight.

"Nothing, we are clear."

You look towards the most experienced of your hunting party and signal a split. A nod of acknowledgment and a pincer maneuver is executed. The wind tears your eyes as you wait for the two teams to sneak into position. You are left alone with Garreth, the dogs and mainly your thoughts.

"Now."

You release the dogs. They don't bark; they don't growl. As a soundless mass, they charge forwards. You both move closer. The bears are alarmed. A deep resonating roar fills the space between the trees. Moments later, you hear the impact. The dogs throw themselves at the bears, oblivious to any danger. Some are swatted away; others succeed and bite into the resilient skin. The hounds have no hope of killing the beasts. At best they will succeed in keeping them distracted and pinned down.

The two hunting parties now move in, their long spears ready and in formation.

This is what you live for. The battle, the carnage makes you feel alive. You are yet again master of your surroundings, master of your own fate. Garreth has seen enough and looks back at you.

"You are back. I've missed you." A small smile escapes his lips as he closes his eyes.

That was not something he said easily.

"Not back, just recovering." You return the smile. "You shouldn't let me hold you back. Enjoy your hunt, partake in the glory."

"My boy, once you reach my age you'll know a clear victory when you spot it."

Your mentor leaves you nevertheless. 

One bear has now been skewered and held in its place. Its defeated moans tell the world its a threat no longer. The other one, a stronger and more ferocious beast altogether, holds its own against the tide. It crushes one dog beneath its leg. It mauls another with its enormous claws and then rushes through the wall of spears, ruthlessly disrupting any plan of encirclement your party might once have had.

That's when Garreth arrives. He makes himself a big target, yelling at the top of his longs to draw attention. The beast is provoked. He crouches as it charges. At the last moment, he rolls forwards, stabbing his dagger at the soft underbelly. It happens so fast. He stands up, bloodied.

Meanwhile, the other hunters have rallied themselves. They skillfully close the ranks, leaving their target encapsulated in an ever-shrinking circle of spears. The old man had prevented chaos, but they did not allow him to claim the glory. Their advancement goes steadily, step by step. The trap had been laid and set.

The bear checks its solidity. Agitated, it paces around, angry at being denied its kill. Its wild eyes frantically search for any point of weakness. With angry roars, it makes its failure known.

That's when the hair on your neck starts to rise and something tells you to run. You try to duck and turn around, but a bone-shattering force hits your back.

You fly to the ground. Your world goes black for a moment as you hear a deafening roar mere inches from your head. Pretending to be dead, you hear panicked shouting. Sounds of battle are drawing closer and time crawls into a standstill.

Your body is numb once again. You strain yourself to look up and into the beast's maw. There is a moment of recognition. Its brown eyes stare into yours and you see your wife's in them. The battle around you fades away as she calls to you, as she soothes you. My Isa..

She tries to pull you into her memories. You look up and you see..
> A beast of nightmares.
This is not the time. You have to stay alert. Your heart is pounding in your throat. Your arms are twitching involuntarily in an increasing pool of clotting red blood. Still, your mind is clear.

You have to keep still in order to survive. It doesn't work. You see the brown eyes -focus on the eyes!- coming closer. You hear yourself scream as your body gets mangled and discarded away. Your panicking defense was overthrown by the sheer force. You struggle to breathe. The pain makes moving impossible.

As you lay there, you are certain of your end. The bear stands on his rear legs. His silhouette blots out the sun, never before have you been so humbled. Then slowly it descends to finish its job. A last-ditch effort, pure adrenaline, and primal fear take over, forcing you to roll sidewards. You've bought yourself some seconds of life.

However, something changes. The beast trashes wildly, seemingly ignoring you. With wild, uncoordinated movements you crawl into safety. Nearby you hear the paws of your pack of dogs smashing the ground, closing the distance. They are followed by the shouting, several hands pull you further back. A flash of pain and you find yourself seated against a tree. The world turns into shades of gray, turns ninety degrees as you lose all sense of where you are.

Unintelligible directing voices are followed with pressure on your wounds. In the distance you see a mountain being battled by little figures. It's funny how the little figures fly. The mountain moves, changes its shape, strikes out to everything around it. Yet it doesn't seem enough to stem the tide. The water around it contorts itself with every attack. It's a beautiful dance, an artful exchange between two colliding forces of nature. However the deft dodges seem to tire the mountain, it can't keep the pace up. It slows, only to be methodically surrounded and then corroded by the tide.

It's funny how the mountain falls. Good. You let your bloodloss take your consciousness.<|endoftext|>
